[[File:Alan with hat 2.jpg|thumb|Alan Reed]]
'''Alan Reed''' (born 1961 in [[Corbridge]], [[Northumberland]], [[England]]) is a UK [[watercolour]] artist. He began painting at an early age, winning a prize at the age of 10 for his painting of 'Bamburgh Castle at sunset'. He had his first exhibition at the age of 18, at the local library in his home town, Ponteland, and has been taking commissions ever since. His watercolour paintings have been exhibited worldwide in the UK, Italy, the US and the Middle East.<ref>http://www.newartcollectors.com/artist_portfolio.asp?Artist=Alan%20Reed&Portfolio=1369#biog.</ref>
==Career== He trained as an illustrator/graphic designer at Newcastle upon Tyne College of Art and Technology from 1978 to 1982. Although his course did not touch on watercolour in the first year as he was being trained in other mediums including [[Acrylic paint|acrylic]] and [[gouache]], he practised using watercolours in his spare time. Early influences were established international artists including the American, [[Winslow Homer]], who had lived at [[Cullercoats]] in the North east of England, not far from where Alan lives now. He also admired the work of [[Rowland Hilder]], who he described as a master of [[cityscapes]], [[John Singer Sargent]] and [[Sir William Russell Flint]].<ref>http://www.ne4me.co.uk/culture-4/watercolour-artist-paints-29.html.</ref>
He left college with an HND in Applied Design and became self-employed in 1984 <ref>http://www.axisweb.org/seCVPG.aspx?ArtistID=3233.</ref> using the [[Enterprise Allowance Scheme]]. He also commenced a series of lecturing jobs at Newcastle College of Art and Technology, South Tyneside College, Derwentside College and Cleveland College of Art, covering a 20-year timescale. He opened his own Gallery of Fine Art in Eldon Garden, Newcastle in 1998 to 2002 and then went on to open his own studio in Ponteland.<ref>http://www.chroniclelive.co.uk/north-east-news/news-archive/2006/07/20/artist-s-brush-with-hospital-72703-17418438/.</ref>
He has been a member of the [[Fine Art Trade Guild]] for over 10 years.<ref>http://www.fineart.co.uk/Directory/Detail.aspx?DirectoryUid=ed6a18dc-f30b-4fa8-8a8f-8c52a46e9856.</ref> [[File:Grey Street, Saturday Morning.jpg|thumb|Grey Street, Saturday Morning, Newcastle]]
==The UK== Reed's work often includes street scenes. [[Newcastle upon Tyne]] <ref>http://www.journallive.co.uk/culture-newcastle/theatre-in-newcastle/2001/11/30/millennium-bridge-is-a-blinking-best-seller-61634-11454636/.</ref> is a source of inspiration and the city's football fans heading for St James Park football ground have been one of many local subjects. Scenes of [[Durham, England|Durham]] city, [[Northumberland]] castles and [[Norfolk]] are also amongst his extensive portfolio amassed over three decades of painting. He also has an array of images of [[Scotland]], in particular [[Edinburgh]] and the east coastline and has exhibited on a regular basis in Scotland. For three successive years (1992,1993 and 1994) his work was shortlisted for the [[Sunday Times]] Watercolour Competition. In September 2010 Alan was 1st runner up in "The Bath Prize" with his original painting of "[[The Royal Crescent]], [[Bath, Somerset|Bath]]". His painting "The [[Roman Baths (Bath)|Roman Baths]] by Torchlight" was also highly commended.<ref>http://www.journallive.co.uk/northumberland-sites/ponteland-northumberland/ponteland-news/2010/09/14/ponteland-painter-alan-reed-in-running-for-national-prize-61634-27264126/.</ref><ref>http://www.thisisbath.co.uk/Adrian-scoops-163-5-000-prize-prestigious-art-contest/story-11349589-detail/story.html.</ref> He has had a number of solo exhibitions since 1981 including those at the [[Mall Galleries]] in [[London]] and has been a regular exhibitor of rowing scenes in the Stewards' enclosure at the [[Henley Royal Regatta]] along with exhibitions in his native Newcastle.<ref>http://www.morpethherald.co.uk/lifestyle/artist_alan_has_his_own_independence_day_1_3509164.</ref>
[[File:Val d'Orcia.jpg|thumb|left|Val d'Orcia, Italy]]
==Italy== In 1991 Alan was introduced to Italy by Susan; the holiday was to have a lasting effect on him. Impressed by the landscape, Alan subsequently travelled to various regions throughout the country from the [[Veneto]] to [[Piedmont]], [[Tuscany]], [[Umbria]], the [[Amalfi Coast]] and [[Abruzzo]]. He has completed several commissions to paint famous towns and cities including [[San Gimignano]], [[Florence]] and [[Venice]]. In 2005 he held an exhibition of his work entitled "The Light" in [[Marostica]], which was featured on Italian television and local press.
[[File:Barka, Oman.jpg|thumb|Barka, Oman]]
==Middle East== Also in 2005 Reed was commissioned to paint two watercolours for a client in Oman. This became the catalyst for regular painting trips to [[Arab states of the Persian Gulf|The Gulf]], including [[Dubai]] and [[Kuwait]] as well as [[Oman]].<ref>http://www.nebusiness.co.uk/business-news/latest-business-news/2011/08/03/north-east-firms-looking-east-in-search-of-new-markets-51140-29163925/.</ref> common feature of his work in this region has been the [[dhows]] at rest in calm harbour waters, the distinctive [[Arabic]] architecture and the activity in the life of the Souks. Alan has enjoyed an ongoing relationship with the Bait Muzna Gallery in [[Muscat, Oman|Muscat]] since 2007. He had a joint exhibition with landscape photographer Malcolm MacGregor titled "Mystical Oman" in April 2010 opened by his Highness Sayyid Tarik Al Said.<ref>http://main.omanobserver.om/node/5240.</ref> sketch book studies of Oman have attracted significant interest and have been printed as a handmade leather bound limited edition reproduction sketch book featuring watercolours to celebrate Oman's 40th Renaissance.<ref>http://main.omanobserver.om/search/node/paintings+of+Oman+for+queen+elizabeth</ref>
==Personal life== Alan was born in [[Corbridge]], Northumberland, England, eldest son of Kenneth and Gillian Reed. Kenneth Reed is also an artist, specialising in paintings of [[golf]] courses.<ref>http://www.axisweb.org/seEventDetails.aspx?EventID=360242&TYPE=0.</ref> Alan's grandfather, Thomas Reed also painted and his great grandfather carved ship figureheads. Alan now lives in [[Ponteland]], Northumberland where his gallery and studio are based within his own home. He married his wife Susan in 1993 and they have two children and three grandchildren. They both share strong family ethics and a [[Christian]] faith along with a unique bond following an operation on 27 June 2001 at Newcastle's [[Freeman Hospital]]. Susan needed a [[kidney transplant]] and although her mother was tested she was not compatible.<ref>http://www.chroniclelive.co.uk/north-east-news/evening-chronicle-news/2001/05/12/gift-husband-can-save-desperately-ill-wife-72703-11051565/.</ref> Alan's kidneys were and he donated one of his own to Susan.<ref>Newcastle Evening Chronicle Saturday May 12, 2001 "A Gift of Life" Front Page.</ref><ref>The Journal, Newcastle Saturday December 22, 2001, pages 24–25</ref> story was featured on BBC 1's Songs of Praise on Sunday 5 November 2006.
==Further reading== Alan's approach to painting is described in a book entitled "[[Landscapes]] in Watercolour" by Theodora Philcox, a lecturer in art at Warwickshire. The book featured the work of 23 leading watercolourists from around the world.
Landscapes in Watercolour by Theodora Philcox {{ISBN|2-88479-004-7}}
The Artists of Northumbria by Marshall Hall {{ISBN|0-9532609-9-2}}
Golfing Art by Phil Pilley {{ISBN|0-09-171480-X}}

{{Infobox person | name = Anthony Charles Graves | image = Anthony Graves, October 2017.jpg | alt = Anthony Graves speaking at an event in October 2017 | caption = Anthony Graves speaking at an event in Spring, Texas, on October 11, 2017 | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1965|08|29}} | nationality = American | home_town = [[Brenham, Texas|Brenham]], [[Texas]], United States | known_for = Wrongfully convicted and sentenced to death; later exonerated }}
[[File:My last day.webm|thumbtime=1:56|{{largethumb}}|Short video by [[Amnesty International]]]] '''Anthony Charles Graves''' (born August 29, 1965) is the 138th exonerated [[death row]] inmate in America.<ref name=ACLU>{{cite news | last1 = | first1 = | title = Anthony Graves: Death Row Exonoree #138 | newspaper = [[ACLU]] | location = | pages = | language = | publisher = | date = | url = https://www.aclu.org/bio/anthony-graves | accessdate = October 14, 2015}}</ref> With no record of violence,<ref name=ACLU /> he was arrested at 26 years old, wrongfully convicted, and incarcerated for 18 years before finally being exonerated and released.<ref name=Chron_October_07_2010>{{cite news | last1 = Rogers | first1 = Brian | last2 = George | first2 = Cindy | title = Texas sets man free from death row | newspaper = [[Houston Chronicle]] | location = | pages = | language = | publisher = | date = October 27, 2010 | url = http://www.chron.com/news/houston-texas/article/Texas-sets-man-free-from-death-row-1619337.php | accessdate = October 14, 2015}}</ref> He was awarded $1.4 million for the time he spent imprisoned,<ref name=ABC13_June_26_2011>{{cite news | last1 = Azad | first1 = Sonia | title = Anthony Graves wins battle for $1.4M in restitution | newspaper = [[KTRK-TV|KRTK-TV/ABC-13 Eyewitness News]] | location = [[Houston, Texas]] | pages = | language = | publisher = | date = June 26, 2011 | url = http://abc13.com/archive/8215647/ | accessdate = October 14, 2015}}</ref> and the prosecutor who put him in prison was ultimately disbarred for concealing exculpatory evidence and using false testimony in the case.<ref name=CBS_June_12_2015>{{cite news | last1 = | first1 = | title = DA disbarred for sending Texas man to death row | newspaper = [[CBS]] | location = | pages = | language = | publisher = | date = June 12, 2015 | url = http://www.cbsnews.com/news/charles-sebasta-prosecutor-of-wrongfully-convicted-man-anthony-graves-loses-law-license/ | accessdate = October 14, 2015}}</ref>
== Biography == Graves grew up in [[Brenham, Texas|Brenham]] and is the oldest among his four other siblings in his family.<ref name=TexasMonthly_October_2010>{{cite news | last1 = | first1 = | title = Innocence Lost | newspaper = [[Texas Monthly]] | location = | pages = | language = | publisher = | date = October 2010 | url = http://www.texasmonthly.com/articles/innocence-lost/ | accessdate = October 14, 2015}}</ref> He is a father with three children.<ref name=ACLU /> He worked at [[Magnetic Instruments]] in Brenham for three years before moving to [[Austin, Texas|Austin]] to work as an assembly line worker at [[Dell]]. In the spring prior to his arrest, Graves lost his job at Dell and returned to Brenham.<ref name=TexasMonthly_October_2010 />
== Conviction == In 1992, Graves was charged with and convicted of murdering a family of six people in [[Somerville, Texas|Somerville]], despite the lack of a motive or any physical evidence connecting Graves to the crime scene. In lieu of physical evidence, the conviction was based upon the testimony of Robert Carter, who later admitted he had committed the crime on his own, and was executed.<ref name=TexasMonthly_October_2010 /> Graves was twice scheduled for execution by lethal injection.<ref name=CBS_2013>{{cite news | last1 = | first1 = | title = Anthony Graves, Texas man wrongfully convicted of murders, gives back to woman who helped set him free | newspaper = [[CBS]] | location = | pages = | language = | publisher = | date = 2013 | url = http://www.texasmonthly.com/articles/innocence-lost/ | accessdate = October 14, 2015}}</ref>
== Imprisonment == Graves was imprisoned at the [[Allan B. Polunsky Unit]]. Following Graves' exoneration and release, he testified at a Senate subcommittee hearing about the conditions of his imprisonment, and following his testimony, [[Mother Jones (magazine)|Mother Jones]] declared the prison to be the second-worst in the United States.<ref name=MotherJones_May_02_2013>{{cite news | last1 = Ridgeway | first1 = James | last2 = Casella | first2 = Jean | title = America's 10 Worst Prisons: Polunsky | newspaper = [[Mother Jones (magazine)|Mother Jones]] | location = | pages = | language = | publisher = | date = May 2, 2013 | url = https://www.motherjones.com/politics/2013/05/10-worst-prisons-america-allan-polunsky-unit-texas-death-row | accessdate = October 14, 2015}}</ref>
== Exoneration == After 12 years on death row, Grave's conviction was overturned by a federal appeals court in 2006, yet he was not released until four years later.<ref name=CBS_June_12_2015 />
== Release == Following approval from district attorney Bill Parham, Graves was released from prison on October 27, 2010.<ref name=Chron_October_07_2010 /> In June 2011, Graves was awarded $1.4 million for the time he spent on death row<ref name=ABC13_June_26_2011 /> under the [[Tim Cole Compensation Act]].<ref name=CBS_March_19_2012>{{cite news | last1 = | first1 = | title = The fight for justice for Anthony Graves | newspaper = [[CBS]] | location = | pages = | language = | publisher = | date = March 19, 2012 | url = http://www.cbsnews.com/news/the-fight-for-justice-for-anthony-graves/ | accessdate = October 14, 2015}}</ref> Following this, the prosecutor who had sent Graves to prison, Charles Sebesta, was disbarred on June 11, 2015, for withholding exculpatory evidence in Grave's case, and for using false testimony to secure the conviction.<ref name=CBS_June_12_2015 />
== Philanthropy == Following his release, Graves founded a scholarship, the Nicole B. Cásarez Endowed Scholarship In Law, in honor of his attorney.<ref name=HuffingtonPost_October_17_2013>{{cite news | last1 = | first1 = | title = Anthony Graves, Former Death Row Inmate, Creates Scholarship In Name Of Attorney Who Saved His Life | newspaper = [[Huffington Post]] | location = | pages = | language = | publisher = | date = October 17, 2013 | url = http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2013/10/17/anthony-graves-scholarship_n_4118176.html | accessdate = October 14, 2015}}</ref>

He continued to play in [[Finland]] for [[TPS (ice hockey)|TPS]] until the [[1997–98 NHL season|1997–98]] season when he joined the Ducks. He was assigned to their [[American Hockey League|minor hockey team]], the [[Cincinnati Mighty Ducks]] for 29 games and played for the Ducks for three games. He continued to play in the NHL until the [[2000–01 NHL season|2000–01]] season. The next season, 2001–02, saw Aalto return to Finland, which is where he continued to play until 2006 when he was forced to retire due to a shoulder injury. == Career statistics == {| border="0" {{Use dmy dates|date=January 2016}} {{Infobox royalty|name=Princess Ashraf |title=Princess of Iran / Persia |image=PrincessAshrafPahlavi2537.jpg |caption= |birth_date={{Birth date|1919|10|26|df=y}} |birth_place=[[Tehran]], [[History of Iran#Pahlavi era (1925–1979)|Persia]] |death_date={{Death date and age|2016|1|7|1919|10|26|df=y}} |death_place=[[Monte Carlo]], [[Monaco]] |spouse={{plain list| *{{marriage|Ali Ghavam|1937|1942|end=div.}} *{{marriage|Ahmad Shafiq|1944|1960|end=div.}} *{{marriage|Mehdi Bushehri|1960|}} }} |issue={{plain list| * Prince Shahram Pahlavi-Nia * Prince [[Shahriar Shafiq]] * Princess [[Azadeh Shafiq]] }} |full name={{lang-en|Ashraf ol-Molouk}}
{{lang-fa|اشرف الملوک}} |house=[[Pahlavi dynasty|Pahlavi]] |father=[[Reza Shah]] |mother=[[Tadj ol-Molouk]] |burial_date=14 January 2016 |burial_place=[[Monaco Cemetery]] }} '''Princess Ashraf ol-Molouk Pahlavi''' ({{lang-fa|اشرف الملوک پهلوی}}, {{transl|fa|''Aŝraf Pahlawi''}}, 26 October 1919 – 7 January 2016) was the twin sister of [[Mohammad Reza Pahlavi]], the last [[Shah]] of [[Iran]] ([[Name of Iran|Persia]]), and a member of the [[Pahlavi Dynasty]]. She was considered the "power behind her brother" and was instrumental in the [[1953 Iranian coup d'état|1953 coup]] which led to him taking the throne.{{cite web |url=https://www.yahoo.com/news/ashraf-pahlavi-twin-sister-last-iran-shah-dead-073606016.html |title=Iranian Princess Ashraf, shah's twin sister, dies at age 96 |website=Yahoo News |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170909143617/https://www.yahoo.com/news/ashraf-pahlavi-twin-sister-last-iran-shah-dead-073606016.html |archive-date=5 February 2017 |dead-url=no |access-date=5 February 2017}} She served her brother as a palace adviser and was a strong advocate for [[Women's rights in Iran|women's rights]].{{Cite news|title=Ashraf Pahlavi, twin sister of Iran's late shah, dies at 96|url= https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/middle_east/ashraf-pahlavi-twin-sister-of-irans-late-shah-dies-at-96/2016/01/08/e5df0e32-b5b7-11e5-9388-466021d971de_story.html|newspaper=The Washington Post|date=8 January 2016|access-date=8 January 2016|issn=0190-8286|language=en-US|author= Brian Murphy}} Following the [[Iranian Revolution]] in 1979, she lived in exile in France, New York, Paris and Monte Carlo and remained outspoken against the Islamic Republic. ==Early life== Ashraf Pahlavi was born in [[Tehran]] on 26 October 1919, five hours after her brother Mohammad Reza. Her parents were [[Reza Shah|Reza Pahlavi]], a military commander, who would become the Shah of Persia, and [[Tadj ol-Molouk]], the second of his four wives. She had 10 siblings and half-siblings. In the early 1930s, Ashraf Pahlavi, her older sister [[Shams Pahlavi|Shams]], and their mother were among the first significant Iranian women to cease wearing [[Hijab|the traditional veil]]. Ashraf Pahlavi [[Iranian gender restrictions in education|was not permitted to attend university]] and instead was married in 1937, at the age of 18, to Mirza Khan Ghavam, whose family was politically allied with her father. ==Politics== [[File:Young Ashraf Pahlavi.jpg|thumb|A young Ashraf Pahlavi]] ===Involvement in 1953 coup against Mossadegh=== {{Main|1953 Iranian coup d'état}} In 1953, Ashraf Pahlavi played an important role in [[1953 Iranian coup d'état|Operation Ajax]] as the one who changed Mohammad Reza Shah's mind in giving consent to the [[CIA]] and [[Secret Intelligence Service|SIS]] to start the operation.{{Cite web|title = Shah of Iran's twin sister dead at 96|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/world/ashraf-pahlavi-obit-1.3394866|work=CBC|accessdate=8 January 2016}} The Shah had originally opposed the operation and for a while resisted accepting it. In early 1953, she met with CIA agents who asked her to talk to her brother since she was the only one who was able to influence him. As historian [[Stephen Kinzer]]'s book ''All the Shah's Men'' recounts, "Ashraf was enjoying life in French casinos and nightclubs when one of [[Kermit Roosevelt Jr.|[Kermit] Roosevelt]]'s best Iranian agents, [[Assadollah Rashidian]], paid her a call. He found her reluctant, so the next day a delegation of American and British agents came to pose the invitation in stronger terms. The leader of the delegation, a senior British operative named Norman Darbyshire, had the foresight to bring a mink coat and a packet of cash. When Ashraf saw these emoluments, Darbyshire later recalled, "her eyes lit up and her resistance crumbled."{{harvp|Kinzer|2003|p=7}} By her own account, Pahlavi was offered a blank check if she agreed to return to Iran from her enforced exile in France, but refused the money and returned of her own accord.'{{harvp|Pahlavi|1980|pp=136–138}} Some historians argue that the coup would have occurred with or without Ashraf Pahlavi's persuasion of her brother. In an ''International Journal of Middle East Studies'' article, writer Mark Gasiorowski states that the Shah "was not consulted about the decision to undertake the coup, about its manner of execution, or about the candidate chosen to replace [[Mohammad Mosaddegh|Mossadegh]]"{{harvp|Gasiorowski|1987}} and that the coup was instead largely executed by the United States and others looking to undermine Mossadegh's leadership. ===Political activities=== [[File:Ashraf-meeting.png|thumb|left|Ashraf Pahlavi heading a meeting]] Ashraf Pahlavi was a strong supporter of [[women's rights in Iran]] and the world during her brother's reign. In 1967, Pahlavi worked with the [[United Nations]] as the Iranian delegate to [[United Nations Commission on Human Rights|the Commission on Human Rights]] as well as [[United Nations Economic and Social Council|the Economic and Social Council]].{{cite journal|author=Kathleen Teltsch|work=The New York Times|title=She may be a Princess, but Shah's Twin is more Interested in Equal Rights|date=22 March 1970}} In 1975, she was heavily involved with the [[International Women's Year]], and addressed the United Nations. Though an instrumental force in legitimizing gender reforms, her philosophy on gender was not particularly introspective: "I confess that even though since childhood I had paid a price for being a woman, in terms of education and personal freedom, I had not given much thought to specific ways in which women in general were more oppressed than men."{{cite book |last=Pahlavi|first=Ashraf |title=Faces in a Mirror: Memoirs from Exile |location=Englewood Cliffs, NJ |oclc=643157789 |ISBN=9780132991315 |publisher=Prentice-Hall |year=1980|page=153}} By her own account, she was a strong supporter of the rights of women to basic life necessities such as "food, education, and health"{{cite journal |last=Pahlavi |first=Ashraf |title=And Thus Passeth International Women's Year|work=The New York Times |date=5 January 1976}} and was not a radical reformist. She cited "chronic apathy" from many governments as the underlying issue that prevented women's rights reforms from being implemented around the world. Ashraf Pahlavi's women's rights stance was called into question after the publication of her 1976 ''[[The New York Times]]'' op-ed piece, "And Thus Passeth International Women's Year." In a March 1976 article in ''[[The Nation]]'', writer [[Kay Boyle]] criticized Ashraf for her touting of International Women's Year as succeeding in widening the global vision of sisterhood, while approximately 4,000 of the Princess's own "sisters" were political prisoners in Iran with virtually no hope of a military trial.{{cite journal |last=Boyle |first=Kay |title=Sisters of the Princess|work=The Nation|date=6 March 1976}} In her 1980 memoirs, Pahlavi acknowledges the poor conditions of women in Iran and expresses concern, as she writes, "the news of what was happening to Iran's women was extremely painful…[they] were segregated and relegated to second-class status…many were imprisoned or exiled."{{harvp|Pahlavi|1980|p=211}} [[File:ShahCarter.gif|thumb|Ashraf along with other imperial family members, at a dinner with US President [[Jimmy Carter]] in [[Niavaran Palace]]]] Additionally, Pahlavi worked as an activist for human rights and equality. She was an advocate for the international spread of literacy, especially in Iran, where her brother Mohammad Reza Shah was a major proponent of the anti-illiteracy movement. She served as a member on the International Consultative Liaison Committee for Literacy. Ashraf Pahlavi was the target of an unsuccessful assassination attempt in the summer of 1977 at her summer home on the [[French Riviera]], during which fourteen bullets were fired into the side of her Rolls Royce automobile. Her [[Lady-in-waiting]] was killed but Pahlavi left the scene unharmed.{{harvp|Pahlavi|1980|p=78}}{{cite news|last=Klemesrud|first=Judy |title=Princess' book defends shah, attacks Carter|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1454&dat=19800423&id=fMksAAAAIBAJ&sjid=RBMEAAAAIBAJ&pg=6548,5038930&hl=fi=vIFDAAAAIBAJ&sjid=jq4MAAAAIBAJ&pg=5677,74054&dq=shah's+mother+died&hl=en|accessdate= |newspaper=Star News|date=23 October 1980|agency=N.Y. Times News Service|location=New York}} After the 1979 revolution, Ashraf Pahlavi asked [[David Rockefeller]] to support her brother Mohammad Reza's attempts to find asylum.{{cite web|last=Boyd|first=Lyn|title=A King's exile|url=http://www.usc.edu/dept/LAS/ir/sirga/ARboyd234.pdf|publisher=USC|accessdate=14 February 2013|year=2000}} She also attacked [[U.S President]] [[Jimmy Carter]] and the [[United Nations Secretary General]] [[Kurt Waldheim]] for not giving their support to her late brother the Shah during the start of the Revolution. In 1994 she attended the funeral of former president [[Richard Nixon]].{{cite web|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/obituaries/princess-ashraf-of-iran-the-shah-of-irans-twin-sister-who-was-regarded-as-the-power-behind-the-a6811176.html|title=Princess Ashraf of Iran: The Shah of Iran's twin sister|author=Jon Gambrell|date=14 January 2016|work=The Independent|accessdate=8 February 2016}} ==Character and finance== [[File:Ashraf et shah.jpg|thumb|Ashraf with her twin brother, [[Mohammad Reza Pahlavi]]]] Ashraf Pahlavi argued that she was "attacked for financial misconduct" because she was engaged "in the administration of various organizations".{{harvp|Pahlavi|1980|p=217}} By her own account, she was of limited financial means when [[Mossadegh]] sent her into exile in Paris.{{harvp|Pahlavi|1980|p=125}} However, in later years she was said to have accumulated a large fortune. She attributed her wealth to increases in the value of lands that she had inherited from her father Reza Shah, and income from inherited businesses. Nevertheless, it has been purported that part of the story behind the build up of her fortune may have been that during the Iranian industrial boom, which was driven by a surge in oil prices, Pahlavi and her son Shahram took 10% or more of a new company's stock gratis in return insuring (sic) the delivery of a license to operate, to import, to export, or to deal with the government. Government licenses were said to be given only to a few well-connected companies in each field. As a result, the need to get and keep a license became a cost that had to be met.{{harvp|Keddie|1981|p=172}}; see also {{harvp|Hoveyda|1979|p=144}} In 1979, ''[[The New York Times]]'' reported that a document dated 17 September 1978 from Ashraf's office requested a transfer of $708,000 from her [[Bank Melli]] account to her account at the [[Union Bank of Switzerland]] in [[Geneva]] under the code name 'Sapia'. In 1980, Pahlavi published an article in ''The New York Times'', in which she came out in defense of herself and her family's financial situation. In the article, she argued that her wealth was not accumulated through "ill-gotten gains" and attributed her fortune to inherited land, which "drastically increased in value with the development of Iran and the new prosperity that was there for all". She noted that many other Iranians profited from the sale of their own real estate, but were not accused of financial misconduct because of close ties to the clergy and Khomeini. She also defended her brother, Mohammad Reza Pahlavi, stating that, contrary to the claims made by some Khomeini supporters, the Shah did not profit from the Pahlavi Foundation. The Princess wrote that she planned to "fight these slanders with all my means and through whatever judicial means are available." Psychologically, Ashraf Pahlavi had low self-esteem when she was younger. She did not like "what she saw in the mirror." She "wished for someone else's face,…, fairer skin, and more height." She always imagined that "there were so few people in this world shorter than I."{{harvp|Pahlavi|1980|p=153}} Perhaps this motivated her to be bold. In her memoirs she wrote: {{quote|Two decades ago French journalists named me "La Panthère Noire" (The Black Panther), I must admit that I rather like this name, and that in some respects it suits me. Like the panther, my nature is turbulent, rebellious, self-confident. Often, it is only through strenuous effort that I maintain my reserve and my composure in public. But in truth, I sometimes wish I were armed with the panther's claws so that I might attack the enemies of my country.{{harvp|Pahlavi|1980|p=xv}}}} Her brother, Mohammad Reza Pahlavi (Mohammad Reza Shah) was her closest friend. In her memoirs, she remembers looking upon him with a sense of wonder as a child, writing, "long before we reached adulthood, his voice became the dominant one in my life."{{harvp|Pahlavi|1980|p=14}} Some sources mention a connection between her and [[drug trafficking]];{{harvp|Fardust|1998|p=121}} she said: "My detractors have accused me of being a smuggler, a spy, a Mafia associate (once even a drug dealer)". ==Notable positions held== *Honorary President of [[Red Lion and Sun Society]], 1944 *Chairwoman of the United Nations Commission on the Status of Women, 1965 *Iranian delegate to the United Nations Commission on Human Rights, 1967 *Iranian delegate to the United Nations Economic and Social Council, 1967 *Chairwoman of the United Nations High Commission for Human Rights, 1970{{cite news|last=Harrelson|first=Max|title=Human rights chairman pursues racial equality|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=lNJNAAAAIBAJ&sjid=YYoDAAAAIBAJ&pg=3261,711832&dq=ashraf+pahlavi's+son&hl=en|accessdate=5 November 2012|newspaper=The Free Lance Star|date=9 March 1970|agency=AP|location=New York}} *Member of the Consultative Committee of International Women's Year Conference, 1975 *President of the Women's Organization Of Iran, 1967–1979 *Chairwoman of the Imperial Foundation for Social Services *Honorary Fellow of [[Wadham College]], Oxford *Member of the International Consultative Liaison Committee for Literacy ==Marriages and children== ===First marriage=== Pahlavi's first marriage was to Mirza 'Ali Muhammed Khan Ghavam, Nasir ud-Daula (1911–?). They were married in March 1937 and divorced in 1942. Ghavam was the Assistant Military Attaché for Iran in 1941 in Washington DC and the eldest son of H.H. Mirza Ibrahim Khan Ghavam, [[Qavam family|Qavam ul-Mulk]]. She had one son from her first marriage, H.H. Prince (Vala Gohar) Shahram Pahlavi-Nia (born 18 April 1940, [[Tehran]]). In 1966 he married 16-year-old Niloufar Afshar, and the couple had one son, Cyrus, in 1969. Pahlavi-Nia had another son, Amir Ebrahim (born 1974) out of wedlock with Naz Alam, a daughter of the Shah's longtime minister of court and confidante, Asadollah Alam. In 1987 Shahram and Naz had an Islamic marriage ceremony in the US Virgin Islands.{{cite web|url=http://www.royalark.net/Persia/pahlavi.htm | title = Iran, The Royal Dynasty |work=Royal Ark |date=13 January 2013 |accessdate=5 February 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160408232955/http://www.royalark.net/Persia/pahlavi.htm |archivedate=8 April 2016 }} ===Second marriage=== [[File:(Ashraf and her husband.jpeg) اشرف پهلوي در كنار همسرش احمد شفيق.jpg|thumb|Ashraf and her spouse, Ahmed Shafiq]] Pavlavi's second marriage was to (Sahib ul-Izza) Ahmed Chafik Bey (21 September 1911 – 1976). He was the director-general of Civil Aviation and fourth son of H.E. (Hazrat Sahib ul-Sa'ada) Ahmad Shafiq Pasha, the minister of the [[Khedive|Khedivial]] Court of Egypt. They married in 1944 in [[Cairo]], and divorced in 1960; he went on to a second marriage to Deloris Pianezzola, and died of cancer in 1976, in Tehran. They had two children, Captain H.H. [[Shahriar Shafiq|Prince (Vala Gohar) Shahriar Mustapha Chafik]] (15 March 1945 – 7 December 1979), assassinated in Paris,{{cite news|title=Bakhtiar escapes assassination attempt|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=HdIdAAAAIBAJ&sjid=BEcEAAAAIBAJ&pg=4832,2531982&dq=shahpour+bakhtiar+assassinated&hl=en|accessdate=4 November 2012|newspaper=Daily News|date=17 July 1980|agency=AP|location=Paris}} and H.H. Princess (Vala Gohari) [[Azadeh Shafiq|Azadeh Pahlavi-Chafik]] (1951–2011).{{cite web|title=Tribute to Princess Azadeh Shafigh Pahlavi (1951-2011)|url=http://www.iranian.com/main/blog/darius-kadivar/irandokht-tribute-princess-azadeh-shafigh-pahlavi-1951-2011|publisher=Iranian|accessdate=18 November 2012}} ===Third marriage=== Pahlavi married a third and final time on 5 June 1960 (at the Iranian Embassy in Paris) to Mehdi Bushehri (1916–?), who was the Director of the Maison d'Iran (House of Iran), Paris. They had no children together, and were often separated while Pahlavi lived in exile in [[New York City]] and Mehdi Bushehri remained in Paris.{{cite news|last=McElwaine|first=Sandra|title=Shah's sister living in a shadow world|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=FRZVAAAAIBAJ&sjid=Rj0NAAAAIBAJ&pg=6057,3092787&dq=shahnaz+pahlavi+married&hl=en|accessdate=7 November 2012|newspaper=The Miami News|date=29 April 1980}} In a 1980 interview with ''The New York Times'' journalist [[Judy Klemesrud]], Pahlavi stated, "I have never been a good mother. Because of my way of life, I was not with my children very much". ==Exile and death== [[File:Ashraf Pahlavı.jpg|thumb|Ashraf in 1970s]] After the Revolution Princess Ashraf divided her time between [[Beekman Place]]https://www.mansionglobal.com/articles/77884-an-eight-story-manhattan-mansion-with-a-history-of-famous-residents which she sold before moving to [[Park Avenue]] in [[New York City]], [[Paris]] and in [[Juan-les-Pins]], on the [[French Riviera]]. Princess Ashraf Pahlavi died on 7 January 2016 in [[Monte Carlo]] at the age of 96. She had suffered from [[Alzheimer's disease]].{{cite web|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/wires/afp/article-3391409/Ashraf-Pahlavi-twin-sister-Iran-shah-dead-96.html|title=Ashraf Pahlavi, twin sister of Iran's last shah, dead at 96|date=9 January 2016|work=Mail Online|accessdate=8 February 2016}} Her death was announced by her nephew and the imperial family's head, [[Reza Pahlavi, Crown Prince of Iran|Reza Pahlavi]] on his Facebook page. Robert F. Armao, an adviser, said the cause was "old age". Armao related that Princess Ashraf died in her sleep at home in [[Europe]], but declined to name the country, citing concern for the safety of her family.{{Cite news|title=Ashraf Pahlavi, Sister of Iran's Last Shah, Dies at 96|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/01/08/world/middleeast/ashraf-pahlavi-sister-of-irans-last-shah-defender-and-diplomat-dies-at-96.html|newspaper=The New York Times|date=8 January 2016|access-date=8 January 2016|issn=0362-4331|author=Liam Stack}} Her funeral took place on 14 January 2016 in the [[Monaco Cemetery|Cimetière de Monaco]] in [[Monaco]], attended by members of the Pahlavi family, including Empress [[Farah Pahlavi]].{{Cite news|title=Obsèques d'Ashraf Pahlavi: Farah Diba en deuil, adieu discret à la soeur du Shah|url=http://www.purepeople.com/article/obseques-d-ashraf-pahlavi-farah-diba-en-deuil-adieu-discret-a-la-soeur-du-shah_a171130/1|newspaper=Pure People|date=19 January 2016|access-date= |issn= |author=}} {{fr}} At the time of her death, she was the oldest living member of her family. ==Books== Ashraf Pahlavi wrote two books in English: *'' Faces in a Mirror: Memoirs from Exile'' (1980) * ''Time for Truth'' (1995) Additionally, she wrote one book in French: *''Jamais Résignée'' (1981) Her three books were published following her 1980 ''The New York Times'' article "I Will Fight These Slanders". In accordance with her promise to fight the "slanders" about her and her family, her books are largely concerned with clearing up what she viewed as misconceptions about the Pahlavi dynasty. She again addresses the questions about her personal financial situation, writing in her most widely read book, her memoir ''Faces in a Mirror'', "I had inherited about $300,000 when my father died (and about 1 million square meters of land near the Caspian Sea, as well as properties in Gorgan and Kermanshah, which would later become extremely valuable)" In the introduction to this book, Pahlavi writes that she wants "very much to explain to Western readers what they have failed to understand about the nature of Iran's culture and heritage…about the nature of the so-called [[Islamic revolution]]", Generally, her books are viewed as too autobiographical and steeped in emotion to be used as serious historical references: ''[[The Library Journal]]'' called Pahlavi's ''Faces in a Mirror'', "little more than a personalized homily on the Pahlavis' virtues and the perfidy of nearly everyone else in the world."Snider, Dave. "''Faces in a Mirror'' (Book Review)". revision.text:
{{Infobox Coat of arms |name = Coat of Arms of the Prince of Wales |image = Coat of Arms of Charles, Prince of Wales.svg |image_width = 270 |middle = Arms of Charles, Prince of Wales.svg |middle_width = 100 |middle_caption = Escutcheon of the [[Prince of Wales]] |armiger = [[Charles, Prince of Wales]] |year_adopted = 1958 |crest = A golden lion difference with a white [[Label (heraldry)|label]] of three points, crowned with the [[Coronet]] of the [[Heir apparent]] and standing on the same coronet; gold and ermine mantling.{{cite web |url=https://www.princeofwales.gov.uk/titles-and-heraldry#chapter-wrapper-2 |title=Titles and Heraldry: Coat of Arms |accessdate=2018-08-10 |work=Official website of the Prince of Wales}} |shield = The [[Royal coat of arms of the United Kingdom|Royal Arms]] difference with a white label of three points; with an inescutcheon of four lions passant guardant, in gold and red, counterchanged (for the [[Principality of Wales]]). |supporters = A golden lion, wearing the coronet of the Heir apparent, and a silver unicorn, both difference with a white label of three points. |motto = {{lang-de|[[Ich dien]]}} |orders = [[Order of the Garter]] |other_elements = [[Heraldic badge|Badges]]: [[Prince of Wales's feathers]], [[Welsh dragon]] with a white label of three points and crowned escutcheon of the [[Duchy of Cornwall]]. |earlier_versions = |use = }} The '''coat of arms of the Prince of Wales''' is the official [[Heraldry|heraldic]] insignia of the [[Prince of Wales]], a title traditionally granted to the [[heir apparent]] to the [[Monarchy of the United Kingdom|reigning monarch]] of the [[United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland]], formerly the [[Kingdom of Great Britain]] and before that the [[Kingdom of England]]. The [[coat of arms]], in its current form, was devised for [[Charles, Prince of Wales]] in 1958. It contains the badges and elements taken from all four of the [[Countries of the United Kingdom|constituent countries of the United Kingdom]] as well as from the many [[List of titles and honours of Charles, Prince of Wales|titles the prince holds]] as [[heir apparent]]. The history of the coat of arms is closely linked with that of the [[Royal Arms of England|Royal coat of arms of England]] and the [[Royal coat of arms of the United Kingdom]]. However, as the noted antiquarian and heraldist [[Charles Boutell]] wrote in 1863, "The Arms of the Prince of Wales have a distinct individuality of their own, with which nothing ought to be directly associated."Boutell p. 256 ==Elements== ====Coronet==== [[File:Ströhl-Regentenkronen-Fig. 31.png|thumb|130px|left|The British heir-apparent's coronet as depicted by [[Hugo Gerard Ströhl]]]] The [[Coronet|coronets of the Prince and the Peers]] of the realm were regulated by King [[Charles II of England|Charles II]] by Royal Warrant, signed on 9 February 1661. Part of the warrant proclaimed: "Our Will and Pleasure therefore is, That the Son and Heir Apparent of the Crown for the time being, shall use and bear his Coronet composed of Crosses and [[Fleur-de-lis|Flower-de-Lized]] with one Arch; and in the midst a [[Globus cruciger|Ball and Cross]], as hath our Royal Diadem".{{cite web |url=http://www.heraldica.org/topics/britain/prince_highness_docs.htm#The_Warrant_of_1661 |title=Warrant of Feb 9, 1661|accessdate=2018-08-10 |work=www.heraldica.org}} In other words, the heraldic coronet used in the Prince of Wales's coat of arms is similar to the [[Crown (heraldry)|heraldic crown]] ([[St. Edward's crown]]) used in the Royal arms, except that instead of two intersecting arches it has only one. Boutell wrote that: "It should be noticed, however, that this coronet belongs to the prince as eldest son of the Sovereign and heir-apparent to the Throne, and not as Prince of Wales". The coronet is also used by the Prince of Wales's consort, in her coat of arms.Boutell p. 363 The heir's coronet was confirmed in another Royal Warrant signed on 19 November 1917 by King [[George V of the United Kingdom|George V]]. The warrant proclaimed: "by the son and heir apparent of the sovereign and his successors a coronet composed of crosses and fleurs-de-lis with one arch and in the midst a ball and cross as in the royal crown."{{cite web |url=http://www.heraldica.org/topics/britain/prince_highness_docs.htm#Warrant_of_Nov_19_1917 |title=Warrant of Nov 19, 1917|accessdate=2018-08-10 |work=www.heraldica.org}} Currently there are three physical examples of coronets used at one time or other as part of the [[Honours of the Principality of Wales]]; the [[Coronet of Frederick, Prince of Wales|Coronet of Frederick]], the [[Coronet of George, Prince of Wales|Coronet of George]] and the [[Coronet of Charles, Prince of Wales|Coronet of Charles]]. However these physical manifestations have not affected the graphical representation of the coronet in heraldic art.{{Cite web |url=https://www.royal.uk/honours-principality-wales |title=Honours of the Principality of Wales |website=www.royal.uk |access-date=2018-10-15}} ====Label==== Beginning with the reign of King [[Edward I of England|Edward I]], a [[Label (heraldry)|label]] of three points [[Azure (heraldry)|Azure]] (or blue) was used by his son, the future King [[Edward II of England|Edward II]], to differentiate his arms from those of his father. Without such a label their arms would be identical. Within [[heraldry]] this system of differentiating arms is called [[cadency]]. The label is placed on the [[Chief (heraldry)|chief]] (or top) of the [[shield]] of arms, with the ends extending across from the dexter to the sinister sides of the shield. It was Prince [[Edward the Black Prince]], heir of King [[Edward III of England|Edward III]], who first used a label of three points [[Argent]], also white or silver. This has been the label of the heir apparent ever since, without regard to the system of [[Cadency labels of the British royal family|cadency used by other members]] of the royal family.Boutell p. 187 ====Crest==== [[File:Prince of Wales 1914.png|thumb|200px|right|Coat of arms of [[Edward VIII of the United Kingdom|Edward, Prince of Wales]] as illustrated in [[Burke's Peerage]] 1914 edition.]] The Prince of Wales's [[Crest (heraldry)|crest]] follows closely that of the Sovereign, but always with the appropriate label of [[Cadency|difference]] displayed. This crest depicts a "Lion [[Or (heraldry)|Or]], passant guardant, wearing a coronet of the Heir, and differenced on the shoulders with a label of three points Argent." The lion always stands on a larger coronet of the Heir, which then sits on a golden [[Helmet (heraldry)|helmet]] or the Royal Helm. From the sides flow the gold and [[Ermine (heraldry)|ermine]] [[mantling]] of the royal family. ====Supporters==== Similarly to the crest, the prince's [[supporter]]s follow those of the Sovereign. On either side of the shield of arms and standing on gold scrollwork are the royal supporters: the [[Lion and the Unicorn]]. Both beasts have the prince's label charged around their necks, again as an appropriate mark of difference. The [[Lion (heraldry)|lion]] on the [[Dexter and sinister|dexter side]], an [[National symbols of England|ancient symbol of England]], is crowned with the coronet of the Heir. The beast has been a [[Royal Supporters of England|supporter of the English royal arms]] since the reign of King [[Henry VIII of England|Henry VIII]]. The white [[Unicorn#Heraldry|unicorn]] of [[Scotland]] on the [[Dexter and sinister|sinister side]], was incorporated into the royal arms from the [[Royal coat of arms of Scotland|Scottish royal arms]] after the Union of the crowns in 1603. ====Order==== Prince Charles was appointed a [[List of current members of the Order of the Garter|Knight of the Garter]] in 1958. Since the founding of the Order in 1348, almost every Prince of Wales has been appointed to the Order.Boutell p. 265 The [[Order of the Garter]] is represented in the coat of arms by its namesake the blue buckled [[Garter (stockings)|garter]], which bears in gold letters the motto, ''[[Honi soit qui mal y pense]]'', [[French language|French]] for "Shame upon him who thinks evil of it". ====Motto==== Under the coat of arms is a scroll bearing the [[motto]] ''[[Ich dien]]'', German for "I serve". The motto of uncertain origin first appeared on the arms of [[Edward, the Black Prince|Edward of Woodstock]], or the Black Prince. Prince Edward was created Prince of Wales by his father King [[Edward III of England|Edward III]] on 12 May 1343. Legend holds that the Black Prince took the motto as well as the ostrich feathers from King [[John of Bohemia|John the Blind of Bohemia]], who was killed fighting alongside the prince and his father at the [[Battle of Crécy]] in 1346. The motto is also a near [[homophone]] for ''Eich Dyn'', "Your Man" in [[Welsh language|Welsh]].Scott-Giles p. 75 ===Badges=== {| style="float:right; width:170px; border:solid #ccc 1px; margin:5px;" |- align="center" |[[File:Prince of Wales's feathers Badge.svg|150px]] |- align="center" |The [[Prince of Wales's feathers]] badge |- align="center" |[[File:Prince of Wales' Red Dragon.svg|150px]] |- align="center" |The [[Welsh Dragon|Welsh red dragon]] badge with a white label of three points |- align="center" |[[File:Arms of the Duchy of Cornwall.svg|90px]] |- align="center" |The arms of [[Cornwall]] with coronet |} The Prince of Wales as part of his full achievement of arms has many [[Heraldic badge]]s, which represents the history and sovereignty of his many titles. ====Prince of Wales' feathers==== {{Main|Prince of Wales's feathers}} The Prince of Wales's feathers badge comprises "A plume of three [[ostrich]] feathers Argent enfiled by a royal coronet of alternate crosses and fleur-de-lys Or" with the motto 'Ich Dien' on a dark blue ribbon. The badge is probably the most recognisable element of the Prince of Wales's coat of arms. It has become synonymous as a personal insignia of the prince and also of the [[Principality of Wales]] itself.{{cite web |url=https://www.princeofwales.gov.uk/titles-and-heraldry|title=Titles and Heraldry: Prince of Wales's Feathers |accessdate=2018-08-10 |work=Official website of the Prince of Wales}} In a personal capacity the badge is granted as a [[Royal Warrant of Appointment (United Kingdom)|Royal Warrant of Appointment]] to companies that regularly supply of goods and services to the Prince. Currently there are 170 companies which are entitled to display this badge with the words 'By Appointment to HRH The Prince of Wales' underneath. The badge can be depicted on all premises, delivery vehicles, stationery and advertisements as well as on the individual products themselves.{{cite web |url=https://www.princeofwales.gov.uk/titles-and-heraldry |title=Titles and Heraldry: Royal Warrants |accessdate=2018-08-10 |work=Official website of the Prince of Wales}} Other organisations associated with Wales or the prince incorporate the badge into their own insignia including many Welsh regiments of the [[British Army]] (such as the [[Royal Regiment of Wales]]) and the [[Welsh Rugby Union]].Scott-Giles p. 18 Feathers used as either a crest or a badge have been an [[Royal badges of England|ancient heraldic badge]] of the [[House of Plantagenet]]. However it was not until its incorporation into the heraldic achievements of the Black Prince that the feathers have become an omnipresent feature of the coats of arms of the Prince of Wales.Scott-Giles pp. 89–93 ====Red Dragon of Wales==== {{Main|Royal Badge of Wales}} On 10 December 1901 a warrant signed by King [[Edward VII]] approved the addition of a badge of the [[Welsh Dragon|Red Dragon]] to the coat of arms of the Prince of Wales. The proclamation stated that: "on the sinister side a representation of the [[Royal badge of Wales|Badge of Wales]], namely, on a mount vert a Dragon, passant [[gules]], differenced (as in the Crest) with a label of three points argent." This was to complement the feathers badge, which was to be depicted on the dexter side of the prince's crest.{{LondonGazette|issue=27385 |date=10 December 1901 |page=8714 }} The Red Dragon, or ''Y Ddraig Goch'', has been a symbol associated with Wales since the time of [[Cadwaladr]], [[Kingdom of Gwynedd|King of Gwynedd]] in the 7th century. It was not until the beginning of the [[House of Tudor]] that the Red Dragon became a royal badge of the kings of England. Henry Tudor (later King [[Henry VII of England|Henry VII]]) displayed the Dragon of Cadwaladr on his [[Royal standards of England|battle standard]].{{Cite web |url=https://www.flaginstitute.org/pdfs/Robin%20Ashburner.pdf |title=Flags in Wales |last=Ashburner |first=Robin |date=2001 |website=flaginstitute.org |access-date=2018-10-15}} The red dragon became an official royal badge of the sovereign (representing Wales) according to a warrant issued in 1801. The warrant at the same time also confirmed the [[Tudor rose]] as a royal badge for England, the [[thistle]] for Scotland and the [[Celtic harp|golden harp]] for Ireland.Pinces & Pinces p. 216 ====Arms of the Duchy of Cornwall==== {{Main|Duke of Cornwall}} The arms of the Duke of Cornwall are: "[[Sable (heraldry)|Sable]], fifteen [[bezant]]s, five, four, three, two and one." These arms were derived from those of [[Richard, 1st Earl of Cornwall]], [[King of the Romans]], son and heir of King [[John, King of England|John]], who was also [[Count of Poitiers]] (or [[Poitou]]), represented by arms made up of [[pea]]s (poix) or [[gold coin]]s.{{cite book |last=Fox-Davis |first=Arthur Charles|authorlink=Arthur Charles Fox-Davies |title=The Book Of Public Arms. A Complete Encyclopaedia Of All Royal, Territorial, Municipal, Corporate, Official, And Impersonal Arms |url=https://archive.org/details/bookofpublicarms00foxd/page/210 |year=1915 |publisher=T. C. & E. C. Jack |location=London |asin=B00TT2UM5S |pages=210}}Scott-Giles p. 70 Upon the accession of the prince's mother as Queen [[Elizabeth II]] on 6 February 1952, Prince Charles was automatically made the [[Duke of Cornwall]]. As such he is able to display the arms of the duchy on his coat of arms.{{cite book |last=Burke's Peerage|first= |authorlink=Burke's Peerage |title=Burke's guide to the Royal Family (Burke's genealogical series)|url=https://archive.org/details/burkesguidetoroy00lond/page/136 |year=1973 |publisher=Burke's Peerage; 1st edition |location=London |isbn=0220662223|pages=137}} This title has been granted to every heir apparent since 17 March 1337, in accordance with a charter issued by King [[Edward III of England|Edward III]] for Prince [[Edward the Black Prince]], his eldest son and heir.{{cite book |last=Burke's Peerage|first= |authorlink=Burke's Peerage |title=Burke's genealogical and heraldic history of peerage, baronetage and knightage |url=https://archive.org/details/bub_gb_Pf8cAAAAYAAJ/page/n213 |year=1914 |publisher=Burke's Peerage |location=London |isbn=|pages=16}} ==Escutcheon== ===Independent Prince=== {| width = "100%" border = 1 border="1" cellpadding="4" cellspacing="0" style="margin: 0.5em 1em 0.5em 0; background: #f9f9f9; border: 1px #aaa solid; border-collapse: collapse;" |- !width = "14%"|Arms !width = "10%"|Dates !width = "26%"|Princes !width = "50%"|Information |- |
[[File:Arms of Llywelyn.svg|100px]]
||c.1240 – 1282|| * [[Dafydd ap Llywelyn]] * [[Llywelyn the Last|Llywelyn ap Gruffydd]] the Last ||The arms of Gwynedd or Llywelyn ap Gruffydd were the arms of the princes of North Wales; the arms are blazoned as: ''"[[Quartering (heraldry)|Quarterly]] Or and Gules, four lions passant guardant counterchanged."''Pinces & Pinces p. 273 |- |
[[File:Arms of Dafydd ap Gruffydd.svg|100px]]
||c.1282 – 1283|| * [[Dafydd ap Gruffydd]] ||The arms of Dafydd ap Gruffydd were the arms of the last independent prince of Wales, before his execution at the hands of King [[Edward I of England]] in 1283. His arms are the same as those of Llywelyn, but with Azure replacing Gules.Pinces & Pinces p. 173{{Cite web |url=https://www.dailypost.co.uk/news/north-wales-news/dafydd-ap-gruffydds-outlawed-lions-2759658 |title=Dafydd ap Gruffydd’s outlawed lions return on coat of arms |date=2018-03-01 |website=North Wales Daily Post |access-date=2018-10-16}} |- |
[[File:Arms of Owain Glyndŵr.svg|100px]]
||1404 – c.1415|| * [[Owain Glyndŵr]] ||The arms of Owain Glyndŵr were supposedly based on those of the houses of [[House of Dinefwr|Dinefwr]] and [[House of Mathrafal|Mathrafal]]. Blazoned as: ''"Quarterly or and gules, four lions rampant armed and langued azure counterchanged."'' Glyndŵr unsuccessfully led the [[Glyndŵr Rising]] for Welsh independence that was crushed in 1415 during the reign of King [[Henry V of England|Henry V]].Scott-Giles p. 74 |- |} ===Heir Apparent=== {| width = "100%" border = 1 border="1" cellpadding="4" cellspacing="0" style="margin: 0.5em 1em 0.5em 0; background: #f9f9f9; border: 1px #aaa solid; border-collapse: collapse;" |- !width = "14%"|Arms !width = "10%"|Dates !width = "26%"|Princes (later as King) !width = "50%"|Information |- |
[[File:Arms_of_Edward,_Prince_of_Wales_(1301-1307).svg|100px]]
||1303 – 1307|| * Edward of Caernarfon ([[Edward II of England]]) ||{{cquote|E portroit, o un bleu label
Les armes le bon roi son pere.
Or li doint Dieus grace ke il pere
Ausi vaillans, e non pas meins; }} Translated as: "Arms he bore of the good King his father, with a label azure. May God grant him grace and courage to his royal father’s measure!" The quote is from a contemporary poem of the siege of [[Caerlaverock Castle|Caerlaverock]] in 1300.{{cite web |url=https://www.theheraldrysociety.com/articles/the-siege-of-caerlaverock/ |title=The Siege of Caerlaverock |accessdate=2018-10-09 |work=The Heraldry Society}}{{cite book |last=Wright|first=Thomas |authorlink=Thomas Wright (antiquarian) |title=The Roll of Arms of the Princes, Barons, and Knights who Attended King Edward I to the Siege of Caerlaverock, in 1300 |url=https://archive.org/details/rollofarmsofprin00wrigrich/ |year=1864 |publisher=J.C. Hotten |location=Londone |isbn=0-900455-25-X|pages=18}} The poem refers to Prince Edward (the future of Edward II), who was born in 1284 at [[Caernarfon Castle]] and was then presented to the Welsh chiefs by his father King [[Edward I of England|Edward I]] as their Prince. However it was not until seventeen years later that he was presented with the title of Prince of Wales. His arms depicted the arms of the [[Kingdom of England]] with a label of three points Azure.Pinces & Pinces p. 48Boutell p. 191 |- |
[[File:Arms of the Prince of Wales (Ancient).svg|100px]]
||1343 – 1377|| * [[Edward, the Black Prince|Edward of Woodstock]], the Black Prince * Richard of Bordeaux ([[Richard II of England]]) ||[[File:Arms of the Prince of Wales (Shield of Peace).svg|100px|right|thumb|Shield of Peace]] Edward, the Black Prince's arms were: ''"Quarterly France ancien'' (reflecting King [[Edward III of England|Edward III]]'s [[English claims to the French throne|claim to the French throne]]) ''and England with a label of three points Argent"''. This shield is often called his 'Shield for War'; additionally a scroll with the [[French language|French]] word ''Houmont'' (or Magnanimous) appears above the shield. On his tomb however an additional shield of arms was also displayed, the 'Shield for Peace': ''"Sable, three ostrich feathers, their quils passing through escrolls Argent bearing the words 'Ich Dien'"''; the same motto also appears above the shield in another scroll.Brooke-Little p.77 The future Richard II was granted the shield for war as his arms when he was created Prince of Wales, a few months after the death of his father in 1376.Pinces & Pinces p. 61 |- |
[[File:Arms of the Prince of Wales (Modern).svg|100px]]
||1399 – 1509|| * Henry of Monmouth ([[Henry V of England]]) * [[Edward of Westminster]] * Edward of the Sanctuary ([[Edward V of England]]) * [[Edward of Middleham, Prince of Wales|Edward of Middleham]] * [[Arthur, Prince of Wales|Arthur Tudor]] * Henry Tudor, Duke of York ([[Henry VIII of England]]) ||Mirroring the changes in the Royal arms, as brought about by King [[Henry IV of England|Henry IV]], who changed the 1st and 4th quarter from [[National Emblem of France|France ancien to France moderne]]. This version was first granted to the future Henry V.Pinces & Pinces p. 94 The arms were then used by various Princes of Wales from both the [[House of Lancaster|Houses of Lancaster]] (Edward of Westminster) and [[House of York|York]] (the future Edward V and Edward of Middleham).Pinces & Pinces p. 124 The arms remained unchanged during the [[House of Tudor|Tudor dynasty]] when the title was granted to Arthur Tudor in 1489. With his death in 1502, the arms were re-granted to his brother, the future Henry VIII, in 1504.Pinces & Pinces p. 139 |- |
[[File:Arms of the Stuart Princes of Wales (1610-1688).svg|100px]]
||1610 – 1688|| * [[Henry Frederick, Prince of Wales|Henry Frederick Stuart]] * Charles Stuart, Duke of York ([[Charles I of England]]) * Charles Stuart ([[Charles II of England]]) * ''James Stuart, Duke of York ([[James II of England]])'' * [[James Francis Edward Stuart]] ||The [[House of Stuart|Stuart succession]] brought major changes to arms by incorporating elements of the arms of Scotland and Ireland in the 2nd and 3rd quarters respectively. The arms were first granted to Henry Stuart, the Duke of Rothesay after his father [[James I of England|James VI]] ascended the throne of England as James I. The arms were then granted twice more to the future Charles I and Charles II. It has been reported that James, the Duke of York (future James II) also bore the arms (despite not holding the title Prince of Wales), but only when his position as heir-presumptive to his brother became secure after the [[Exclusion Bill|Exclusion crisis]]. The arms were once more granted to James Francis Edward, who after 1688 became the [[Jacobitism|Jacobite Pretender]], whose son [[Charles Edward Stuart|Charles Edward]] (Bonnie Prince Charlie) continued the use of the arms in exile.Pinces & Pinces pp. 170-189 |- |
[[File:Arms of the Hanoverian Princes of Wales (1714-1760).svg|100px]]
||1714 – 1801|| * George Augustus ([[George II of Great Britain]]) * [[Frederick, Prince of Wales|Frederick Louis]] * George William Frederick
([[George III of the United Kingdom]]) * George Augustus Frederick
([[George IV of the United Kingdom]]) ||[[File:Royal Hanover Inescutcheon.svg|100px|right|thumb|Arms of Hanover with the crown of Charlemagne]] The [[House of Hanover]] inherited the throne of Great Britain after the death of Queen [[Anne, Queen of Great Britain|Anne]] in 1714, which led to the incorporation of the arms of King George I's possessions in [[Germany]] into the Royal arms. The blazon for the arms became: ''"1st quarter England impaling Scotland, 2nd France moderne, 3rd Ireland and 4th the [[Electorate of Brunswick-Lüneburg|Electorate of Hanover]], with a label of three points Argent. The Hanoverian quarter depicted: [[Duchy of Brunswick|Brunswick]], [[Lüneburg]], [[Duchy of Westphalia|Westphalia]] and an inescutcheon plain Gules, over all three."'' In the Royal arms the inescutcheon contained a depiction of the [[Crown of Charlemagne]], which was an [[augmentation of honour]] granted to the [[Prince-elector]]s of Hanover as [[Arch-Treasurer]] to the [[Holy Roman Emperor]]. As heir to this Imperial office, only the Prince of Wales was entitled to bear the empty inescutcheon, in right of inheritance of this imperial office.Pinces & Pinces pp. 206-229 |- |
[[File:Arms of George, Prince of Wales and Prince Regent (1762-1820).svg|100px]]
||1801 – 1820|| * George Augustus Frederick
(George IV of the United Kingdom) ||With the [[Acts of Union 1800|Act of Union of 1800]], the arms of the Prince of Wales changed with those of the Kingdom. The ancient claim to France was abandoned, and England occupied the 1st and 4th quarter, while the Hanoverian quarter became an inescutcheon at the centre of the shield. This shield of arms was granted only once to George Augustus Frederick (the future George IV), who also became [[Prince regent]] in 1811.Pinces & Pinces p. 229 |- |
[[File:Arms of the Prince of Wales (1841-1910).svg|100px]]
||1841 – 1910|| * Albert Edward
([[Edward VII of the United Kingdom]]) * George, Duke of York
([[George V of the United Kingdom]]) ||The Royal arms were once again altered following the ascension of Queen [[Queen Victoria|Victoria]] to the throne in 1837, when the Hanoverian shield was dropped. The Hanoverian inescutcheon was replaced by the [[Coat of arms of Saxony|arms of Saxony]], which was a heraldic inheritance from the queen's husband Prince [[Albert, Prince Consort|Albert of Saxe-Coburg and Gotha]] (a Duke of Saxony).Aveling p. 287Pinces & Pinces p. 259 The inescutcheon only appeared in the arms of Albert's male-line descendants, and not in the Royal arms itself. According to the antiquarian Charles Boutell, the inescutcheon was placed as an "escutcheon of pretence", that "does not appear to be in accordance with either the spirit or the practical usage of true historical Heraldry". These arms were granted twice, first to 'Bertie' (later King Edward VII) and to the future George V. In his 1909 book ''A Complete Guide to Heraldry,'' [[Arthur Charles Fox-Davies]] writes: "It is much to be regretted that the arms of H.R.H. the Prince of Wales (the future George V) do not include the arms of his sovereignty of the Duchy of Cornwall, nor any allusion to his dignities of Prince of Wales or [[Earl of Chester]]."Fox-Davies (1909) p. 486Pinces & Pinces p. 265 |- |
[[File:Arms of Charles, Prince of Wales.svg|100px]]
||1911 – present|| * Edward Albert
([[Edward VIII of the United Kingdom]]) * Charles, Prince of Wales
(''incumbent'') ||In 1910 Prince Edward Albert was invested and presented to the Welsh people as Prince of Wales at Caernarfon Castle, the first time in six hundred years. Welsh local authorities had asked that the red dragon might be introduced into the Royal arms and the coinage, but neither of these wishes were granted. However a year later in 1911, King George V issued an [[order in council]] that replaced the inescutcheon of Saxony, in the Arms of the Prince of Wales, with an inescutcheon with the arms "representing the Principality of Wales". Blazoned as: ''"Quarterly Or and Gules four lions passant guardant counterchanged, ensigned by the Coronet of His degree."''{{LondonGazette|issue=28473 |date=7 March 1911 |page=1939 }}Pinces & Pinces p. 273 In 1958 Prince Charles, the Duke of Cornwall, son of Queen [[Elizabeth II]] was granted the same arms when he was made Prince of Wales.Pinces & Pinces p. 280 |- |} ==Family== ===Consorts=== The family of the Prince of Wales is entitled to use certain heraldic features. The consort of the Prince of Wales (titled the [[Princess of Wales]]) is granted a unique coat of arms upon marriage, based on the [[Impalement (heraldry)|impaling]] of the prince's arms (on the dexter side) and her father's arms (on the sinister side). The consort is also entitled to use the prince's supporters (with the appropriate label) and the use of the prince's coronet over the arms. The current consort; [[Camilla, Duchess of Cornwall|Camilla]], the [[Duchess of Cornwall]], was granted a coat of arms on 17 July 2005 upon her marriage to Charles, Prince of Wales.{{cite web |url=https://www.princeofwales.gov.uk/biographies/hrh-duchess-cornwall |title=HRH The Duchess of Cornwall: Titles and Heraldry |accessdate=2018-10-09 |work=Official website of the Prince of Wales}}

[[Image:Davenport brothers.jpg|thumb|350px|This 1870 photograph shows the brothers and William Fay in front of the "spirit cabinet".]] [[File:Davenport brothers sketch.png|thumb|Davenport brothers]] '''Ira Erastus Davenport''' (September 17, 1839 – July 8, 1911){{cite book | title=The Encyclopedia of Ghosts and Spirits | author=Guiley, Rosemary Ellen | authorlink=Rosemary Ellen Guiley | year=1992 | publisher=[[Facts On File]] | location=New York | isbn=0-8160-2140-6 | pages=81–83 }} and '''William Henry Davenport''' (February 1, 1841 – July 1, 1877), known as the '''Davenport brothers''', were [[Americans|American]] [[Magic (illusion)|magicians]] in the late 19th century, sons of a [[Buffalo, New York|Buffalo]], [[New York (state)|New York]] [[police]]man. The brothers presented illusions that they and others claimed to be [[supernatural]]. ==Career== The Davenports began in 1854, less than a decade after [[Spiritualism (religious movement)|Spiritualism]] had taken off in America. After stories of the [[Fox sisters]], the Davenports started reporting similar occurrences. Their father took up managing his sons and the group was joined by William Fay, a Buffalo resident with an interest in conjuring. Their shows were introduced by a former "[[Restoration Movement]]" [[religious minister|minister]], Dr. [[Jesse Babcock Ferguson|J. B. Ferguson]], a follower of Spiritualism, who assured the audience that the brothers worked by spirit power rather than deceptive trickery. Ferguson was apparently sincere in his belief that the Davenports possessed spiritual powers. The Davenports' most famous effect was the box illusion. The brothers were tied inside a box which contained [[musical instruments]]. Once the box was closed, the instruments would sound. Upon opening the box, the brothers were tied in the positions in which they had started the illusion. Those who witnessed the effect were made to believe supernatural forces had caused the trick to work. The Davenports toured the United States for 10 years and then traveled to [[England]] where spiritualism was beginning to become popular. Their "spirit cabinet" was investigated by [[the Ghost Club]], who were challenging their claim of being able to contact the dead.{{cite web|url=http://www.prairieghosts.com/ghostclub.html |title=The Ghost Club |publisher=Prairieghosts.com |date= |accessdate=2014-07-25}} The result of the Ghost Club's investigation was never made public. In 1868 the team was joined by [[Harry Kellar]]. Kellar and Fay eventually would leave the group to pursue their own career as a magician team. ==Exposures== The Davenport brothers were exposed as frauds many times.[[Milbourne Christopher|Christopher, Milbourne]]. (1990 edition, originally published in 1962). ''Magic: A Picture History''. [[Dover Publications]]. p. 99. {{ISBN|0-486-26373-8}} "The Davenports were exposed many times, not only by magicians but by scientists and college students. The latter ignited matches in the dark. The flickering flames disclosed the brothers, with their arms free, waving the instruments which until then had seemed to be floating. The exposures had little effect on that segment of the public which chose to believe the manifestations were genuine. They closed their minds to the truth and sat in awe, sure that spirits had been conjured up in their presence." The stage magician [[John Nevil Maskelyne]] saw how the Davenports' spirit cabinet illusion worked, and stated to the audience in the theatre that he could recreate their act using no supernatural methods. With the help of a friend, cabinet maker George Alfred Cooke, he built a version of the cabinet. Together, they revealed the Davenport Brothers' trickery to the public at a show in Cheltenham in June 1865.{{cite book | author=Steinmeyer, Jim | authorlink=Jim Steinmeyer | title=Hiding the Elephant | publisher=Arrow | year=2005 | isbn=0-09-947664-9 | pages=95–96}} Magicians including [[John Henry Anderson]] and [[Jean Eugène Robert-Houdin]] worked to expose the Davenport Brothers, writing exposés and performing duplicate effects. A pair of amateur magicians followed the brothers around [[Great Britain|Britain]], tying the Davenports into their box with a [[knot]] that could not be easily removed and thus exposed the trick to audiences who demanded their money back. The impresario [[P. T. Barnum]] included an exposé of the Davenports in his 1865 book ''The Humbugs of the World''. [[File:Davenport brothers cabinet sketch.png|thumb|left|Davenport brothers cabinet.]] The Davenports were rejoined by William Fay for a final American tour before William Henry's death in 1877. Fay settled in [[Australia]] and Ira Erastus lived in America until the two reunited in 1895 and toured with a show that failed. The magician [[John Mulholland (magician)|John Mulholland]] also exposed the tricks of the Davenport brothers:
A number of things immediately become less miraculous when it is known at times the Davenports employed as many as ten confederates. It was a night when a confederate was used that [[Alexander Herrmann]] (the stage magician known as Herrmann the Great) described in an article in the ''Cosmopolitan Magazine''. The performance was being given in Ithaca, New York, and many Cornell College students were in the audience. They had brought "pyrotechnic balls so made as to ignite suddenly with bright light." When the lights were struck the Davenports were found to be on opposite sides of the stage waving musical instruments around in the air.[[John Mulholland (magician)|Mulholland, John]] . (1938). ''Beware Familiar Spirits''. Charles Scribner's Sons. p. 78. {{ISBN|0-684-16181-8}}
According to the magician [[Harry Houdini]], Ira had confessed to him that he and his brother had faked their "spirit" phenomena. Houdini in his book ''A Magician Amongst the Spirits'' (1924) also reproduced a letter from Ira claiming "we never in public affirmed our Belief in spiritualism." The spiritualist [[Arthur Conan Doyle]] refused to accept the exposures of fraud, and insisted that in private Ira was a practicing spiritualist.[[Joe Nickell|Nickell, Joe]]. (2001). ''Real-Life X-Files: Investigating the Paranormal''. [[University Press of Kentucky]]. pp. 18-27. {{ISBN|0-8131-2210-4}} In 1998, skeptical investigator [[Joe Nickell]] discovered the Davenport's [[Scrapbooking|scrapbook]] from the museum at the [[Lily Dale Spiritualist Assembly]]. Nickell examined newspaper clippings, personal notes and photographs from the scrapbook. He concluded that Doyle was correct about Ira endorsing spiritualism in private and Houdini was also correct about their public "spirit" phenomena being the result of trickery. According to Nickell "taken as a whole, the evidence of the scrapbook does indicate that Ira Davenport was a practicing spiritualist, or at least pretended to be, although he and his brother used trickery to accomplish the effects they attributed to spirits." ==See also== *[[Thomas brothers (mediums)|Thomas brothers]] ==References== ==Further reading== *Nichols, Thomas Low. ''Biography of the Brothers Davenport''. 1864. (reprinted in 1976) {{ISBN|0-405-07969-9}} ==External links== * {{Internet Archive author |sname=Davenport brothers |birth=1841 |death=1877 |sopt=t}} {{Spiritism and Spiritualism}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Davenport Brothers}} [[Category:American magicians]] [[Category:Professional magicians]] [[Category:People from Buffalo, New York]] [[Category:Sibling duos]] [[Category:Spiritualists]] [[Category:1841 births]] [[Category:1877 deaths]]

{{More footnotes|BLP=yes|date=September 2013}} [[File:Br.David St.Gerold.jpg|thumb|David Steindl-Rast (2004)]] '''David Steindl-Rast''' OSB (born July 12, 1926) is a [[Catholic]] [[Benedictine]] [[monk]], notable for his active participation in [[interfaith]] dialogue and his work on the interaction between [[spirituality]] and science.
==Biography== Steindl-Rast was born and raised in [[Vienna, Austria]]. He received his MA degree from the [[Vienna Academy of Fine Arts]] and his [[Ph.D.]] in [[experimental psychology]] from the [[University of Vienna]] (1952). He emigrated to the United States in the same year and became a Benedictine monk in 1953 at [[Mount_Saviour_Monastery|Mount Saviour Monastery]] in [[Pine City, New York]], a newly founded Benedictine community. With permission of his abbot, Damasus Winzen, in 1966 he was officially delegated to pursue [[Buddhism|Buddhist]]-[[Christian]] dialogue and began to study [[Zen]] with masters [[Haku'un Yasutani]], [[Soen Nakagawa]], [[Shunryu Suzuki]] and [[Eido Tai Shimano]].<ref>Hallward, Clare. "David Steindl-Rast: Essential Writings". Orbis Books, Maryknoll, NY, 2010, p. 23.</ref>
He co-founded the Center for Spiritual Studies with [[Judaism|Jewish]], [[Buddhist]], [[Hinduism|Hindu]] and [[Sufi]] teachers, and since the 1970s has been a member of the cultural historian William Irwin Thompson's [[Lindisfarne Association]]. His writings include ''Gratefulness, the Heart of Prayer'', ''The Music of Silence'' (with Sharon Lebell), ''Words of Common Sense'' and ''Belonging to the Universe'' (co-authored with [[Fritjof Capra]]). He also co-founded A Network for Grateful Living, an organization dedicated to gratefulness as a transformative influence for individuals and society.
==Religion and mysticism==
During [[Link TV]]'s ''Lunch With Bokara'' 2005 episode ''The Monk and the Rabbi'', he stated:
:The religions start from mysticism. There is no other way to start a religion. But, I compare this to a volcano that gushes forth ...and then ...the magma flows down the sides of the mountain and cools off. And when it reaches the bottom, it's just rocks. You'd never guess that there was fire in it. So after a couple of hundred years, or two thousand years or more, what was once alive is dead rock. Doctrine becomes doctrinaire. Morals become moralistic. Ritual becomes ritualistic. What do we do with it? We have to push through this crust and go to the fire that's within it.
In that same episode, he expressed his belief in [[panentheism]], where divinity interpenetrates every part of existence and timelessly extends beyond it (as distinct from [[pantheism]]).
==Selected writings== * 1984, ''Gratefulness, the Heart of Prayer: An Approach to Life in Fullness'', N.J. Paulist Press 1984. {{ISBN|0-8091-2628-1}} * 1991, ''Belonging to the Universe: Explorations on the Frontiers of Science and Spirituality'', coauthored with [[Fritjof Capra]] and Thomas Matus, [[Harper San Francisco]], {{ISBN|978-0-06-250187-5}} * 1995, ''Music of Silence: A Sacred Journey through the Hours of the Day'', coauthored with Sharon LeBell, Ulysses Press, 2. Ed. 2001, {{ISBN|1-56975-297-4}} * 1996, ''The Ground We Share: Everyday Practice, Buddhist and Christian'', coauthored with [[Robert Baker Aitken]]. [[Shambhala Publications]], {{ISBN|1-57062-219-1}} * 1999, ''A Listening Heart: The Spirituality of Sacred Sensuousness'', Crossroad, {{ISBN|0-8245-1780-6}} * 2002, ''Words of Common Sense for Mind, Body and Soul'', [[Templeton Foundation Press]], {{ISBN|1-890151-98-X}} * 2008, ''Common Sense Spirituality.'' The [[Crossroad Publishing Company]], {{ISBN|0-8245-2479-9}} * 2010, ''Deeper than Words: Living the Apostles' Creed'', [[Doubleday Religion]], {{ISBN|978-0-307-58961-3}} * 2010, ''David Steindl-Rast: Essential Writings'', selected with and introduction by Clare Hallward, part of the Modern Spiritual Masters Series Edited by [[Robert Ellsberg]], [[Orbis Books]], {{ISBN|978-1-57075-888-1}} * 2016, ''Faith beyond Belief: Spirituality for Our Times'', coauthored with [[Anselm Grün]]. [[Liturgical Press]], {{ISBN|978-0814647134}} * 2016. ''The Way of Silence: Engaging the Sacred in Daily Life'', [[Franciscan Media]], {{ISBN|978-1632530165}} * 2017, ''i am through you so i'', [[Paulist Press]], {{ISBN|978-0809153947}}
In addition he has contributed to numerous works, including: * Introduction, ''Words of Gratitude for Mind, Body, and Soul'', by [[Robert A. Emmons]] and Joanna Hill * Afterword, ''Benedict's Dharma: Buddhists Reflect on the Rule of Saint Benedict'', by [[Zoketsu Norman Fischer|Norman Fischer]], [[Joseph Goldstein (writer)|Joseph Goldstein]] and [[Judith Simmer-Brown]], edited by [[Yifa]], and [[Patrick Henry]] * Foreword, ''Living Buddha, Living Christ'', by [[Thich Nhat Hanh]] * Foreword, ''This World'', by Teddy Macker
