[[User-centered design]] | thesis_title = Sensory Thresholds And Response Biases In Detection Experiments, A Theoretical And Experimental Analysis | thesis_year = 1962 | doctoral_advisor = [[R. Duncan Luce]] | doctoral_students = {{plainlist|1= *[[Michael I. Jordan]]
[[Abigail Sellen]] }} | website = {{URL|jnd.org}} }} '''Donald Arthur Norman''' (born December 25, 1935) is the director of The Design Lab at [[University of California, San Diego]].{{cite web | last = Robbins | first = Gary | title = Don Norman has Designs on Your Life | url = http://www.utsandiego.com/news/2014/oct/23/don-norman-homecoming/ | accessdate = November 18, 2014}}http://designlab.ucsd.edu/ He is best known for his books on design, especially ''[[The Design of Everyday Things]]''. He is widely regarded for his expertise in the fields of [[design]], [[usability engineering]], and [[cognitive science]].http://www.utsandiego.com/news/2014/oct/23/don-norman-homecoming/ Norman was also part of a select team flown in to investigate the [[Three Mile Island accident|Three Mile Island nuclear accident]].{{Cite news|url=http://www.mindflowdesign.com/insights/user-centric-design-the-lessons-of-3-mile-island/|title=User-Centric Design - The Lessons of 3 Mile Island|date=2014-08-06|work=Mindflow Design|access-date=2018-04-14|language=en-US}} He is also a co-founder and consultant with the [[Nielsen Norman Group]]. Much of Norman's work involves the advocacy of [[user-centered design]].{{cite journal | last = Zachry | first = Mark | title = An Interview with Donald Norman | journal = Technical Communication Quarterly | volume = 14 | issue = 4 | date = October 2005 | page = 469 | doi = 10.1207/s15427625tcq1404_5}} His books all have the underlying purpose of furthering the field of design, from doors to computers. Norman has taken a controversial stance in saying that the [[design research]] community has had little impact in the innovation of products, and that while academics can help in refining existing products, it is technologists that accomplish the breakthroughs.{{ cite web | last = Norman | first = Donald | title = Technology First, Needs Last | url = http://jnd.org/dn.mss/technology_first_needs_last.html | accessdate = January 26, 2010 }} To this end, Norman named his website with the initialism ''[[Just-noticeable difference|JND]]'' to signify his endeavors to make a difference.{{cite web |url= http://www.jnd.org/about.html#jnd |title= What does ''jnd.org'' mean? |website= Just-Noticeable Difference }} Norman had been splitting his time between co-directing the dual-degree MBA and Engineering program at [[Northwestern University]] and consulting with the Nielsen Norman Group. Norman announced that he would no longer teach full-time after the 2009–2010 academic year.{{ cite web | last = Norman | first = Donald | title = My change of status | url = http://jnd.org | accessdate = January 26, 2010 }} Norman is an active [[Distinguished Visiting Professor]] at the [[Korea Advanced Institute of Science and Technology]] (KAIST), where he spends two months a year teaching. He also holds the title of [[Professor Emeritus]] of Cognitive Science at the [[University of California, San Diego]].{{ cite web | last = Norman | first = Donald | title = Donald Norman Curriculum Vitae | url = http://jnd.org/docs/Don_Norman_Academic_Vita.pdf | accessdate = January 26, 2010 }} He is on numerous educational, private, and public sector advisory boards, including the editorial board of ''[[Encyclopædia Britannica]]''. In 2014, Norman returned to the University of California, San Diego as newly appointed director of The Design Lab.{{Cite web|url=http://www.sandiegouniontribune.com/news/2014/oct/23/don-norman-homecoming/|title=Don Norman has designs on your life|website=The San Diego Union-Tribune|access-date=2016-05-21}} == Early academics == In 1957, Norman received a [[Bachelor of Science]] in [[Electrical Engineering and Computer Science]] (EECS) from [[MIT]]. Norman continued through college until 1962, in the process earning [[Master of Science|M.S.]] in [[Electrical Engineering and Computer Science|EECS]] and a [[Doctorate of Philosophy]] in [[Mathematical Psychology]] from the [[University of Pennsylvania]]. After graduating, Norman took up a postdoctoral fellowship at the Center for Cognitive Studies at [[Harvard University]] and within a year became a lecturer. After four years with the Center, Norman took a position as an associate professor in the Psychology Department at [[University of California, San Diego]] (UCSD). Norman applied his training as an engineer and computer scientist, and as an experimental and mathematical psychologist, to the emerging discipline of [[cognitive science]]. Norman eventually became founding chair of the Department of Cognitive Science and chair of the Department of Psychology. At UCSD, Norman was a founder of the Institute for Cognitive Science and one of the organizers of the [[Cognitive Science Society]] (along with [[Roger Schank]], [[Allan M. Collins|Allan Collins]], and others), which held its first meeting at the UCSD campus in 1979. Together with psychologist [[Tim Shallice]], Norman proposed a framework of attentional control of executive functioning. One of the components of the Norman-Shallice model is the [[supervisory attentional system]].{{cite book | last = Friedenberg | first = Jay | author2 = Gordon Silverman | title = Cognitive Science: An Introduction of the Study of Mind | year = 2010 | publisher = SAGE Publications | location = United St ates of America | isbn = 978-1-4129-7761-6 | pages = 180–182}} == Cognitive engineering career == Norman made the transition from cognitive science to [[cognitive engineering]] by entering the field as a consultant and writer. His article "The truth about Unix: ''The user interface is horrid''"{{cite news | last1 = Norman | first1 = Don | title = The truth about Unix: The user interface is horrid | url = http://www.bradleymonk.com/File:The_truth_about_Unix_Don_Norman.pdf | work = Datamation | issue = 27(12) | date = 1981}} in ''[[Datamation]]'' (1981) catapulted him to a position of prominence in the computer world.{{Citation needed|date=November 2015}} Soon after, his career took off outside of academia, although he still remained active at UCSD until 1993. Norman continued his work to further [[human-centered design]] by serving on numerous university and government advisory boards such as the [[Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency]] (DARPA). He currently serves on numerous committees and advisory boards like at Motorola, the [[Toyota National College of Technology]], [[TED Conference]], [[Panasonic]], ''[[Encyclopædia Britannica]]'', and many more. Norman published several important books during his time at UCSD, one of which, ''User Centered System Design'', obliquely referred to the university in the initials of its title. In 1993, Norman left UCSD to join [[Apple Computer]], initially as an Apple Fellow as a User Experience Architect (the first use of the phrase "[[User Experience]]" in a job title{{cite web|last1=Lialina|first1=Olia|title=Rich User Experience, UX and Desktopization of War|url=http://contemporary-home-computing.org/RUE/|website=contemporary-home-computing.org|accessdate=25 September 2016}}{{cite web|last1=Merholz|first1=Peter|title=Peter in Conversation with Don Norman About UX & Innovation|url=http://adaptivepath.org/ideas/e000862/|website=Adaptative Path|accessdate=25 September 2016}}{{Citation needed|date=January 2016}}), and then as the Vice President of the [[Apple Advanced Technology Group|Advanced Technology Group]]. He later worked for [[Hewlett-Packard]] before joining with [[Jakob Nielsen (usability consultant)|Jakob Nielsen]] to form the [[Nielsen Norman Group]] in 1998. He returned to academia as a professor of [[computer science]] at [[Northwestern University]], where he was co-director of the [[Segal Design Institute]] until 2010. In 2014, he returned to UCSD to become director of the newly established The Design Lab housed at the [[California Institute for Telecommunications and Information Technology]]. Norman has received many awards for his work. He received an [[honorary degree]] from the [[University of Padua]] in [[Padua]], Italy. In 2001 he was inducted as a [[Fellow]] of the [[Association for Computing Machinery]], and in 2006 he received the [[The Franklin Institute Awards|Benjamin Franklin Medal]] in Computer and Cognitive Science.{{ cite web | url = http://www.fi.edu/tfi/exhibits/bower/06/ccscience.html | title = Donald A. Norman | work = Laureate Database | publisher = The Franklin Institute Awards | accessdate = 2011-06-24 }} In 2009 Norman was elected an Honorary Fellow of the [[Design Research Society]]. == User-centered design == In his book ''[[The Design of Everyday Things]]'', Norman uses the term "[[user-centered design]]" to describe design based on the needs of the user, leaving aside what he deems secondary issues like aesthetics. User-centered design involves simplifying the structure of tasks, making things visible, getting the mapping right, exploiting the powers of constraint, designing for error, explaining [[affordance]]s and [[seven stages of action]]. In addition, Norman discusses the closely related term "[[human-centered design]]" at length. In his book The Things that Make us Smart: Defending the Human Attribute in the Age of the Machine,{{cite book|last1=Norman|first1=Don|title=Things That Make us Smart: Defending Human Attributes in the Age of the Machine|date=1993|publisher=Pursues Book Group|url=https://www.amazon.com/exec/obidos/ISBN%3D0201626950/donnormanA/104-2013751-2967137}} Norman uses the term “Cognitive Artifacts” to describe “those artificial devices that maintain, display, or operate upon information in order to serve a representational function and that affect human cognitive performance”. Similar to his [[The Design of Everyday Things]] book, Norman argues for the development of [[machine]]s that fit our minds, rather than have our minds be conformed to the machine. == Quotes == * "Academics get paid for being clever, not for being right."{{ cite book | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=FUkXAQAAMAAJ&q=%22academics+get+paid+for+being+clever%22&dq=%22academics+get+paid+for+being+clever%22&hl=en&ei=xGaDTarAA5DmsQPLo52IAg&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=2&ved=0CDAQ6AEwAQ | title = Annual conference | publisher = Google Books | date = 2010-12-21 | accessdate = 2011-06-24 }} * "When you get paid $100 an hour, people expect you to do real work. When you get paid $1000 an hour, people only expect you to have lunch with the CEO."{{Cite quote|date=May 2016}} * "Good design is actually a lot harder to notice than poor design, in part because good designs fit our needs so well that the design is invisible."{{Cite book|title=The Design of Everyday Things: Revised and Expanded Edition|last=Norman|first=Donald|publisher=|year=2013|isbn=|location=|pages=xi}} == Partial bibliography == === Psychology === * ''Human information processing: An introduction to psychology (1972) in collaboration with Peter H. Lindsay (first author)''{{cite journal | last1 = Oden | first1 = Gregg C. | last2 = Lopes | first2 = Lola L. | year = 1997 | title = Human Information Processing: An Introduction to Psychology by Peter H. Lindsay, Donald A. Norman | url = | journal = The American Journal of Psychology | volume = 110 | issue = 4 | pages = 635–641 | doi = 10.2307/1423414 | subscription = yes}} * ''Memory and attention'' (1977) * ''Learning and memory'' (1982) === Usability === * ''Direct manipulation interfaces'' (1985) about [[direct manipulation interface]]s in collaboration with E. '''Emory S. Foster''' (November 5, 1839 – December 23, 1902) was a [[Major (United States)|major]] in the 7th [[Missouri State Militia (Union)|Missouri State Militia]] Cavalry during the [[American Civil War]]. Afterwards he was a [[St. Louis, Missouri]] newspaper editor who fought a [[duel]] with rival editor and former [[Confederate States Army|Confederate]] [[John N. Edwards]].
==Civil War== Foster was born in [[Greene County, Missouri]].
He was a staunch Unionist whose brother Marshall was murdered by secessionists in early 1861 on his way to vote.<ref>Matthews, Matt and Lindberg, Kip, "Shot All to Pieces, the Battle of Lone Jack, Missouri, August 16, 1862", ''North and South'', Vol. 7, No. 1, January, 2004, page 58</ref> During the [[American Civil War]], on Emory formed a [[Home Guard (Union)|Unionist Home Guard]] company called "Foster's Mounted Rangers" in which he served as [[Captain (United States)|captain]], enlisting on August 28, 1861.<ref>Missouri State Archives, Soldiers Database,Record of Service Card, Civil War, 1861-1865, Box 28, Reel s881</ref> He later enlisted in the Federally funded [[Missouri State Militia (Union)|Missouri State Militia]], being elected major of the 7th MSM Cavalry. He and his men engaged in skirmishes around his new home in [[Warrensburg, Missouri]] and Foster gained a reputation as an aggressive commander.
On August 15, 1862 after a two-day march from [[Warrensburg, Missouri]] to [[Lexington, Missouri]], he was ordered to take 800 men on a 20-mile march to [[Lone Jack, Missouri]] to engage Confederate troops that were attempting to capture [[Jackson County, Missouri]] in what would become the [[Battle of Lone Jack]].
Upon arrival, Foster's force encountered an 800-1,600 man sleeping Confederate recruiting force under [[Colonel]] [[John T. Coffee]] and [[Lieutenant colonel (United States)|Lieutenant Colonel]] John Charles Tracy and routed them. However, the firing of Foster's artillery alerted other Confederate recruiting commands in the area of his presence and intent. Confederates under Colonels [[Vard Cockrell]], [[Upton Hays]], and [[DeWitt C. Hunter]] were joined by Lt. Col. Tracy and a fierce five-hour battle ensued the next morning.<ref>Matthews, Matt and Lindberg, Kip, "Shot All to Pieces, the Battle of Lone Jack, Missouri, August 16, 1862", ''North and South'', Vol. 7, No. 1, January, 2004, pages 59-60</ref> The Federals withdrew after Foster was wounded and Col. Coffee's command joined Cockrell.
Foster and his brother were severely wounded, unable to withdraw, and were taken to a cabin. The cabin was captured by the Confederates and Foster was about to be executed by a member of [[Quantrill's Raiders]] when an 18-year-old [[Cole Younger]] physically threw the gunman out sparing Foster and his brothers life. They gave $1,000 and their handguns to Younger who then delivered them to the Foster sons' mother in Warrensburg (all despite Younger's being a member of the Confederates).<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=rJNHtVsKH-gC&pg=PA139&lpg=PA139&dq=%22emory+s+foster%22&source=web&ots=Z33yQ4yEGF&sig=-bufCG6pUz4poRhN3NXyAgZTrag#PPA139,M1 The Devil Knows How to Ride: The True Story of William Clarke Quantrill and His Confederate Raiders by Edward E. Leslie - Da Capo Press - 1998] {{ISBN|0-306-80865-X}}</ref>
In 1876, Younger as a member of the [[James-Younger Gang]] was captured in the botched [[Northfield, Minnesota]] bank robbery. Foster was to forcefully argue for a parole for Younger in the 1890s.<ref>Matthews, Matt and Lindberg, Kip, "Shot All to Pieces, the Battle of Lone Jack, Missouri, August 16, 1862", ''North and South'', Vol. 7, No. 1, January, 2004, page 66</ref> Also arguing for the parole was future [[Secretary of War]] [[Stephen Benton Elkins]] whose only taste of combat had been at Lone Jack, an experience which he said filled him with disgust of war.
==Duel with John Newman Edwards== After the war he became an editor at the St. Louis Journal.
On September 4, 1875 he fought a duel north of [[Rockford, Illinois]] with Edwards, who was then an editor of the St. Louis Times (after leaving the [[Kansas City Times]] in 1873).
The dispute had centered on an August 25 article by Edwards talking about the mistreatment of [[Jefferson Davis]] at the [[Winnebago County, Illinois]] Fair. The Journal replied the same day "the writer of the Times article had lied, and knew he lied, when he wrote it."
Edwards demanded a retraction and Foster refused saying the editorial was not directed at Edwards personally. On August 30 Edwards challenged Foster to a duel:
:The disclaimer in the first four paragraphs of your letter would be satisfactory had you followed it up by a withdrawal of the offensive terms of your editorial, so far as they referred to me personally. But as you decline to do so I must, therefore, construe your letter of this date, and its spirit, as a refusal on your part to do me an act of common justice, and so regarding it, I deem it my duty to ask of you that satisfaction which one gentleman has a right to ask of another.<ref>[http://www.civilwarstlouis.com/History2/johnnedwardsbio.htm JOHN NEWMAN EDWARDS - civilwarstlouis.com - February 13, 2008]</ref>
Their seconds made the arrangements and at 5 pm the two met in a field and both missed as Foster smoked a cigar. Foster commented, "A little high."
Edwards demanded a second fire, "I will go on if it takes a thousand fires."
Foster refused a second fire. He had been challenged and shots had been fired and so his honor had been maintained.
Both shook hands and made a [[bourbon whiskey|bourbon]] [[toast]].
Foster died in [[Oakland, California]].

{{Infobox politician | name = Eugen Varga | image = Vargajenő.jpg | birth_date = {{birth date|df=yes|1879|11|06}} | birth_place = [[Budapest]], [[Austria-Hungary]] | death_date = {{Death date and age|1964|10|07|1879|11|06|df=y}} | death_place = [[Moscow]], [[Soviet Union]] | profession = politician | party = | spouse = | children = | parents = Sámuel Weisz
Julianna Singer }} '''Eugen Samuilovich "Jenő" Varga''' (born as '''Eugen Weisz''', November 6, 1879, [[Budapest]] – October 7, 1964, [[Moscow]]) was a [[Marxian economist]] of [[Hungarian people|Hungarian]] origin. ==Biography== ===Early years=== He was born as Jenő Weiß (Hungarian orthography: Weisz) in a poor Jewish family{{cite book|author=[[Michael Löwy]]|title=Redemption and Utopia: Jewish Libertarian Thought in Central Europe : a Study in Elective Affinity|publisher=Stanford University Press|year=1992|page=174|ISBN=9780804717762|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=J0XaP509LdYC&printsec=frontcover&dq=Redemption+and+Utopia:+Jewish+Libertarian+Thought+in+Central+Europe+:+a+Study+in+Elective+Affinity&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjJ4PmH0u_UAhUNJ1AKHRuRCY0Q6AEIKDAA#v=onepage&q=Redemption%20and%20Utopia%3A%20Jewish%20Libertarian%20Thought%20in%20Central%20Europe%20%3A%20a%20Study%20in%20Elective%20Affinity&f=false}}, as a child of Samuel Weisz - who was a teacher in the primary school of [[Nagytétény]] - and Julianna Singer. Eugen "Jenő" Varga studied philosophy and economic geography at the [[Eötvös Loránd University|University of Budapest]]. In 1906, he started writing in socialist and academic journals, mainly on economic subjects, but also on other topics. Before [[World War I]] he gained some fame by discussing with [[Otto Bauer]] about the origins of inflation in the [[Austria-Hungary|Austro-Hungarian Empire]]. In this period he belonged to the Marxist Centrists, of whom [[Karl Kautsky]] and [[Rudolf Hilferding]] were the most prominent spokesmen. ===Hungarian revolution=== He participated as minister of finance in the short-lived [[Hungarian Soviet Republic]] of 1919. After the overthrow of the Soviet Republic he fled to Vienna. ===Soviet emigration=== In 1920 he went to the [[Soviet Union]], where he started working for the [[Comintern]], specializing in international economic problems and agrarian questions. In years 1922-1927 he was working at the department of trade in the Soviet embassy in [[Berlin]]. In the 1930s he became an economic adviser to [[Joseph Stalin]]. He survived the purges of the 1930s. During [[World War II]] he advised the Soviet Government in matters of post-war reparations. He attended the Potsdam Conference of 1945 as an expert. Like most of his compatriots living and working in Moscow, he joined the [[Communist Party of the Soviet Union]], but he also remained active in the [[Hungarian Communist Party]]. He authored the economic reports the congresses of the Comintern discussed between 1921 and 1935. A large number of his writings were studies of the international economic [[conjuncture]], in which he made great effort to assess quantitative trends in output, investment and employment using official economic data from numerous countries. He also extensively studied [[Germany|German]] imperialism. In 1946 he published ''The Economic Transformation of Capitalism at the End of the Second World War'', in which he argued that the capitalist system was more inherently stable than had been hitherto believed. This led to the closure of the Institute which he headed. (See: Paolo Spriano, ''Stalin and the European Communists''. London: Verso, 1985). Finally, in 1949 he would make his self-criticism. Though he remained a leading academic economist, his prestige had diminished. In the second edition of the ''Great Soviet Encyclopedia'' he was qualified as a "bourgeois economist." ===Years after Stalin=== After Stalin's death in 1953, he reappeared on the scene, but the new men in power in the [[Kremlin]] believing in the virtues of peaceful co-existence were not interested in Varga's predictions of the outbreak of a "necessary" economic crisis in the United States. In 1954 and 1959 he received the [[Lenin Order]]s, in 1954 he obtained a [[Stalin Prize]] and in 1963 a [[Lenin Prize]]. After his death, his selected works in three volumes were published in the [[Soviet Union]], [[Hungary]], and [[East Germany]]. Varga never returned to living in his native Hungary. Because he was very close to [[Mátyás Rákosi]], he was several times invited as an economic advisor to Hungary. In this period (1945-1950) he had specialized in economic planning, pricing and monetary reforms, i.e. reforms the Hungarian Communists now in power were carrying out. After the fall of Rákosi caused by the [[Hungarian Revolution of 1956]] and the take-over by the [[János Kádár|Kádár]] team, Varga's advisory work was not appreciated anymore. ==Footnotes== {{reflist|2}} == Further reading == * Gerhard Duda, ''Jeno Varga und die Geschichte des Instituts für Weltwirtschaft und Weltpolitik in Moskau 1921-1970.'' Berlin, 1994. * Charlene Gannage, "E. S. Varga and the Theory of State Monopoly Capitalism," ''Review of Radical Political Economics,'' vol. 12, no. 3 (Fall 1980), pp. 36–49. * Peter Knirsch, ''Eugen Varga.'' Berlin, 1961. * Laszlo Tikos, ''E. Vargas Tätigkeit als Wirtschaftsanalytiker und Publizist in der ungarischen Sozialdemokratie, in der Konimtern, in der Akademie der Wissenschaften der UdSSR.'' Tübingen, 1965. * André Mommen, ''Eens komt de grote crisis van het kapitalisme. Leven en werk van Jeno Varga.'' Brussels, 2002. * André Mommen, ''Stalin's Economist. The Economic Contributions of Jenö Varga.'' London: Routledge, 2011. * {{cite journal |author=Kyung Deok Roh |date=July 2011 |title=Rethinking the Varga Controversy, 1941-1953 |journal=Europe-Asia Studies |volume=63 |issue=5 |pages=833–855 |doi=10.1080/09668136.2011.576026}} == External links == *[http://marxists.org/archive/varga/ Eugen Varga on Marxist Internet Archive] *[https://archive.org/details/TwentiethCenturyCapitalism ''Twentieth Century Capitalism'' by Varga, 1962.] *[https://archive.org/details/PoliticoEconomicProblemsOfCapitalism ''Politico-Economic Problems of Capitalism'' by Varga, 1968.] * {{PM20|FID=pe/017760}} {{s-start}} {{s-off}} {{succession box|title=[[Minister of Finance of Hungary|People's Commissar of Finance]]|before=[[Pál Szende]]|after=[[Béla Székely]] and [[Gyula Lengyel]]|years=1919}} {{s-end}} {{HungarianFinanceMinisters}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Varga, Jenoe}} [[Category:1879 births]] [[Category:1964 deaths]] [[Category:People from Budapest]] [[Category:Hungarian communists]] [[Category:Finance ministers of Hungary]] [[Category:Comintern people]] [[Category:Marxist theorists]] [[Category:Hungarian economists]] [[Category:Russian economists]] [[Category:Soviet economists]] [[Category:20th-century economists]] [[Category:Hungarian emigrants to the Soviet Union]] [[Category:Full Members of the USSR Academy of Sciences]] [[Category:Lenin Prize winners]] [[Category:Recipients of the Order of Lenin]] [[Category:Members of the German Academy of Sciences at Berlin]]

{{Infobox officeholder |name = Eyo Ita Esua |image = |office1 = Chairman of the Federal Electoral Commission |term_start1 = 1964 |term_end1 = 1966 |predecessor1 = |successor1 = [[Michael Ani]] |birth_date = 14 January 1901 |birth_place = [[Cross River State]], [[Nigeria]] |death_date = 1973 |party = |Educational background = }} '''Eyo Ita Esua''' (14 January 1901 - 1973) was a [[Nigerian]] teacher and trade unionist who was at the helm of the Balewa government's Federal Electoral Commission in the [[Nigerian First Republic]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://allafrica.com/stories/201006090203.html |title=Past INEC Chairmen |work=ThisDay |author=Imam Imam |date=9 June 2010 |accessdate=2010-06-10}}</ref>
Esua was a school master and a founder member of the Nigerian Union of Teachers. He was the first full-time general secretary of the union from 1943 until his retirement in 1964.<ref>{{cite book |page=32 |title=Thomas Hodgkin: letters from Africa 1947-56 |author1=Thomas Lionel Hodgkin |author2=Elizabeth Hodgkin |author3=Michael Wolfers |publisher=HAAN |year=2000 |ISBN=1-874209-93-6}}</ref> He was an [[Ibibio people|Ibibio]], [[Calabar]] man, renowned for his dedication to duty and uprightness.<ref>{{cite book |title=Violence and politics in Nigeria: the Tiv and Yoruba experience |author=Remi Anifowose |publisher=Nok Publishers International |year=1982 |ISBN=0-88357-084-X}}</ref>
The Esua-led commission organized the December 1964 election, which was mired in controversy. Two members of the commission disagreed with the chairman and resigned from the commission. Esua also conducted the 1965 Western Region election, which was violent and was disputed by the opposition United Party Grand Alliance.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://thenationonlineng.net/web2/articles/49282/1/Will-he-make-the-difference/Page1.html |title=Will he make the difference? |author=Olukorede Yishau |work=The Nation |date=2010-06-09 |accessdate=2010-06-10}}</ref> A few days before these elections Esua acknowledged that his organisation could not guarantee a free and fair poll.<ref>{{cite book |page=39 |title=The Biafra war: Nigeria and the aftermath |author=Herbert Ekwe-Ekwe |ISBN=0-88946-175-9 |publisher=E. Mellen Press |year=1990}}</ref> The widespread electoral abuses may have been a factor in the success of the military coup of January 1966 in which Major General [[Johnson Aguiyi-Ironsi]] came to power.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.thenigerianvoice.com/nvnews/26106/1/electoral-commission-through-the-years.html |title=ELECTORAL COMMISSION THROUGH THE YEARS |work=NBF News |date=7 Jun 2010 |accessdate=2010-06-10}}</ref>

{{Use mdy dates|date=January 2015}} {{Infobox musical artist | name = Freddie Aguilar | image = Freddie- aguilar.jpg | caption = Aguilar in [[Tondo, Manila|Tondo]], Manila, [[Philippines]], 1988 | image_size = <!-- Only for images narrower than 220 pixels --> | background = solo_singer | birth_name = Ferdinand Pascual Aguilar | alias = Ka Freddie, Abdul Farid | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1953|02|05}} | birth_place = [[Santo Tomas, Isabela|Santo Tomas]], [[Isabela (province)|Isabela]], Philippines | instrument = Vocals, guitar, bass guitar | genre = [[Philippine folk music|Folk]], [[Manila Sound]], [[Original Pilipino Music|OPM]] | occupation = Musician, songwriter | years_active = 1973–present | label = [[Vicor Music]]/Sunshine, [[RCA Records|RCA]] | associated_acts = Watawat Band | website = {{URL|freddieanakaguilar.com/}} }}
'''Ferdinand Pascual Aguilar''' (born February 5, 1953), better known as '''Freddie Aguilar''' or '''Ka Freddie Aguilar''', is a [[Folk music|folk]] musician from the [[Philippines]]. He is best known for his rendition of "[[Bayan Ko]]", which became the anthem for the opposition to the [[Ferdinand Marcos|Marcos]] regime during the 1986 [[People Power Revolution]],<ref>[http://www.asianweek.com/070596/Wife.html Priestess, Wife, Revolutionary: A new film documents the role of women in Philippine history] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20061215100515/http://www.asianweek.com/070596/Wife.html |date=December 15, 2006 }}</ref> and for his song "[[Anak (song)|Anak]]", the best-selling Philippine music record of all time.<ref name="a">{{cite web |url=http://telebisyon.net/balita/Still-up-on-his-toes/source/119613/ |title=Still up on his toes (an interview with Freddie Aguilar) |accessdate=2010-06-06 |author=Dot Ramos Balasbas-Gancayco |date=December 12, 2006 |work=The Philippine Star |publisher= |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120310193356/http://telebisyon.net/balita/Still-up-on-his-toes/source/119613/ |archivedate=March 10, 2012 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> He is heavily associated with [[Pinoy rock]].<ref>{{cite book|last=Dorian|first=Frederick|author2=Simon Broughton |author3=Mark Ellingham |author4=James McConnachie |author5=Richard Trillo |author6=Orla Duane |title=World Music: The Rough Guide|publisher=Rough Guides|year=2000|page=216|isbn=1-85828-636-0|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=QzX8THIgRjUC&pg=PA216&dq=anak+freddie|accessdate=2009-07-06}}</ref>
He is well known internationally, and within the Philippines and Asia-Pacific region, claiming fame as one of the best musician-songwriters of the Philippines.
==Early life== Freddie Aguilar's musical beginnings started when he was young. At the age of 14, he wrote songs about his family who are now knows as the Peralta Family from Bukidnon. It was said that these people were exceedingly handsome and beautiful people that stole the hearts of many. When he was 17-years-old, Aguilar played his first guitar. By the time he was 20-years-old, Freddie Aguilar performed on stage for the first time.<ref>[http://freddieanakaguilar.com/biography.html, The Freddie Aguilar Story]</ref>
Freddie Aguilar studied [[Electrical Engineering]] at De Guzman Institute of Technology but did not finish the degree program. Instead he pursued music, became a street musician, and then a folk club and bar musician.<ref name="e">{{cite book|last=Lockard|first=Craig A.|title=Dance of life: popular music and politics in Southeast Asia|publisher=University of Hawaii|year=1998|page=144|isbn=0-8248-1918-7|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=_likSSE9sEAC&pg=PA144&dq=anak+freddie|accessdate=2009-07-03}}</ref>
At the age of 18, Aguilar parted ways with his family and quit college. After realizing and regretting his mistakes five years later, he composed the song "[[Anak (song)|Anak]]".<ref>[http://www.philstar.com/entertainment/2017/06/10/1708408/freddie-i-wrote-anak-atone-my-sins Freddie: I wrote Anak to atone my sins] ''Philstar'' (10 June 2017). Retrieved 4 January 2018.</ref>
===Influences=== Freddie Aguilar's influences include British and American folk-rock stars like [[Cat Stevens]] and [[James Taylor]].<ref name="e"/> He is also heavily influenced by his Filipino heritage, nationalist feelings, and tries to constitute a musical exploration of the Filipino ethos.<ref name="e"/>
==Career==
===International acclaim=== Freddie Aguilar's "Anak" not only broke the Philippine record charts in 1979, but it also hit the no. 1 spot in Japan and achieved considerable popularity in other countries such as Indonesia, Malaysia, Hong Kong, and parts of Western Europe.<ref name="c"/> The song has become so famous that, by some counts, it has been recorded in as many as a hundred versions in 23 languages throughout the world.<ref>{{Citation | last = Caruncho | first = Eric S. | author-link = | last2 = | first2 = | author2-link = | title = Whose 'Anak' is it Anyway? | newspaper = Philippine Daily Inquirer | page = 3 | date = July 15, 2001 | url = }}</ref> ''Billboard'' reported that the song was the number two world hit of the 1980s. As of 2006, it was unsurpassed as the highest-selling record of Philippine music history.<ref name="a"/>
===Political activism=== Even before Aguilar's rendition of "Bayan Ko," Aguilar created and performed songs targeted at social injustices. His album, ''Magdalena'' included songs about a girl forced into prostitution as a result of poverty and the Christian-Muslim clashes in his song ''Mindanao.'' After the album, Freddie Aguilar also sang about the injustices suffered by the powerless, poverty, and the arrogance of superpowers in a song about the U.S. and Russia.<ref name="e"/>
Five years after the composition of "Anak", Freddie Aguilar joined protests against the Marcos regime and began writing and performing songs that criticized the excesses of the government.<ref name="c">{{cite journal |last1=Tadiar |first1=Neferti X. M. |last2= |first2= |year=2009 |title=Popular Laments |journal=Cultural Studies |volume=23 |issue=1 |pages=1–26 |publisher= |doi=10.1080/09502380701702482 |url=}}</ref> Some of the songs that caused him to be banned from mainstream media include: "Kata-rungan" or "''Justice''" (speaking for the unjustly accused), "Pangako" ("''Promise''") (a leader's unfulfilled pledges to an abandoned people), and "Luzvi-minda" (an acronym for Luzon, Visayas, Mindanao, calling on Filipinos to wake up to the reality of oppression). One of the songs he was most remembered for during that time was his interpretation of "[[Bayan Ko]]" ("''My Country''"), in which he added a verse to the original piece.<ref>{{Citation | last = Poblete | first = Johanna D. | author-link = | last2 = | first2 = | author2-link = | title = Songs of Freedom | newspaper = Weekender | pages = S4/1 | date = August 7, 2009 | url = }}</ref>
==="Bayan Ko" (My Country)=== In 1978, Aguilar first recorded "Bayan Ko" in a patriotic effort to, in his words, "jolt back those who were starting to forget who we really are."<ref name="c"/> He also provided a rendition of the song as it is inspiring and gave him excitement and a surge of power.<ref name="f">[http://www.abs-cbnnews.com/lifestyle/06/24/10/bayan-ko-has-long-history 'Bayan Ko' has a long history]</ref> The song was originally composed in 1928 by Constancio de Guzman, with lyrics by poet [[Jose Corazon de Jesus]], during a time of struggle for Philippine independence from US occupation.<ref name="d">{{cite journal |last1=Maceda |first1=Teresita Gemenez |last2= |first2= |year=2007 |title=Problematizing the popular: the dynamics of Pinoy pop(ular) music and popular protest music |journal=Inter-Asian Cultural Studies |volume=8 |issue=3 |pages=390–413 |publisher= |doi=10.1080/14649370701393766 |url=}}</ref> It emerged once again during the Marcos regime as the unofficial anthem of the emergent "people" of "[[People Power]]", the new democratic nation opposed to authoritarianism that is widely credited with the deposing of [[Ferdinand Marcos]].<ref name="c"/> In 1983, the assassination of [[Benigno Aquino, Jr.|Benigno "Ninoy" Aquino]] triggered massive demonstrations against the Marcos dictatorship, and Aguilar's rendition of "Bayan Ko" was blared on the radio and speakers mounted on jeepneys throughout the streets of Manila and the provinces of the Philippines.<ref name="d"/> At the funeral of Senator Aquino, Freddie Aguilar sang "Bayan Ko" and felt that Aquino was a man of action who even gave his life for the freedom of the Philippines.<ref name="g">[http://www.gov.ph/2014/02/25/dancing-to-the-tune-of-the-revolution/, Dancing to the Tune of the Revolution: 5 songs of EDSA]</ref> During the performance, Freddie Aguilar did not feel scared anymore and felt strong and confident.<ref name="f"/> He then decided to join the cause as well.<ref name="g"/> Aguilar, along with [[APO Hiking Society]] and other Pinoy pop musicians who took a stand against dictatorship, joined other protest singers in music and street performances as part of the anti-Marcos rallies.<ref name="d"/>
A few years later, Aguilar campaigned for the presidential candidacy of [[Corazon Aquino]] in the national election that would lead to the 1986 revolt.<ref name="c"/>
Aguilar mentioned in an interview with ABS-CBN News that the lyrics of the song combines the love the Filipinos have for their country, commemorate the Aquino family, and commitment to the country.<ref name="f"/> Even in this modern time, Filipinos will identify "Bayan Ko" as the nation's protest anthem.<ref name="d"/>
===Present day=== On January 18, 2008, Aguilar received the Asia Star Award from the Asia Model Award Festival in [[Korea]].<ref>[http://www.gmanews.tv/story/77331/Iza-Calzado-bags-Asian-model-award-in-Korea GMA NEWS.TV, Iza Calzado bags Asian model award in Korea]</ref>
Aguilar still lives in the Philippines, and continues to perform. He currently has moved to his own place dubbed "Ka Freddie's". He still has a strong following in the Philippines and among many [[Filipino people|Filipinos]] living overseas.
On July 14, 2016, Aguilar has been appointed as one of the 15 commissioners of the [[National Commission for Culture and the Arts]] (NCCA). Aguilar has been advocating for the creation of a new department called "Department of Culture and Arts".<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.pep.ph/news/63764/freddie-aguilar-appointed-as-new-ncca-commissioner-by-president-rodrigo-duterte|title=Freddie Aguilar appointed as new NCCA commissioner by President Rodrigo Duterte|publisher=[[Philippine Entertainment Portal]]|language=Filipino|last=Serato|first=Arniel|date=July 15, 2016|accessdate=July 15, 2016}}</ref> During the campaign and the [[Inauguration of Rodrigo Duterte|Inauguration]] of president [[Rodrigo Duterte]], Aguilar performed “Para sa Tunay na Pagbabago”, which is one of Duterte's campaign jingles to the tune of Ipaglalaban Ko.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://s3.amazonaws.com/hiphopdx-production/2018/05/Tekashi-e1526316435503-827x620.jpg|title=Freddie Aguilar at the peak of his career|publisher=[[GMA news]]|date=June 30, 1994|accessdate=July 15, 2016}}</ref> Aguilar is President Duterte's favorite singer. <ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.gmanetwork.com/news/story/571879/news/nation/at-duterte-inauguration-freddie-aguilar-sings-about-tunay-na-pagbabago|title=At Duterte inauguration, Freddie Aguilar sings about 'tunay na pagbabago'|publisher=[[GMA News]]|date=June 30, 2016|accessdate=July 15, 2016}}</ref>
==Personal life== In 1978, he married Josephine Queipo and with her had 4 children: Maegan, Jonan, Isabella, and Jeriko.
On October 17, 2013, Aguilar openly admitted, in spite of the controversy that followed,<ref name="freddiecriticism">{{cite news|url=http://www.interaksyon.com/entertainment/twittterverse-slams-freddie-aguilar-for-relationship-with-16-year-old-girl|title=Twittterverse slams Freddie Aguilar for relationship with 16-year-old girl|work=InterAksyon|accessdate=October 17, 2013}}</ref> that he is in a relationship with a 16-year-old girl, with plans to marry and even have children, as his partner insisted that she is willing to have a baby.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.abs-cbnnews.com/entertainment/10/16/13/freddie-aguilar-ready-marry-16-year-old-gf |title=Freddie Aguilar ready to marry 16-year-old GF |publisher=ABS-CBN News |accessdate=2013-10-17}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://philnews.ph/2013/10/17/freddie-aguilar-marry-16-year-old-gf-who-wants-have-baby/ |title=Freddie Aguilar to Marry 16-Year-Old GF who Wants to Have a Baby | Philippine News |publisher=Philnews.ph |accessdate=2013-10-17}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.pep.ph/news/40746/60-year-old-legendary-singer-Freddie-Aguilar-admits-to-dating-16-year-old-girl|title=60-year-old legendary singer Freddie Aguilar is helplessly in love with 16-year-old girlfriend|work=PEP.ph|accessdate=October 17, 2013}}</ref>
On November 22, 2013, Aguilar, under [[Islam]]ic rites, married his partner in [[Buluan, Maguindanao]].<ref>{{cite web|last=Diola |first=Camille |url=http://www.philstar.com/entertainment/2013/11/22/1259602/now-muslim-freddie-aguilar-marries-16-year-old |title=Now a Muslim, Freddie Aguilar marries 16-year-old | Entertainment, News, The Philippine Star |publisher=philstar.com |accessdate=2013-11-23}}</ref> Aguilar had converted to Islam six months prior to these reports, so that he could marry his then 16-year-old girlfriend.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.abs-cbnnews.com/entertainment/11/22/13/why-freddie-16-year-old-gf-can-marry-muslims |title=Why Freddie, 16-year-old GF can marry as Muslims |publisher=ABS-CBN News |accessdate=2013-11-23}}</ref> His Muslim name is Abdul Farid.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://philnews.ph/2013/11/23/freddie-aguilar-as-abdul-farid-wedding-photos-with-16-year-old-gf/ |title=Freddie Aguilar as Abdul Farid Wedding Photos with 16-Year-Old GF | Philippine News |publisher=Philnews.ph |date=August 9, 2013 |accessdate=2013-11-23}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.abs-cbnnews.com/entertainment/11/22/13/teen-explains-why-she-married-freddie-aguilar |title=Teen explains why she married Freddie Aguilar |publisher=ABS-CBN News |accessdate=2013-11-23}}</ref>
On January 3, 2018, Aguilar's residence in North Fairview, [[Quezon City]] was destroyed by a fire, which was reported to have started at his music room.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Jalea|first1=Mary Gleefer|title=Singer Freddie Aguilar loses QC home, belongings to fire|url=http://www.manilatimes.net/singer-freddie-aguilar-loses-qc-home-belongings-fire/372130/|accessdate=January 4, 2018|work=The Manila Times|date=January 4, 2018}}</ref> The fire destroyed most of Aguilar's valuables estimated at around {{Philippine peso|1.5 million}}, including his art collection, awards, musical instruments, records, and other personal memorabilia. Aguilar was at a bar along [[Tomas Morato Avenue]] during the fire. His wife, son Jonan, and mother-in-law were all inside his residence during the fire, but were able to escape unharmed with the help of their neighbors.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Enano|first1=Jhesset|title=Fire guts Freddie Aguilar’s QC house|url=https://newsinfo.inquirer.net/957296/fire-guts-freddie-aguilars-qc-house|accessdate=January 4, 2018|work=Philippine Daily Inquirer|date=January 4, 2018}}</ref>

{{expand language|topic=|langcode=es|otherarticle=Gustavo Baz Prada|date=May 2018}} [[File:Gustavo Baz Prada.jpg|thumb|Gustavo Baz.]] '''Gustavo Baz Prada''' ([[Tlalnepantla de Baz|Tlalnepantla]], 31 January 1894 – [[Mexico City]], 12 October 1987)<ref name="González 2014 p. 20">{{cite book |last=González |first=E.E.Z. |title=Historia del Pentathlón Deportivo Militarizado Universitario (1938–1988): |publisher=Zapata González, Eduardo Emiliano |year=2014 |isbn=978-607-00-8400-3 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=HgegBwAAQBAJ&pg=PA20 |language=es |access-date=May 16, 2018 |page=20}}</ref> was a distinguished Mexican politician and medical doctor. He was [[Governor of the State of Mexico]] from 1914 to 1915 and from 1957 to 1963<ref>Anzaldo, p. 255.</ref>.
== Life == Baz Prada's family moved to [[Zacatecas]] and [[Jalisco]] while he was young but he completed his education in [[Toluca]]. He then went to Mexico's Medical Military College.
In 1914 Baz Prada served as a medical doctor treating the troops of [[Vincente Navarro]]. He rose to the rank of Brigadier General in the forces of Zapatista. It was during this time he first served as governor of the state of Mexico. In 1916 he resigned his generalship to continue his medical studies.
He completed his studies in 1920 and by 1922 was on the faculty of the military medical school. In 1925 he went to the United States doing further medical studies with [[Harvard Medical School]], [[Augustan Hospital]] in Chicago and also in Rochester, New York. In 1926 and 1927 che went to France, Belgium and Germany, studying at the [[University of Paris]] among other institutions. In 1935 he was made director of Mexico's National School of Medicine.
Baz Prada was head of the [[National Autonomous University of Mexico]] (UNAM) from 1938 until 1940.<ref name="México (Ciudad). Universidad Nacional México 2001 p. 377">{{cite book |author=México (Ciudad). Universidad Nacional |last2=México |first2=U.N. |title=Compendio de legislación universitaria |publisher=Universidad Nacional Autónoma de México, Dirección General de Legislación Universitaria |year=2001 |isbn=978-968-36-9575-8 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=RG7c7E62Eb8C&pg=PA377 |language=es |access-date=May 16, 2018 |page=377}}</ref> From 1940 until 1946 he was Secretary of Health and Welfare for Mexico.
During his tenure as governor of Mexico State he brought about the founding of the State University of Mexico. He was appointed to Mexico's Supreme Council of Health in 1965.

{{Use dmy dates|date=May 2017}} {{Infobox comedian | name = Hannah Gadsby | image = Hannah Gadsby and Jason Wing - Jam Project - crop.jpg | imagesize = | caption = Hannah Gadsby in 2013. | pseudonym = | birth_name = | birth_date = | birth_place = [[Smithton, Tasmania]], Australia | medium = Live performance | nationality = Australian | active = 2006–present | genre = Stand-up | subject = Small town life, Smithton, art history, [[dysfunctional]] parents, [[homosexuality]], homophobia, mental illness, trauma | influences = | influenced = | spouse = | domesticpartner = | notable_work = Kiss Me Quick, I'm Full of Jubes
''[[Please Like Me]]'', ''[[Nanette (show)|Nanette]]'' | signature = | website = {{URL|hannahgadsby.com.au|HannahGadsby.com.au}} }} '''Hannah Gadsby''' (born 12 January 1978) is an Australian comedian and writer. She rose to prominence after winning the national final of the [[Raw Comedy]] competition for new comedians in 2006. She has toured internationally and appeared on Australian and New Zealand television. In 2018, Gadsby's Netflix special, ''[[Nanette (show)|Nanette]],'' brought her to the attention of international audiences.{{cite news|last1=Zinoman|first1=Jason|title=Introducing a Major New Voice in Comedy (Who Also Attacks Comedy)|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/03/19/arts/hannah-gadsby-comedy-nanette.html|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=19 March 2018|language=en}}{{cite news|last1=Logan|first1=Brian|title=Hannah Gadsby review – electrifying farewell to standup|url=https://www.theguardian.com/stage/2017/aug/19/hannah-gadsby-review-nanette|work=[[The Guardian]]|date=19 August 2017|language=en}} ==Early life and education== Gadsby was born and grew up in [[Smithton, Tasmania|Smithton]] in [[Tasmania]], the youngest of five children.[http://www.suchsmallportions.com/feature/hannah-gadsby-interview-%E2%80%9Ci-talk-about-my-shows-theyre-ships%E2%80%9D Hannah Gadsby interview: I talk about my shows like they're ships | Such Small Portions 10 November 2011] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140929080446/http://suchsmallportions.com/feature/hannah-gadsby-interview-%E2%80%9Ci-talk-about-my-shows-theyre-ships%E2%80%9D |date=29 September 2014 }}. Suchsmallportions.com (10 November 2011). Retrieved on 2017-05-14. She attended [[Smithton, Tasmania|Smithton High School]] from 1990 to 1995, [[Launceston College, Tasmania|Launceston College]] and the [[University of Tasmania]] in [[Hobart]]. She later graduated from the [[Australian National University]] in 2003 with a [[Bachelor of Arts]] degree in Art History and Curatorship.{{cite web|url=http://www.anu.edu.au/students/program-administration/program-management/graduate-search|title=Graduate search|date=12 November 2014|publisher=}} Before her comedy career, Gadsby worked as a cinema projectionist and as a tree planter on a farm. == Career == === Art lectures === Although Gadsby is best known for her comedy work, she has a degree in Art History and Curatorship and presents comedy art tours in conjunction with the [[National Gallery of Victoria]]. Since 2009, Gadsby has presented tours with themes such as paintings of the Holy Virgin, Dadaism, Modernism, Impressionism and the nude in art. Gadsby also gives talks on art and opens exhibitions.{{cite web | date = 20 March 2013 | author = Kylie Northover | url = http://www.theage.com.au/entertainment/art-and-design/reclining-nudes-get-standup-treatment-20130319-2gd5d.html | title = Reclining nudes get stand-up treatment | work = [[The Age]] }} Gadsby has written and presented two documentary specials for the ''Artscape'' program on ABC TV, ''The [[National Gallery of Victoria|NGV Story]]'' (2011)[http://www.screenaustralia.gov.au/find-a-film/detail.aspx?tid=30677 Hannah Gadsby: The NGV Story | Screen Australia. Retrieved 6 June 2013]. Screenaustralia.gov.au. Retrieved on 14 May 2017. and ''Hannah Gadsby Goes Domestic'' (2010).[http://www.abc.net.au/arts/stories/s2959751.htm Artscape – Hannah Gadsby Goes Domestic | ABC Arts 20 May 2011. Retrieved 6 June 2013]. Abc.net.au. Retrieved on 14 May 2017. In 2015 she wrote and performed ''Hannah Gadsby: Arts Clown'', a series for [[BBC Radio 4]] based on her comedy art shows.{{cite web | title= Hannah Gadsby: Arts Clown |url= https://www.comedy.co.uk/radio/hannah_gadsby_arts_clown/ |website=British Comedy Guide |accessdate=27 September 2018}} === Acting and presenting === Gadsby co-starred on the Australian [[ABC1|ABC television]] network show ''[[Adam Hills Tonight]]'' (formerly known as ''Adam Hills in Gordon Street Tonight''). She had regular segments called 'On This Day' and 'Hannah Has A Go' and also featured on the couch, contributing as host [[Adam Hills]] interviewed his guests.[http://www.abc.net.au/tv/adamhillsIGST/about/default.htm Adam Hills Tonight | ABC Television website. Retrieved 5 June 2013] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130604012519/http://www.abc.net.au/tv/adamhillsIGST/about/default.htm |date=4 June 2013 }} The show ceased production following the end of its third season in July 2013.[http://www.smh.com.au/entertainment/tv-and-radio/adam-hills-calls-it-quits-from-abc-series-adam-hills-tonight-20131128-2yb2n.html#ixzz2ltZguWfy Sydney Morning Herald website. Retrieved 21 October 2014]. Smh.com.au (28 November 2013). Retrieved on 2017-05-14. She has also appeared as a guest on ''[[Good News Week]],'' ''[[Spicks and Specks (TV series)|Spicks and Specks]]'', and [[TV3 (New Zealand)|New Zealand TV 3]]'s ''[[7 Days (New Zealand)|7 Days]]''. She has written and presented a three-part series on ABC TV, ''Hannah Gadsby's Oz'', which aired in March 2014.[http://www.abc.net.au/tv/programs/hannah-gadsbys-oz/ ABC TV Programs March 2014. Retrieved 21 October 2014]. Abc.net.au. Retrieved on 14 May 2017. She featured as Hannah, a fictional version of herself, in the second, third and fourth seasons of fellow comedian [[Josh Thomas (comedian)|Josh Thomas]]'s series ''[[Please Like Me]]'' in 2015. She was also a co-writer of the series. === Stand-up === As a comedian, Gadsby was a regular on the local and international comedy festival circuit for over 10 years. In 2018, [[Netflix]] released ''[[Nanette (show)|Nanette]],'' which brought her to the attention of an international audience. On [[Rotten Tomatoes]] Nanette received an approval rating of 100% based on reviews from 40 critics.{{Cite web|title=Hannah Gadsby: Nanette|url=https://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/hannah_gadsby_nanette/ |website=[[Rotten Tomatoes]] |access-date= 2018-10-18}}. ==Personal life== Gadsby is a lesbian and often refers to her sexuality in her stand-up routines.{{cite web |author= Lenny Ann Low |url = http://www.smh.com.au/entertainment/comedy/the-great-gadsby-20110211-1apth.html | title = The great Gadsby |work= Sydney Morning Herald |date= 12 February 2011 | accessdate = 2018-09-05 }}[http://tvnz.co.nz/international-comedy-festival/hannah-gadsby-comedy-festival-review-2739756 Hannah Gadsby: Comedy Festival Review | TVNZ 10 November 2011. Tvnz.co.nz. Retrieved on 14 May 2017. Gadsby is an active supporter of various charities. Organisations she has assisted include [[Big Brothers Big Sisters of America|Big Brothers Big Sisters]] of Melbourne, [[Edmund Rice Camps]] of Victoria and the [[Sacred Heart Mission]].[http://melbourne.jollypeople.com/in-stitches-for-kids/5923/#more-5923 In Stitches for Kids Charity Comedy | Jolly People.com 14 July 2010. Renounces Comedy|url=https://www.newyorker.com/podcast/the-new-yorker-radio-hour/hannah-gadsby-against-comedy-and-james-wood-on-writing-a-novel|work=[[The New Yorker]]|date=15 June 2018|format=Audio {{*}}[[Knoxville Campaign]] | awards = | laterwork = }} '''Henry Lawrence Burnett''' (December 26, 1838 – January 4, 1916) was an American lawyer and, after serving as a [[Major (military)|major]] in the [[Cavalry Corps (Union Army)]], he was a [[Colonel (United States)|colonel]] and [[Judge Advocate General's Corps (United States)|Judge Advocate]] in the [[Union Army]] during the [[American Civil War]]. He was a prosecutor in the trial that followed the [[Abraham Lincoln assassination]].{{cite book|last1=Colby, M.A.|first1=Frank Moore|title=The New International Year Book {{!}} A Compendium of the World's Progress for the year 1916|date=1917|publisher=Dodd, Mead & Company, Inc.|location=New York|page=106|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=eytNAQAAMAAJ&pg=PA106&lpg=PA106|accessdate=3 November 2017|language=en}} He was appointed to the grade of [[Brevet (military)|brevet]] [[Brigadier general (United States)|brigadier general]] of volunteers in 1866, to rank from March 13, 1865. ==Early life== Burnett was born in [[Youngstown, Ohio]], in 1838. He was the son of Henry Burnett (1801–1876), an [[abolitionist]], and Nancy ([[née]] Jones) Burnett (d. 1880).{{cite book|last1=Randall|first1=Emilius Oviatt|last2=Ryan|first2=Daniel Joseph|title=History of Ohio: The Rise and Progress of an American State|date=1912|publisher=Century History Company|pages=105–112|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=oQ8WAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA105&lpg=PA105|accessdate=3 November 2017|language=en}} His paternal grandfather, Samuel Burnett, a native of [[Morristown, New Jersey]] was, at one time, prominent and influential. He as educated had a considerable fortune, but lost most of his property during the [[American Revolutionary War|Revolutionary War]], along with [[Robert Morris (judge)|Robert Morris]], and emigrated west to Ohio around 1798.{{cite web|title=Henry Burnett - An Ohio Pioneer |url=https://www.iment.com/maida/familytree/burnett/henrysr.htm#obit|website=www.iment.com|accessdate=3 November 2017}} He was also a descendant of [[William Burnet (colonial administrator)|William Burnett]], a [[List of colonial governors of New York|colonial governor of New York]] and [[List of colonial governors of New Jersey|New Jersey]]. He was determined not to become a [[farmer]], he ran away from home to get an education. He attended [[Chester, Ohio|Chester Academy]] and, later, [[Hiram College]] where he was taught by later President [[James A. Garfield]]. In 1855, he began his studies at [[Poland Seminary|Ohio State National Law School]], in [[Poland, Ohio]], graduating in 1859. Following his graduation, he begins reading law with Judge Benjamin F. Hoffman, law partner of [[David Tod]], who later served as [[Governor of Ohio]]. He was [[admitted to the bar]] in 1860, and began practicing in [[Warren, Ohio]]. ==Career== In 1861 when the Civil War broke out, Burnett joined the [[2nd Ohio Cavalry]], where he rose to the rank of [[major (United States)|major]] in 1862. After being trampled by a horse and seriously injured in 1863, however, he transferred to the [[Judge Advocate General's Corps]] of the [[Department of the Ohio]], working for [[Joseph Holt]], the [[Judge Advocate General of the United States Army|Judge Advocate General of the U.S. Army]]. In 1865, he was appointed [[Brevet (military)|brevet]] [[Colonel (United States)|Colonel]] in the Judge Advocate Corps. ===Lincoln assassination trial=== [[File:JBingham-JHolt-HBurnett.jpg|thumb|left|340px|Henry Burnett ''(right)'' along with [[John Bingham]] ''(left)'' and [[Joseph Holt]] ''(center)'' were the three judges in charge of the Lincoln assassination trial.]][[File:Henry_Lawrence_Burnett_c1865.jpg|thumb|right|Brig. Gen. Henry Lawrence Burnett]] After the assassination of [[President of the United States|President]] [[Abraham Lincoln]] in 1865, Burnett was called upon by [[United States Secretary of War|Secretary of War]] [[Edwin Stanton]] to be an Assistant [[Judge Advocate General's Corps, U.S. Army|Judge Advocate General]]. Along with him were [[John Bingham]] and [[Joseph Holt]], the Judge Advocate General. The accused conspirators where [[George Atzerodt]], [[David Herold]], [[Lewis Powell (assassin)|Lewis Powell]], [[Samuel Arnold (Lincoln conspirator)|Samuel Arnold]], [[Michael O'Laughlen]], [[Edman Spangler]], [[Samuel Mudd]] and [[Mary Surratt]]. The trail began on May 10, 1865. The three spent nearly two months in court, awaiting a verdict from the jury. Holt and Bingham attempted to obscure the fact that there were two plots. The first plot was to kidnap Lincoln in exchange for the [[Confederate States of America|Confederate]] prisoners the [[Union (American Civil War)|Union]] had. The second was to assassinate Lincoln, [[Vice President of the United States|Vice President]] [[Andrew Johnson]] and [[United States Secretary of State|Secretary of State]] [[William H. Seward]] to throw the government into chaos. It was important for the prosecution not to reveal the existence of a [[diary]] taken from the body of Lincoln's assassin [[John Wilkes Booth]]. The diary made it clear that the assassination plan dated from 14 April. The defence surprisingly did not call for Booth's diary to be produced in court. Holt was accused of withholding evidence, but it was never proven. On June 29, the eight were found guilty for their involvement in the conspiracy to kill Lincoln. [[Samuel Arnold (Lincoln conspirator)|Arnold]], [[Michael O'Laughlen|O'Laughlen]] and [[Samuel Mudd|Mudd]] were sentenced to life in prison, [[Edman Spangler|Spangler]] six years in prison and [[George Atzerodt|Atzerodt]], [[David Herold|Herold]], [[Lewis Powell (assassin)|Paine]] and [[Mary Surratt|Surratt]] were to hang. They were executed July 7, 1865. Surratt was the first woman in American history to be executed. O'Laughlen died in prison in 1867. Arnold, Spangler, and Mudd were pardoned by [[Andrew Johnson]] in early 1869. Following the completion of the trial, in October 1865, Burnett asked to be mustered out on December 1, 1865, which was granted. Senator [[John Sherman]] and Holt asked for him to be appointed a [[Brevet (military)|brevet]] [[Brigadier general (United States)|brigadier general]], which he accepted in May 1866. On January 13, 1866, [[President of the United States|President]] [[Andrew Johnson]] nominated Burnett for appointment to the grade of brevet brigadier general of volunteers, to rank from March 13, 1865, and the [[United States Senate]] confirmed the appointment on March 12, 1866.Eicher, John H., and [[David J. Eicher]], ''Civil War High Commands.'' Stanford: Stanford University Press, 2001. {{ISBN|978-0-8047-3641-1}}. p. 741. ===Post-Civil War career=== In late 1865, he moved to [[New York City]] where he resumed the practice of law with Judge [[Thomas W. Bartley]], former [[List of Justices of the Ohio Supreme Court|Justice of the Ohio Supreme Court]] and Governor of Ohio, until 1869. Following his practice in New York, Burnett and his second wife moved back to Ohio where he then practiced law with [[Jacob Dolson Cox]], another former Governor, and [[John F. Follett]], who later served as a [[U.S. Representative]], until 1872, when he started a practice in New York with [[Edwin W. Stoughton]]. Burnett again moved to [[New York (state)|New York]], this time in [[Buffalo, New York|Buffalo]], where he served as counsel to the [[Buffalo and Erie Railroad]] (where his father-in-law was treasurer), until 1874. After the railroad, he formed several law practices in New York with various prominent men, including ''Emott, Burnett & Hammond'' (with former Judge James Emott, Henry B. Hammond, and Charles C. Emott in 1875),{{cite book|title=American Bar Association Journal|date=1917|publisher=[[American Bar Association]]|page=674|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=aQdLAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA674&lpg=PA674|accessdate=3 November 2017|language=en}}{{cite book|title=Court of Appeals: New York: 27|date=1885|publisher=W. Lowey, Law Book and Job Printer|location=New York|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=_iVQwRbIsUUC&pg=RA12-PA2&lpg=RA12-PA2|accessdate=3 November 2017|language=en}} which litigated for and against the Railways,{{cite news|title=ERIE MEETS ITS ENEMIES.; A COUNTER SUIT AGAINST M'HENRY. JUDGE DONOHUE ORDERS A STAY OF PROCEEDINGS IN THE MONROE COUNTY ACTION--M'HENRY SAID TO BE WITHOUT TANGIBLE PROPERTY--A PERMANENT INJUNCTION DEMANDED BY THE FRIENDS OF THE REORGANIZATION PLAN.|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1877/12/07/archives/erie-meets-its-enemies-a-counter-suit-against-mhenry-judge-donohue.html|accessdate=3 November 2017|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=7 December 1877}}{{cite news|title=ERIE REORGANIZATION OPPOSED.; A SUIT BEGUN BY M'HENRY AND OTHERS-- SERIOUS CHARGES MADE AGAINST RECEIVER JEWETT AND THE FARMERS' LOAN AND TRUST COMPANY--THE RELIEF APPLIED FOR.|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1877/11/25/archives/erie-reorganization-opposed-a-suit-begun-by-mhenry-and-others.html|accessdate=3 November 2017|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=25 November 1877}}{{cite book|last1=Klein|first1=Maury|title=Union Pacific: 1862 - 1893|date=2006|publisher=[[U of Minnesota Press]]|isbn=9781452908731|page=716|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ExkjGddZkRIC&pg=PA716&lpg=PA716|accessdate=3 November 2017|language=en}} ''Emott, Burnett & Kidder'' (with Camillus George Kidder in 1877),{{cite book|title=The National Cyclopaedia of American Biography|date=1898|publisher=J. T. White Company|pages=251–252|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=4NkbAAAAIAAJ&pg=PA252|accessdate=3 November 2017|language=en}}{{cite book|last1=Cutter|first1=William Richard|title=New England Families, Genealogical and Memorial: A Record of the Achievements of Her People in the Making of Commonwealths and the Founding of a Nation|date=1913|publisher=Lewis Historical Publishing Company|page=521|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ofcsAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA521|accessdate=3 November 2017|language=en}} ''Bristow, Peet, Burnett, & Opdyke'' (with [[Benjamin Bristow]], a former [[Secretary of the Treasury]], William Peet, and [[George Opdyke|W. S. Opdyke]] in 1878),{{cite web|title=Solicitor General: Benjamin H. Bristow {{!}} OSG {{!}} Department of Justice|url=https://www.justice.gov/osg/bio/benjamin-h-bristow|website=www.justice.gov|publisher=[[United States Department of Justice|Department of Justice]]|accessdate=3 November 2017|language=en}} and ''Burnett & Whitney'' (with [[Edward Baldwin Whitney]] in 1883).{{cite book|last1=Harrison|first1=Bruce|title=The Family Forest Descendants of Sir Robert Parke|isbn=9781411686304|page=238|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=eKGMUOscGoYC&pg=PA238|accessdate=3 November 2017|language=en}} He was notable involved in representing the English bondholders in the [[Emma Silver Mine]] litigation. In 1898, [[President of the United States|President]] [[William McKinley]], his close friend, appointed Burnett federal [[district attorney]] for the southern district of [[New York (state)|New York]].{{cite news|title=HENRY L. BURNETT'S CAREER.; A Lawyer, Soldier, and Public Man Since the Time of the War.|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1898/01/06/archives/henry-l-burnetts-career-a-lawyer-soldier-and-public-man-since-the.html|accessdate=3 November 2017|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=January 6, 1898}} Upon completion of his four-year term, he was reappointed by McKinley's successor, [[Theodore Roosevelt]], for another four-year term in 1901, which he served in until his retirement in 1906. ==Personal life== On October 27, 1858, Burnett married Grace "Kitty" Hoffman (1842–1864), the daughter of Benjamin F. Hoffman, a judge. Together, they were the parents of:{{cite web|title=Timeline of the Life of Brigadier General Henry Lawrence Burnett (1838-1916)|url=http://www.iment.com/maida/familytree/burnett/burnetttimeline.htm|website=www.iment.com|accessdate=3 November 2017}} * Grace Hoffman Burnett (1860–1945), who married Baron [[:de:Victor von Oertzen|Victor Siegmund von Oertzen]] (1854–1934), a [[Generalmajor|Maj. Gen.]] in the [[Imperial German army]], in 1878.{{cite news|title=Baron Victor Von Oertzen was married, in Paris recently to Miss Grace Hoffman Burnett of New YorK|url=https://www.newspapers.com/newspage/83258288/|accessdate=3 November 2017|work=Record of the Times|date=November 4, 1878|page=3|language=en}}{{cite news|title=BERLIN IS SHOCKED BY ARMY KILLINGS; Survivor of Execution of 29 Marines Testifies at Lieut. Marloh's Trial. FLED FROM A PILE OF DEAD Reinhardt's Adjutant Charged with Forcing the Accused Officer to Disappear. Tells of Wholesale Executions. BERLIN IS SHOCKED BY ARMY KILLINGS Says Reinhardt Condemned Him. Lieutenant Spirited Away. Says Kessel Claimed Big Backing. Reinhardt Reported Out of Army.|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1919/12/08/archives/berlin-is-shocked-by-army-killings-survivor-of-execution-of-29.html|accessdate=3 November 2017|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=8 December 1919}} His sister, Baroness Felicioas von Oertzen was married to William H. Barber in 1890.{{cite news|title=WILLIAM H. BARBER.; Pianist and Teacher Headed Music Department of Stamford School.|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1934/02/10/archives/william-h-barber-pianist-and-teacher-headed-music-department-of.html|accessdate=3 November 2017|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=10 February 1934}} She died, childless, in [[Bad Doberan]]. * Catharine "Kitty" Cleveland Burnett (b. 1864), After his first wife's death in 1864, he married Sarah Gibson Lansing (1846–1877), the daughter of Brig. Gen. Henry Livingston Lansing (1818–1889), treasurer of the [[Buffalo and Erie Railroad]], and Catharine Olivia ([[née]] Gibson) Lansing (1818–1897), on September 4, 1867. Her paternal grandfather was [[Abraham G. Lansing|Barent Bleecker Lansing]] and her maternal grandparents were Henry Bicker Gibson (1783-1863), banker and president of the [[Rochester and Syracuse Railroad]], and one of the richest men in [[Western New York]], and Sarah (née Sherman) Gibson (herself the aunt of [[William Watts Sherman]]). Before her death in 1877, they were the parents of: * Catherine Olivia Gibson Burnett (1873–1934), who married Robert Jewett Mercur (1854–1929) in 1895. They divorced and she married John Evans Bell (1864–1952). Her last marriage was to Robert Meade Van Deusen.{{cite web|title=Major Bradley T. Van Deusen|url=https://www.iment.com/maida/family/father/index.htm|website=www.iment.com|accessdate=3 November 2017}} * Lansing Burnett (1869–1893), who died unmarried. After his second wife's death and burial at [[Forest Lawn Cemetery, Buffalo]] in 1877, he married for the third and final time to [[Agnes Suffern Tailer Burnett|Agnes Suffern Tailer]] (1858–1932){{cite news|title=Mrs. H. L. Burnett|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1932/12/12/archives/exgoylleoddies-at-columbia-s-c-member-of-the-bar-of-his-native-j.html|accessdate=3 November 2017|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=12 December 1932}} on January 31, 1882 at the [[Church of the Ascension, Episcopal (Manhattan)|Church of the Ascension]] at [[Fifth Avenue]] and [[10th Street (Manhattan)|10th Street]] in Manhattan.{{cite news|title=MISCELLANEOUS CITY NEWS; A BRILLIANT WEDDING. MARRIAGE OF GEN. HERRY L. BURNETT TO MISS AGENTS S. TAILER.|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1882/02/01/archives/miscellaneous-city-news-a-brilliant-wedding-marriage-of-gen-herry-l.html|accessdate=3 November 2017|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=1 February 1882}} She was the daughter of [[Edward Neufville Tailer]], a prominent New York merchant and banker,{{cite book|last1=Henkin|first1=David M.|title=City Reading: Written Words and Public Spaces in Antebellum New York|date=1998|publisher=[[Columbia University Press]]|isbn=9780231107440|page=130|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=bfxYF1sdhJEC&pg=PA130&lpg=PA130|accessdate=3 November 2017|language=en}}{{cite web|title=TAILER, EDWARD NEUFVILLE|url=https://newyorkdiaries.com/the-diarists/tailer-edward-neufville|website=newyorkdiaries.com|publisher=New York Diaries (1609-2009)|accessdate=3 November 2017}} and the granddaughter of Thomas Suffern{{cite book|last1=Folpe|first1=Emily Kies|title=It Happened on Washington Square|date=2002|publisher=[[JHU Press]]|isbn=9780801870880|page=142|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=thWVcHVixF4C&pg=PA142&lpg=PA142|accessdate=3 November 2017|language=en}} and Edward Neufville Tailer, Sr. (descendants of [[William Tailer]], [[List of colonial governors of Massachusetts|colonial governor of Massachusetts]]).{{cite book|last1=Saint Nicholas Society of the City of New York|title=Genealogical Record of the Saint Nicholas Society: Advanced Sheets, First Series|date=1902|publisher=Society|page=61|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=_6Q-AAAAYAAJ&pg=PA61&lpg=PA61|accessdate=3 November 2017|language=en}} The guests at their wedding included Mr. and Mrs. [[William H. Vanderbilt]], [[William K. Vanderbilt|William]] and [[Alva Belmont|Alva Vanderbilt]], [[Cornelius Vanderbilt II|Cornelius]] and [[Alice Claypoole Vanderbilt]], [[W. Seward Webb|William Seward]] and [[Eliza Osgood Vanderbilt Webb|Eliza Vanderbilt Webb]], Gen. [[James Watson Webb]], [[Ogden Goelet|Ogden]] and [[Mary Wilson Goelet]], Col. and Mrs. [[Astor family|Delancey Kane]], and others. Together, they were the parents of: * Henry Lawrence Burnett, Jr. (1882–1918), a [[Columbia University]] graduate who served as a [[U.S. Marine]] aboard the ''[[Connecticut-class battleship|U.S.S. Connecticut]]'' and died after a fall down the stairs at his home.{{cite news|title=Henry Lawrence Burnett.|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1918/05/15/archives/henry-lawrence-burnett.html|accessdate=3 November 2017|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=15 May 1918}} * Edward Neufville Tailer Burnett (1885–1966), a [[Yale University]] graduate{{cite book|last1=[[Yale University]]|title=Catalogue of the Officers and Graduates of Yale University in New Haven, Connecticut, 1701-1910|date=1910|publisher=Tuttle, Morehouse & Taylor|page=236|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=0JTOAAAAMAAJ&pg=PA236&lpg=PA236|accessdate=3 November 2017|language=en}} who moved to [[Coachella, California]]. * Robert Suffern Tailer Burnett (1895–1895), who dies young. He died on January 4, 1916 at his home, 7 [[12th Street (Manhattan)|East 12th Street]], in [[New York City]].{{cite news|title=GEH. HENRY BURNETT, NOTED LAWYER, DIES; Distinguished as One of the Prosecutors of the Plotters Who Killed Lincoln. SERVED THROUGH CIVIL WAR Appointed United States District Attorney Here by McKinley and Roosevelt.|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1916/01/05/archives/gehhenry-burnett-noted-lawyer-dies-distinguished-as-one-of-the.html|accessdate=3 November 2017|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=January 5, 1916}} He had been ill for the previous year with pneumonia, traveling between his city home and country home.{{cite news|title=GEN. H. L. BURNETT, ILL, RIDES IN BAGGAGE CAR; Ex.-U.S. Attorney Lies on Cot in Journey from Goshen to City Home.|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1915/11/18/archives/gen-h-l-burnett-ill-rides-in-baggage-car-exus-attorney-lies-on-cot.html|accessdate=3 November 2017|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=18 November 1915}} After a large funeral, he was interred in [[Slate Hill Cemetery]] in Goshen.{{cite news|title=General Burnett's Funeral Today.|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1916/01/07/archives/general-burnetts-funeral-today.html|accessdate=3 November 2017|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=January 7, 1916}} ===Society life=== In 1892, both Burnett and his wife Agnes were included in [[Ward McAllister]]'s [[Ward McAllister#"The Four Hundred"|"Four Hundred"]], purported to be an index of New York's best families, published in ''[[The New York Times]]''.{{cite news|last1=McAllister|first1=Ward|title=THE ONLY FOUR HUNDRED {{!}} WARD M'ALLISTER GIVES OUT THE OFFICIAL LIST. HERE ARE THE NAMES, DON'T YOU KNOW, ON THE AUTHORITY OF THEIR GREAT LEADER, YOU UNDER- STAND, AND THEREFORE GENUINE, YOU SEE.|url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1892/02/16/108210917.pdf|accessdate=26 March 2017|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=16 February 1892|language=en}} Conveniently, 400 was the number of people that could fit into Mrs. Astor's ballroom.{{cite book|last1=Keister|first1=Lisa A.|title=Getting Rich: America's New Rich and How They Got That Way|date=2005|publisher=[[Cambridge University Press]]|isbn=9780521536677|page=36|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=5dAtJf1hmAUC&pg=PA36|accessdate=20 October 2017|language=en}} He was a member of the [[Metropolitan Club]], the [[Century Association]], [[Union Club of the City of New York|Union Club]], the [[General Society of Colonial Wars|Colonial Club]], and the Goshen Driving Club. He also served as past president of the [[Ohio Society of New York]], for four years, and the [[Military Order of the Loyal Legion of the United States|Loyal Legion]]. Seeking a country home away from the city, Burnett and his wife purchased a horse-breeding farm in [[Goshen (village), New York|Goshen, New York]], known as "Hillside Farm," where he raced his stock on the amateur circuit. The 193-acre estate was sold in 1917.{{cite news|title=Burnett Estate Sold|url=http://www.iment.com/maida/familytree/burnett/hillsidefarm.htm#sold|accessdate=3 November 2017|work=[[The Middletown Press|Middletown Times-Press]]|date=May 23, 1917}} ==Published works== * ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=j0VGAAAAYAAJ Some Incidents in the Trial of President Lincoln's Assassins]'' (1888) * ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=wLBYAAAAMAAJ Hancock's Relation to the Trial and Execution of Mrs. Surratt]'' (1888) * ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=lhtCAAAAIAAJ The Controversy between President Johnson and Judge Holt]'' (1889) ==See also== {{Portal|United States Army|American Civil War}} *[[List of American Civil War brevet generals (Union)]] ==References== {{reflist|30em}} ==External links== *{{Find a Grave|3596}} *[http://www.iment.com/maida/familytree/burnett/generalburnett.htm Site on Brig. Gen.
