{{Infobox nobility|type | name = Ivan Ratiev | title = | image = Prince Ivan Ratiev.jpg | caption = Portrait of Ratiev in military uniform | spouse = Ekaterine Bagration-Gruzinskaya | spouse-type = Wife | issue = | full name = Ivane Dimitris dze Ratishvili | noble family = [[Ratishvili]] | father = | mother = | birth_date = July 17, 1868 | birth_place = [[Oryol]], [[Russian Empire]] | death_date = April 26, 1958 | death_place = [[Tbilisi]], [[Georgian Soviet Socialist Republic]], [[Soviet Union]] | burial_date = | burial_place = | occupation = Military Officer }}
'''Ivan Dimitrievich Ratiev''' ({{lang-ru|Иван Дмитриевич Ратиев}}), also known as '''Ivane Dimitris dze Ratishvili''' ({{lang-ka|ივანე რატიშვილი}}) (July 17, 1868 – April 26, 1958) was a [[Georgia (country)|Georgian]] prince and a prominent officer of the [[Imperial Russian Army]]. Serving as a high-ranking official at the [[Winter Palace]] during the [[Russian Revolution of 1917]], Ratiev is best known for saving the [[Diamond Fund|imperial treasures]] from being looted during the revolutionary turmoil.<ref name="nkj">{{ru icon}} [http://www.nkj.ru/archive/articles/9735/ Тропинка в семейном саду] ("A Path in the Family Garden"). ''[[Nauka i Zhizn]]'', 1999: №9.</ref> Ratiev spent several years in the [[Gulag]] but had his sentence commuted, at which point he retired to [[Tbilisi]], [[Georgia (country)|Georgia]] where he remained until his death.
==Early life and career== Ivan Ratiev was born in [[Oryol]] of a branch of the Georgian princely house of [[Ratishvili]], which had emigrated to the Russian Empire in 1724. His father was an officer in the [[Imperial Russian Army|Russian army]]. Ivan Ratiev graduated from the Oryol [[Cadet Corps (Russia)|Cadet Corps]] and then from the Nikolayevsky Cavalry College. In 1890 he joined the 44th Nizhegorod Dragoon Regiment, deployed in [[Russian Georgia|Georgia]]. There he married, in 1896, Ekaterina [[Irakli Gruzinsky|Irakliyevna]], the Serene Princess [[Gruzinsky|Gruzinskaya]] (February 13, 1872 – 1917), a great-granddaughter of King [[Heraclius II of Georgia]] and a [[lady-in-waiting]] of the empress consort [[Alexandra Feodorovna (Alix of Hesse)|Alexandra Feodorovna]].<ref name="DRRI">{{ru icon}} Grebelsky, P. Kh., Dumin, S. V., Lapin, V. V. (1993), Дворянские роды Российской империи (''Noble families of Russian Empire''), vol. 4., p. 192. IPK Vesti.</ref>
==Winter Palace== Ratiev retired from army service due to a trauma sustained in a [[horse race]] at [[Tbilisi]] in 1907. He then studied at [[Académie des Beaux-Arts]] in [[Paris]] and, after his return to Russia, worked for the [[Ministry of the Imperial Court]]. He was assigned to an army cavalry unit of the [[Winter Palace]] with the rank of [[rittmeister]]. By the imperial order of December 6, 1913, he was made a lieutenant-colonel ([[podpolkovnik]]) of the Imperial Guard cavalry and an acting Police Master of the Winter Palace. Promoted to the rank of colonel in 1916, Prince Ratiev was appointed as a deputy commandant of the Winter Palace in April 1917, two months after the [[February Revolution]] overthrew the [[tsar]] [[Nicholas II of Russia|Nicholas II]].<ref name="DRRI"/>
[[File:Princess Ekaterina Gruzinskaya.jpg|thumb|upright|Ratiev's wife, Georgian princess Ekaterine Bagration-Gruzinskaya]]
During the storm of the Winter Palace by the [[Bolsheviks|Bolshevik]] [[October Revolution|revolutionaries]] on October 25, 1917, Ratiev did not flee, but ordered his guardsmen to evacuate the former imperial treasures to safer areas of the Palace. He dispatched his 16-year son Dimitri and two most trusted grenadiers to guard the secret depository, which, among other precious objects, housed the tsar's [[scepter]] incorporating the [[Orlov (diamond)|Orlov diamond]]. He then negotiated with the Bolshevik leader [[Vladimir Antonov-Ovseyenko]], who oversaw the storm of the Palace, thereby saving the treasures of the Palace from being looted and destroyed. The Soviet leadership publicly expressed their gratitude to Prince Ratiev on the pages of ''[[Izvestia]]'' (November 5, 1917) for "self-sacrificing efforts to protect and preserve the people's treasures" and appointed him the chief commandant of the Winter Palace and of all state museums and palaces of the [[Leningrad Military District|Petrograd district]].<ref name="nkj"/><ref name="DRRI"/><ref>Norman, Geraldine (1998), ''The Hermitage: The Biography of a Great Museum'', p. 150. Fromm International, {{ISBN|0-88064-190-8}}.</ref>
==Later life== In March 1919, Ratiev escorted the "golden echelon", a train carrying Russia's [[gold reserve]], upon the transfer of the Russian government from [[Petrograd]] to [[Moscow]]. The road to Moscow was uneasy, Ratiev being pressured into surrendering the train and even being fired upon at [[Tver]]. Ratiev retired from the state service shortly thereafter and worked as a translator for various organizations of Moscow for several years. His subsequent life was marred by the loss of his wife and a son, who drowned while swimming in the river.<ref name="Gogidze">{{ka icon}} Gogidze, Shalva (1987), [http://www.nplg.gov.ge/dlibrary/collect/0001/000450/File1-1.pdf "ამხანაგი თავადი" — განძეულობათა გადამრჩენი] (''"Comrade Prince" — Rescuer of the Treasures''). Tbilisi: Khelovneba.</ref>
In March 1924, Ivan Ratiev, his daughter Olga, and sister Sophia were arrested on charges of being members of "a counterrevolutionary monarchist organization." Due to his service in 1917, Ivan Ratiev's sentence of 5 years in [[Gulag]] was commuted to exile to [[Ekaterinburg]], where the family spent 3 years.<ref>{{ru icon}} [pkk.memo.ru/page%202/dvor/.../ratiev.doc О Ратиевых ("The Ratiev family")]. [[Memorial (society)|Memorial]]. Accessed January 12, 2013.</ref> In 1931, Ratiev moved to the Georgian capital of Tbilisi, where he lived as a "state pensioner" and died at the age of 90.<ref name="nkj"/><ref name="Gogidze"/>
Ratiev's daughter, Olga (died 1987), was married to the Russian [[Rurikids|Rurikid]] prince Yuri Sergeyevich Lvov (1897–1937), a grandnephew of Prince [[Georgy Lvov]], the Russian Prime Minister in 1917. Their daughter, Ekaterina, married the noted Georgian physicist Professor Vladimir Roinishvili.<ref name="nkj"/>

{{Use mdy dates|date=March 2017}} {{Infobox Governor |name=John Collins |order1 = 3rd |office1 = Governor of Rhode Island |term_start1 = May 3, 1786 |term_end1 = May 5, 1790 |predecessor1 = [[William Greene (governor)|William Greene, Jr.]] |successor1 = [[Arthur Fenner]] |office2 = Delegate to the [[Continental Congress]] from [[Rhode Island]] |term_start2 = 1778 |term_end2 = 1780 |term_start3 = 1782 |term_end3 = 1783 |birth_date = {{birth date|1717|6|8}} |birth_place = [[Newport, Rhode Island|Newport]], [[Colony of Rhode Island and Providence Plantations|Colony of Rhode Island]], [[British America]] |death_date = {{death date and age|1795|3|4|1717|6|8}} |death_place = [[Newport, Rhode Island]], U.S. }} '''John Collins''' (June 8, 1717<ref>CBD gives June 8; ''DAB'', November 1.</ref>{{spaced ndash}}March 4, 1795), was the [[List of Governors of Rhode Island|third Governor]] of the [[U.S. state]] of [[Rhode Island]] from 1786 to 1790. He was the last Independent to serve as Governor of Rhode Island until [[Lincoln Chafee]] (2011–2015).
==American Revolution== Born in [[Newport, Rhode Island|Newport]] in the [[Colony of Rhode Island and Providence Plantations]], he was the son of Samuel and Elizabeth Collins. He stood forth as a staunch advocate of the independence of the [[Thirteen Colonies]]. An admirer of [[George Washington]], he was selected by the governor of Rhode Island in 1776 to carry a letter to Washington informing him of the condition of the colony and soliciting counsel upon the best method to adopt for its defense. Later (1782) he was made bearer to the [[President of the Continental Congress|President of Congress]] of a statement of Rhode Island's reasons for rejecting the Impost Act. During the [[American Revolution]], Rhode Island was for the most part an agricultural area and as such opposed the restrictions of a national government.
In 1778, Collins represented Rhode Island in the [[Second Continental Congress]], where he served until May 1781, when he was superseded by [[William Ellery]]. He was, however, re-elected in 1782 and held the position until 1783.
==Post Revolution== Within the state the agricultural interests vigorously advocated a paper currency. Collins espoused their cause and in 1786 was elected governor. During his term in office the issuance of paper money, which had been ceased at intervals since 1750, was resumed. It was provided by law that should any creditor refuse to accept the bills of the state the debtor might secure a discharge by depositing the amount of his debt with one of the judges of the state superior court or the court of common pleas. This law led to the suit of ''[[Trevett vs. Weeden]]'', which resulted in a decision looking toward the right of courts to declare legislative enactments unconstitutional.<ref>Richman, I. B., ''Rhode Island, A Study in Separatism'', 1905, pp. 78–81.</ref>
In 1786 Collins was elected governor of Rhode Island and took office on May 3, 1786.
==Rhode Island's ratification of the U.S. Constitution==
When [[George Washington]] was inaugurated as President on April 30, 1789 Rhode Island was one of only two of the thirteen original states (along with North Carolina) not to have ratified the United States Constitution and was, technically speaking, an independent nation with Collins as it chief of state.
Anti-Federalist elements in Rhode Island, up to 1790, vigorously fought against the calling of a convention to decide upon entering the Federal Union, but in that year (January 17) gave its sanction to such a call by a majority of one vote in the General Assembly. This vote was cast by Collins, who had come to realize the importance of a Federal connection. The vote cost him his popularity and the governorship. He left office on May 5, 1790. The Rhode Island General Assembly ratified the United States Constitution on May 29.
Later in 1790 Collins was elected to the [[1st United States Congress|1st Congress]] but did not take his seat.
==Personal life==
Collins was married to Mary, daughter of John Avery of Boston, and his daughter Abigail married [[John Warren (surgeon)|John Warren]]. Collins died at Newport and was buried on his farm, "[[Brenton Neck]]", near Brenton Point in that city.
His grandson and [[namesake]], [[John Collins Covell]] (1823–1887), was a principal of the [[Virginia School for the Deaf and the Blind]] and [[West Virginia Schools for the Deaf and Blind]].
The Rhode Island Society of the [[Sons of the Revolution]] holds an annual observance of Rhode Island Independence Day (May 4) at Governor Collins' grave.

'''Juan Ibarrola Orueta''' (1900 in [[Llodio]], [[Álava]] – 1976) was a Spanish military commander who fought with the [[Second Spanish Republic|Republicans]] during the [[Spanish Civil War]]. He was a captain of the [[Civil Guard (Spain)|Civil Guard]] (''Guardia Civil''); unlike many of his fellow [[Officer (armed forces)|officers]] he rallied to the Republic when the [[Francisco Franco|Nationalist]] rising began. Featured in the [[Riff War|war in Morocco]], the coup d'état of July 1936 that led to the Civil War he was captain of the Guardia Civil in [[Bilbao]] and took command of a column to expel the rebels from the province of Álava without success.
He was unusual in the Republican Army as he was [[Roman Catholic Church|Catholic]], but he was also a [[Basque people|Basque]] and the Basques had generally rallied to the Republic. He was a medical instructor before the war.
He fought in the north of Spain, was promoted to command the 50th Division, and commanded the XI Army Corps at [[Battle of Teruel|Teruel]].<ref>[http://www.sbhac.net/Republica/Personajes/Militares/Militares3.htm Memoria - República - Personajes - Militares 3<!-- Bot generated title -->] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070208160736/http://www.sbhac.net/Republica/Personajes/Militares/Militares3.htm |date=2007-02-08 }} {{es icon}}</ref>

After graduating from [[University of Tokyo|Tokyo Imperial University]] (currently ''University of Tokyo''), he played for [[Sankyo Pharmaceuticals SC|Sankyo Pharmaceuticals]]. He also played for [[University of Tokyo LB]] was consisted of his alma mater University of Tokyo players and graduates. At University of Tokyo LB, he won [[1949 Emperor's Cup]] with [[Masao Ono]] and so on. ==National team career== In March 1951, when Arima was 33 years old, he was elected [[Japan national football team|Japan national team]] for Japan team first game after [[World War II]], [[Football at the 1951 Asian Games|1951 Asian Games]]. District No.448{{cite web|title=People's Deputy of Ukraine of the II convocation|url=http://w1.c1.rada.gov.ua/pls/radan_gs09/d_ank_arh?kod=52402|website=Official portal|publisher=[[Verkhovna Rada|Verkhovna Rada of Ukraine]]|accessdate=22 December 2014|language=Ukrainian}} | term_start4 = May 10, 1994 | term_end4 = July 15, 1994 }} '''Leonid Danylovych Kuchma''' ({{lang-uk|Леоні́д Дани́лович Ку́чма}}; born 9 August 1938) is a Ukrainian politician who was the [[President of Ukraine#List of Presidents of Ukraine|second President]] of independent [[Ukraine]] from 19 July 1994 to 23 January 2005. Kuchma took office after winning the [[Ukrainian presidential election, 1994|1994 presidential election]] against his rival, the incumbent [[Leonid Kravchuk]]. Kuchma won re-election for an additional five-year term in [[Ukrainian presidential election, 1999|1999]]. His presidency was surrounded by numerous corruption scandals and the lessening of media freedoms. Corruption accelerated after Kuchma's election in 1994, but in 2000–2001, his power began to weaken in the face of exposures in the media.Adrian Karatnycky, "Ukraine's Orange Revolution," ''Foreign Affairs,'' Vol. 84, No. 2 (Mar. – Apr., 2005), pp. 35–52 [https://www.jstor.org/stable/20034274 in JSTOR] On his watch the [[Economy of Ukraine|Ukrainian economy]] continued to decline until 1999, whereas growth was recorded since 2000, bringing relative prosperity to some segments of urban residents. During his presidency, [[Russia–Ukraine relations|Ukrainian-Russian ties]] began to improve.Robert S. Kravchuk, "Kuchma as Economic Reformer," ''Problems of Post-Communism'' Vol. 52#5 September–October 2005, pp 48–58 After a successful career in the machine-building industry of the [[Soviet Union]], Kuchma began his political career in [[Ukrainian parliamentary election, 1990|1990, when he was elected]] to the [[Verkhovna Rada]] (the Ukrainian parliament); he was [[Ukrainian parliamentary election, 1994|re-elected in 1994]].{{cite web |title=Profile: Leonid Kuchma |publisher=BBC |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/2283925.stm |date=26 September 2002}} He served as [[Ukrainian Prime Minister]] between October 1992 and September 1993. From July 2014 until October 2018 Kuchma was a special presidential representative of Ukraine at the semi-official peace talks regarding the ongoing [[War in Donbass]]. ==Early life== Leonid Kuchma was born in the village of [[Chaikine]] in rural [[Chernihiv Oblast]].{{Cite web|title = Leonid Kuchma {{!}} president of Ukraine|url = http://global.britannica.com/biography/Leonid-Kuchma|website = Encyclopædia Britannica|access-date = 2016-01-13}} His father Danylo Prokopovych Kuchma (1901–1942) was wounded in [[World War II]] and eventually died of his wounds in the field hospital #756 (near the village of Novoselytsia) when Leonid was four.{{Cite web|title = single {{!}} The Jamestown Foundation|url = http://www.jamestown.org/single/?tx_ttnews%255Btt_news%255D=11795&tx_ttnews%255BbackPid%255D=213&no_cache=1#.VlNnVPmrTIU|website = www.jamestown.org|access-date = 2016-01-13}}{{Cite web|title = Engology,Engineer, Leonid Kuchma - President of the Ukraine,|url = http://www.engology.com/eng5kuchma.htm|website = www.engology.com|access-date = 2016-01-13}}{{dead link|date=January 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} His mother Paraska Trokhymivna Kuchma worked at a [[kolhoz]]. Kuchma attended the Kostobobrove general education school in the neighboring [[Semenivka Raion, Chernihiv Oblast|Semenivka Raion]]. Later he enrolled in [[Dnipropetrovsk National University]] and graduated in 1960 with a degree in [[mechanical engineering]] (majoring in [[aerospace engineering]]).{{Cite news|title = Profile: Leonid Kuchma|url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/2283925.stm|newspaper = BBC|date = 2002-09-26|access-date = 2016-01-13}} The same year he joined the [[Communist Party of Soviet Union]].{{Cite news|title = UKRAINIANS ELECT A NEW PRESIDENT|url = https://www.nytimes.com/1994/07/12/world/ukrainians-elect-a-new-president.html|newspaper = The New York Times|date = 1994-07-12|access-date = 2016-01-13|issn = 0362-4331|first = Steven|last = Erlanger}} Kuchma is a [[Candidate of Sciences|candidate of technical sciences]]. In 1967 Kuchma married Lyudmyla.[http://en.itar-tass.com/world/735058 First ladies of Ukraine], [[ITAR-TASS]] (6 June 2014) ==Career== After graduation, Kuchma worked in the field of [[aerospace engineering]] for the [[Yuzhnoye Design Bureau]] in [[Dnipropetrovsk]]. At 28 he became a testing director for the Bureau deployed at the [[Baikonur cosmodrome]]. Some political observers suggested that Kuchma's early career was significantly boosted by his marriage to [[:uk:Кучма Людмила Миколаївна|Lyudmila Talalayeva]], an adopted daughter of Gennadiy Tumanov, the [[Yuzhmash]] chief engineering officer and later the Soviet Minister of Medium Machine Building.[[:uk:Бондаренко Костянтин Петрович|Бондаренко К.]] ''Леонід Кучма: портрет на фоні епохи.'' «Фоліо». Харків, 2007; стр. 21[http://www.unian.net/rus/news/news-203117.html Деньги к деньгам: браки в украинской политике (UNIAN, 12 July 2007)]. Unian.net. Retrieved on 6 August 2011. At 38 Kuchma became the Communist party chief at [[Yuzhmash|Yuzhny Machine-building Plant]] and a member of the Central Committee of the [[Communist Party (Bolshevik) of Ukraine|Communist Party of Ukraine]]. He was a delegate of the 27th and 28th Congresses of the Communist Party of Soviet Union. By the end of the 1980s, Kuchma openly criticized the Communist Party.{{cite web| title=Profile: Leonid Kuchma |publisher=[[BBC]]| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/486472.stm| date=29 October 1999}} In 1982 Kuchma was appointed the first deputy of general [[design engineer]] at Yuzhmash, and from 1986 to 1992, he held the position of the company's general director. [[Ukrainian parliamentary election, 1990|From 1990]] to 1992, Kuchma was a member of the [[Verkhovna Rada]] (Ukraine's parliament). In 1992 he was appointed as [[Prime Minister of Ukraine]]. He resigned a year later, complaining of "slow pace of reform". He was [[Ukrainian parliamentary election, 1994|re-elected into parliament in 1994]]. ==President (1994–2005)== {{Expand section|date=March 2013}} Kuchma resigned from the position of [[Prime Minister of Ukraine]] in September 1993 to run for the [[Ukrainian presidential election, 1994|presidency in 1994]] on a platform to boost the economy by restoring economic relations with Russia and faster [[market economy|pro-market reforms]]. Kuchma won a clear victory against the incumbent President [[Leonid Kravchuk]], receiving strong support from the industrial areas in the east and south. His worst results were in the west of the country. Kuchma was [[Ukrainian presidential election, 1999|re-elected in 1999]] to his second term. This time the areas that gave him strongest support last time voted for his opponents, and the areas which voted against him last time came to his support. During Kuchma's Presidency, he closed opposition papers and several journalists died in mysterious circumstances.[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/country_profiles/1102303.stm#media "Country profile: Ukraine"], [[BBC News]] According to historian [[Serhy Yekelchyk]] President Kuchma's administration "employed electoral fraud freely" during the [[Ukrainian constitutional referendum, 2000|2000 constitutional referendum]] and 1999 presidential elections.[https://books.google.com/books?id=_KRBCgAAQBAJ&pg=PA87&dq=Ukrainian+constitutional+referendum+election+fraud+2000&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjtwbHUpszaAhXQDuwKHeJqBJsQ6AEIJDAA#v=onepage&q=Ukrainian%20constitutional%20referendum%20election%20fraud%202000&f=false ''The Conflict in Ukraine: What Everyone Needs to Know''] by [[Serhy Yekelchyk]], [[Oxford University Press]], 2015, {{ISBN|0190237287}} (page 87) File:Вибори 1994.png|Results in the Second round of the [[Ukrainian presidential election, 1994|1994 presidential election]]: Blue – Leonid Kuchma, orange – [[Leonid Kravchuk]] File:Вибори 1999.png|Results in the Second round of the [[Ukrainian presidential election, 1999|1999 presidential election]]: Blue – Leonid Kuchma, red – [[Petro Symonenko]] ===Domestic policy=== In October 1994, Kuchma announced comprehensive economic reforms, including reduced [[subsidies]], lifting of price controls, lower taxes, [[privatization]] of industry and agriculture, and reforms in currency regulation and banking. The parliament approved the plan's main points. The [[International Monetary Fund]] (IMF) promised a $360 million loan to initiate reforms. He was re-elected in 1999 to his second term. Opponents accused him of involvement in the killing in 2000 of journalist [[Georgiy Gongadze]] (see also [[Security Service of Ukraine|SBU]], "[[Cassette Scandal]]", [[Mykola Mel'nychenko]]), which he has always denied. Critics also blamed Kuchma for restrictions on press freedom. Kuchma is believed to have played a key role in sacking the [[Cabinet of Ministers of Ukraine|Cabinet]] of [[Viktor Yushchenko]] by [[Verkhovna Rada]] on 26 April 2001. Kuchma's [[Prime Minister of Ukraine|Prime Minister]] from 2002 until early January 2005 was [[Viktor Yanukovych]], after Kuchma dismissed [[Anatoliy Kinakh]], his previous appointee. ===Foreign policy=== [[Image:Vladimir Putin at CIS Summit 30 November-1 December 2000-2.jpg|thumb|President [[Vladimir Putin]] with Leonid Kuchma, in the centre, and Azeri President [[Heydar Aliyev]] before an expanded meeting of the [[Commonwealth of Independent States|CIS]] Council of Heads of State.]] In 2002 Kuchma stated that Ukraine wanted to sign an association agreement with the [[European Union]] (EU) by 2003–2004 and that Ukraine would meet all EU membership requirements by 2007–2011.[http://ukrainianweek.com/Politics/73494 EU-Ukraine Summits: 16 Years of Wheel-Spinning], ''[[The Ukrainian Week]]'' (28 February 2012) He also hoped for a [[free-trade]] treaty with the EU. In his inaugural address Kuchma said: {{quote|Historically, Ukraine is part of the Euro-Asian cultural and economics space. Ukraine's vitally important national interests are now concentrated on this territory of the former Soviet Union. ... We are also linked with... the former republics of the Soviet Union by traditional scientific, cultural and family ties... I am convinced that Ukraine can assume the role of one of the leaders of Euro-Asian economic integration.'Leonid Kuchma sklav prysiagu na virnist' ukrains'komu narodovy', Holos Ukrainy, 21 July 1994.}} Kuchma signed a "Treaty of Friendship, Cooperation, and Partnership" with Russia, and endorsed a round of talks with the [[Commonwealth of Independent States|CIS]]. Additionally, he referred to Russian as "an official language". He signed a special partnership agreement with [[NATO]] and raised the possibility of membership of the alliance. After Kuchma's popularity at home and abroad sank as he became mired in corruption scandals, he turned to Russia as his new ally. He said that Ukraine needed a "multivector" foreign policy that balanced eastern and western interests{{Citation needed|date=March 2011}}. ===Kuchma and the Cassette Scandal=== {{see also|Cassette Scandal}} From 1998 to 2000, Kuchma's bodyguard [[Mykola Melnychenko]] was allegedly eavesdropping Kuchma's office, later publishing the recordings. The release of the tapes – dubbed "Kuchmagate" by the Ukrainian press – supposedly revealed Kuchma's numerous crimes. In particular, his approving the sale of radar systems to [[Saddam Hussein]] (among other illegal arms sales) and ordering the Ukraine's police minister to "take care" of the journalist [[Georgiy Gongadze]]. [[File:Ukraine Without Kuchma 6 February.jpg|thumbnail|[[Ukraine Without Kuchma]] protests. 6 February 2001.]] In September 2000, Gongadze disappeared and his headless corpse was found mutilated on 3 November 2000. On 28 November, the opposition politician [[Oleksandr Moroz]] publicised the tape recordings implicating Kuchma in Gongadze's murder. In 2005 the Ukrainian Prosecutor General's office instigated criminal proceedings against Kuchma and members of his former administration in connection with the murder of Gongadze.[https://archive.is/20051213221657/http://www.mosnews.com/news/2005/10/09/caseagainstkuchma.shtml Mosnews.com] In 2005 the press reported that Kuchma had been unofficially granted immunity from prosecution in return for his graceful departure from office in 2005.Crouch, David (6 April 2005). [http://www.guardian.co.uk/media/2005/apr/06/pressandpublishing.ukraine "Secrets of journalist's murder cast long shadow over Ukraine's orange revolution"], ''The Guardian''. Retrieved on 6 August 2011.{{cite web|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/europe/2011/03/2011324153540928659.html |publisher=Al Jazeera |title=Ukraine ex-leader charged over murder |date=24 March 2011 |accessdate=24 March 2011}} Critics of the tape point to the difficulty of Melnychenko recording 500 hours of dictaphone tape unaided and undetected, the lack of material evidence of said recording equipment, and other doubts which question the authenticity and motive of the release of the tape. Kuchma acknowledged in 2003 that his voice was one of those on the tapes, but claimed the tapes had been selectively edited to distort his meaning.[https://books.google.com/books?id=NI1G_9j1AhcC&pg=PA504&dq=Kuchma+edited&hl=nl&sa=X&ei=k6gET6P_DZGSOrKj4aIB&ved=0CDMQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=Kuchma%20edited&f=false ''Eastern Europe, Russia and Central Asia 2004]'', ([[Europa Publications]]), [[Routledge]], December 12, 2003, {{ISBN|1-85743-187-1}} (page 504) The [[General Prosecutor of Ukraine]]'s Office canceled its resolution to deny opening of criminal cases against Kuchma and other politicians within the Gongadze-case on 9 October 2010.[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/politics/detail/85674/ "Prosecutor general's office can open criminal cases against former President Leonid Kuchma and other politicians"], ''[[Kyiv Post]]'' (October, 2010) On 22 March 2011, Ukraine opened an official investigation into the murder of Gongadze and, two days later, Ukrainian prosecutors charged Kuchma with involvement in the murder.{{Cite journal|title=Ukraine's ex-president: Catching Kuchma|journal=The Economist|volume=399|issue=8727|page=25|date=2–8 April 2011|url=http://www.economist.com}}[https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-12821790 "Ukraine's ex-leader Kuchma probed over Gongadze murder"], BBC News (22 March 2011). Retrieved on 6 August 2011. A Ukrainian district court ordered prosecutors to drop criminal charges against Kuchma on 14 December 2011 on grounds that evidence linking him to the murder of Gongadze was insufficient.[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/politics/detail/118929/ "Court clears Kuchma of Gongadze murder charges"], ''[[Kyiv Post]]'' (14 December 2011) The court rejected Melnychenko's recordings as evidence.[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/politics/detail/118919/ "Court rejects Melnychenko's tapes as evidence in Gongadze case"], ''[[Kyiv Post]]'' (14 December 2011) Gongadze's widow [[Myroslava Gongadze]] lodged an appeal against the ruling one week later.[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/politics/detail/119389/ "Gongadze's widow appeals closure of criminal case against Kuchma"], ''[[Kyiv Post]]'' (21 December 2011) During the trial of [[Oleksiy Pukach]], he claimed that Kuchma and (Kuchma's head of his [[Presidential Administration of Ukraine|Presidential Administration]], [[Volodymyr Lytvyn]]) were the ones who ordered the murder of Gongadze.[http://www.kyivpost.com/content/ukraine/court-gives-pukach-life-sentence-for-murdering-gongadze-disregards-contract-murder-319519.html "Court sentences Pukach to life for murdering Gongadze, disregards claims against Kuchma, Lytvyn"], ''[[Kyiv Post]]'' (29 January 2013)
[https://www.reuters.com/article/2013/01/29/ukraine-gongadze-sentence-idUSL5N0AYEEJ20130129 "Ukraine police officer accuses ex-president after being jailed for life"], [[Reuters]] (29 January 2013)
[http://news.liga.net/video/politics/803761-ubiytsa_gongadze_ukazal_na_kuchmu_i_litvina_video_iz_suda.htm Gongadze killer pointed on Kuchma and Lytvyn]. "LIGABusinessInform". 2013-1-29[https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/europe/ukraine/8733551/Former-policeman-carried-out-Georgiy-Gongadze-murder-on-behalf-of-Leonid-Kuchma.html "Former policeman 'carried out Georgiy Gongadze murder on behalf of Leonid Kuchma'"], ''[[Telegraph.co.uk]]'' (1 September 2011) Pukach was convicted and sentenced to life for his part in the murder of Gongadze. First Deputy [[Prosecutor General of Ukraine]] [[Renat Kuzmin]] claimed 20 February 2013 that his office had collected enough evidence confirming Kuchma's responsibility for ordering Gongadze's assassination.[https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-21525593 Ukraine's Leonid Kuchma 'implicated' in Gongadze death], [[BBC news]] (20 February 2013)
[http://www.kyivpost.com/content/ukraine/kuchma-outraged-by-reports-alleging-his-arrest-320725.html Kuchma outraged by reports alleging his arrest], [[Kyiv Post]] (21 February 2013) Kuchma's reply the next day was, "This is another banal example of a provocation, which I've heard more than enough in the past 12 years". ===Role in the election crisis of 2004=== Kuchma's role in the [[Ukrainian presidential election, 2004|election crisis of 2004]] is not entirely clear. After the second round on 22 November 2004, it appeared that Yanukovych had won the election by fraud, which caused the opposition and independent observers to dispute the results, leading to the [[Orange Revolution]]. Kuchma was urged by Yanukovych and [[Viktor Medvedchuk]] (the head of the presidential office) to declare a [[state of emergency]] and hold the inauguration of Yanukovych. He denied the request. Later, Yanukovych publicly accused Kuchma of a betrayal. Kuchma refused to officially dismiss Prime Minister Yanukovych after the parliament passed a [[motion of no confidence]] against the Cabinet on 1 December 2004. Soon after, Kuchma left the country. He returned to Ukraine in March 2005. Kuchma said in October 2009 he would vote for Victor Yanukovych at the [[Ukrainian presidential election, 2010]].[http://www.kyivpost.com/nation/50751 Kuchma says he'll vote for Yanukovych as Ukraine's president], ''[[Kyiv Post]]'' (16 October 2009) In a document dated 2 February 2010 uncovered during the [[United States diplomatic cables leak]], Kuchma in conversation with [[United States Ambassador to Ukraine]] [[John F. Tefft]], called the voters' choice between Yanukovych and [[Yulia Tymoshenko]] during the second round of the 2010 presidential election as a choice between "bad and very bad" and praised (the candidate eliminated in the first round of the election) [[Arseniy Yatsenyuk]] instead.[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/nation/detail/92047/ "Kuchma: Yanukovych-Tymoshenko contest a choice between 'bad and very bad'"], ''Kyiv Post'' (3 December 2010) In September 2011 Kuchma stated that he believed that Yanukovych was the real winner of the 2004 election.[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/politics/detail/113012/ Kuchma: Orange Revolution defines Ukrainians as Europeans], [[Kyiv Post]] (17 September 2011) ==Post-presidency== Leonid Kuchma has been active in politics since his presidency ended. He aligned himself with President Viktor Yushchenko in 2005,{{Cite news|title = Kuchma backs Yushchenko in Ukraine turmoil|url = http://www.ft.com/intl/cms/s/0/af8c01b8-2329-11da-86cc-00000e2511c8.html#axzz3ssVRmPKn|newspaper = Financial Times|date = 2005-09-12|access-date = 2016-01-13|issn = 0307-1766|first = Tom|last = Warner}} but later raised concerns about the president in correspondence with then U.S. Ambassador to the Ukraine, [[John F. Tefft|John Tefft]].{{Cite web|title = WikiLeaks: Former President Leonid Kuchma with U.S. Ambassador John Tefft|url = http://www.kyivpost.com/content/politics/wikileaks-former-president-leonid-kuchma-with-us-a-97487.html|website = KyivPost|access-date = 2016-01-13}} Kuchma endorsed Yanukovych for president in 2010.{{Cite web|title = Kuchma campaigns for Yanukovych as president of Ukraine|url = http://www.kyivpost.com/content/politics/kuchma-campaigns-for-yanukovych-as-president-of-uk-58644.html|website = KyivPost|access-date = 2016-01-13}} === Involvement in the 2014 pro-Russian conflict in Ukraine === {{main|2014 pro-Russian conflict in Ukraine}} Kuchma represented Ukraine at negotiations with the [[War in Donbass|armed separatist in the Donetsk and Luhansk provinces]] on 21 June 2014 to discuss President [[Petro Poroshenko]] [[2014 pro-Russian conflict in Ukraine#Fifteen-point peace plan|peace plan]].{{cite web|title=NSDC Says Medvedchuk not Representing Ukraine at Peace Plan Talks|url=http://www.ukrinform.net/rubric-politics/1677760-nsdc_says_medvedchuk_not_representing_ukraine_at_peace_plan_talks_323058.html|website=Ukrinform|date=24 June 2014}}{{cite news|last1=Birnbaum|first1=Michael|title=Separatists in Ukraine Agree to Honor Cease-fire|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/europe/separatists-in-ukraine-agree-to-honor-cease-fire/2014/06/23/40582a78-fb07-11e3-b1f4-8e77c632c07b_story.html|work=The Washington Post|date=23 June 2014}} His role as a diplomat has been received positively by the west and Russia as well as the public in Ukraine.{{Cite web|title = From Disgraced President to Ukraine's Lead Diplomat: The Unlikely Redemption of Leonid Kuchma|url = http://www.huffingtonpost.com/samuel-ramani/from-disgraced-president-_b_8130424.html|website = The Huffington Post|access-date = 2016-01-13}} On 11, February 2015, Kuchma was one of the signatories of a draft plan to end the conflict in Donbas. The summit was known as [[Minsk II]]. The plan ensured that a ceasefire was implemented and reaction from leaders in Europe was generally positive.{{Cite web|title = Ukraine crisis: Leaders agree peace roadmap - BBC News|url = https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-31435812|website = BBC News|access-date = 2016-01-13|language = en-GB}} In March 2015, Kuchma delivered an address and called on the west for greater involvement in the region.{{Cite news|title = Ukraine's Kuchma Says West Too Soft On Russia Over Debaltseve|url = http://www.rferl.org/content/kuchma-ukraine-russia-cease-fire/26883682.html|newspaper = RadioFreeEurope/RadioLiberty|date = 2015-03-05|access-date = 2016-01-13}} He criticized the action of Russian backed forces in the attempt to seize the town of [[Debaltseve]].{{Cite web|title = Ukraine crisis: 'Dozens killed' in east as Minsk talks held - BBC News|url = https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-31074772|website = BBC News|access-date = 2016-01-13|language = en-GB}} Kuchma decommissioned the Chernobyl power plant's reactor.{{when|date=July 2017}}{{citation needed|date=July 2017}} In September, 2015 Kuchma was again appointed as the representative for Ukraine at the [[Trilateral Contact Group on Ukraine|Trilateral Contact Group]]. The group met in [[Belarus]] to discuss ending the conflict in Donbas. The choice of Kuchma comes nearly a decade after his presidency ended. [[File:Kuchma delivering an address on Liberation Day.jpg|thumb|Kuchma delivering an address on the occasion of the Liberation Day of Ukraine in 2004.]] In early 2017, Kuchma spoke out against the transport blockade of Donbass.{{Cite news|url=http://en.interfax.com.ua/news/general/406015.html|title=Donbas blockade harmful for Ukraine - Kuchma|work=Interfax-Ukraine|access-date=2017-05-04}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.kyivpost.com/ukraine-politics/kuchma-says-donbas-blockade-harmful-ukraine.html|title=Kuchma says Donbas blockade harmful for Ukraine {{!}} KyivPost|date=2017-02-28|work=KyivPost|access-date=2017-05-04|language=en-US}} In March 2017 at the Trilateral Contact Group (TCG) in Minsk, he demanded the Russian Federation repeal their decree on the recognition of passports issued in separatist-held areas.{{Cite news|url=https://www.kyivpost.com/ukraine-politics/kyiv-insists-cancellation-separatists-ids-recognition-russia.html|title=Kyiv insists on cancellation of separatists IDs recognition by Russia {{!}} KyivPost|date=2017-03-15|work=KyivPost|access-date=2017-05-04|language=en-US}} On 2 October 2018 Kuchma stepped down as Ukraine’s representative in the Trilateral Contact Group due to his age.[https://www.unian.info/politics/10279581-ukraine-s-envoy-to-minsk-talks-kuchma-going-to-quit.html Ukraine's envoy to Minsk talks Kuchma going to quit], [[UNIAN]] (29 September 2018)
[https://www.unian.info/politics/10283586-kuchma-concludes-work-as-ukraine-s-envoy-to-minsk-talks.html Kuchma concludes work as Ukraine's envoy to Minsk talks], [[UNIAN]] (02 October 2018) [[Oleksandr Omelchenko]] – long-term [[Mayor of Kiev|governor and mayor of Kiev]] ===Business oligarchs and managers of important state-owned companies=== * [[Ihor Bakai]] – [[business oligarch]], later head of [[Naftogas|Naftogas of Ukraine]] national gas and oil company, then Head of the State Accommodation Department, escaped to Russia after the fall of Kuchma's regime, refusing to return permanently * [[Heorhiy Kirpa]] – long-term head of the [[Ukrzaliznytsia]] national railways, then Minister of Transportation, committed [[suicide]] after the fall of Kuchma's regime * [[Viktor Pinchuk]] – second son-in-law, Jewish [[business oligarch]] in control of several important media ==Family and personal life== {{Expand section|date=March 2013}} Leonid Kuchma is married to Lyudmyla Kuchma since 1967. She is the Honorary President of the National Fund of Social Protection of Mothers and Children, "Ukraine to Children"{{cite web|title=About Us: Kuchma, Ludmila Molaivna|url=http://www.ukraine-children.org.ua/eng/about/1|website=Ukraine for Children|date=2004}} and is also known as a [[Ukraine at the Paralympics|paralympic movement in Ukraine]] supporter. Kuchma's only child, daughter [[Olena Pinchuk]], is married to [[Viktor Pinchuk]], a Jewish industrialist and philanthropist whose [[Victor Pinchuk Foundation]] regularly hosts Ukraine-dedicated and philanthropic fora at the annual [[World Economic Forum]] in [[Davos]]. Olena Pinchuk has a son Roman (born in 1991, from her previous marriage with Ukrainian businessman Igor Franchuk) who attends [[Brown University]], and two daughters with Viktor Pinchuk, Katerina (born in 2003) and Veronica (2011). Olena Pinchuk founded the [[ANTIAIDS Foundation]] in 2003.[http://antiaids.org/en/about/publications/440/831 "Elena Franchuk ANTIAIDS Foundation : The daughter of Kuchma will be fighting against AIDS and her husband Pinchuk will provide his media support"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110811135314/http://antiaids.org/en/about/publications/440/831 |date=11 August 2011 }}, Antiaids.org (28 November 2003), Retrieved on 6 August 2011 According to the Ukrainian magazine ''Focus,'' Olena Pinchuk was amongst the "top 10 most influential women" in Ukraine as of 2010.[http://focus.ua/charts/156273 100 самых влиятельных женщин Украины. Рейтинг Фокуса], Focus.ua. Retrieved on 6 August 2011. Victor Pinchuk recently made headlines when it was revealed that one of his lobbyists was previously picked by Donald Trump for national security aide.{{Cite web|url=https://foreignpolicy.com/2017/03/14/trump-national-security-aide-registers-as-foreign-agent-for-ukrainian-oligarch-monica-crowley-plagiarism-scandal-victor-pinchuk-ukraine-billionaire/|title=One-Time Trump National Security Pick Registers As Foreign Agent for Ukrainian Oligarch|website=Foreign Policy|access-date=2017-05-04}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/americas/us-politics/monica-crowley-donald-trump-white-house-plaguarism-pro-russia-ukrainian-oligarch-victor-pinchuk-a7631526.html|title=Woman loses job with Trump, gets one with Ukrainian billionaire|date=2017-03-15|work=The Independent|access-date=2017-05-04|language=en-GB}} It was also revealed that his Foundation made significant contributions to both Trump and Clinton campaigns.{{Cite news|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-3963204/Trump-foundation-received-150-000-donation-Ukrainian-oligarch-exchange-Donald-s-2015-Ukraine-speech.html|title=Trump foundation received $150,000 donation from Ukrainian oligarch|work=Mail Online|access-date=2017-05-04}} Kuchma was an amateur guitar player in his younger years. He was also known for his skill at the complicated [[card game]] ''[[preferans]].'' In 2003, he published his book ''[[Ukraine is not Russia]]'' ([[:uk:Україна — не Росія|uk]]). After retirement, Kuchma was allowed to keep the state-owned [[dacha]] in [[Koncha-Zaspa]] for his personal use upon completion of his state duties.[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/nation/detail/66006/ Ukrayinska Pravda exposes president’s Mezhygirya deal], ''[[Kyiv Post]]'' (6 May 2009) The government order #15-r that would allow for Kuchma to keep his estate was signed by the acting prime-minister [[Mykola Azarov]] on 19 January 2005. Kuchma was also allowed to keep his full presidential salary and all the service personnel, along with two state-owned vehicles. That order also stated that these costs would be paid out of the state budget. ==Awards== Kuchma was awarded the [[Azerbaijan]]i [[Istiglal Order]] for his contributions to [[Azerbaijan-Ukraine relations]] and strategic cooperation between the states by [[President of Azerbaijan]] [[Heydar Aliyev]] on 6 August 1999.{{cite web |url=http://e-qanun.az/print.php?internal=view&target=1&docid=3878&doctype=0 |title=Ukraynanın Prezidenti Leonid Daniloviç Kuçmanın "İstiqlal" ordeni ilə təltif edilməsi haqqında AZƏRBAYCAN RESPUBLİKASI PREZİDENTİNİN FƏRMANI |trans-title=Order of the President of Azerbaijan Republic on awarding President of Ukraine Leonid Kuchma with Istiglal Order |accessdate=20 January 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120315172736/http://e-qanun.az/print.php?internal=view&target=1&docid=3878&doctype=0 |archivedate=15 March 2012 |df=dmy-all }} ;Ukrainian Honours * Order of the Ukrainian Orthodox Church (Moscow Patriarchate) of St. Ilya of Murom, 1st class (2004) * Honorary Citizen of the [[Donetsk Oblast]] (2002) ;Foreign Honours * Knight Grand Cross with Grand Cordon of the [[Order of Merit of the Italian Republic]] (3 May 1995) * [[Order of Merit for the Fatherland]], 1st class (Russia, 20 April 2004) – for his contribution to strengthening friendship and cooperation between Russia and Ukraine * Grand Cross of the [[Order of Vytautas the Great]] (Lithuania, 20 September page.title: List of Westerners who visited Japan before 1868

revision.text:
This list contains notable Europeans and Americans who visited Japan before the [[Meiji Restoration]]. The name of each individual is followed by the year of the first visit, the country of origin, and a brief explanation.
== 16th century == * Two [[Portuguese People|Portuguese]] traders [[António Mota|António da Mota]] and Francisco Zeimoto (Possibly a third named António Peixoto) land on the island of [[Tanegashima]] in 1543. They are the first Europeans to set foot in [[Japan]]. *[[Fernão Mendes Pinto]] (1543, [[Portugal]]) Claimed to be one of the first Westerners who visited Japan and wrote about the introduction of [[guns]] to the Japanese, though the account is almost certainly untrue.<ref>Tanegashima: the arrival of Europe in Japan, Olof G. Lidin, Nordic Institute of Asian Studies, NIAS Press, 2002</ref> *[[Francis Xavier]] (1549, [[Kingdom of Spain|Spain]] (on Portuguese mission)) The first Roman [[Catholic]] missionary who brought [[Christianity]] to Japan.<ref>{{cite journal | last =Pacheco | first =Diego | title =Xavier and Tanegashima | journal = [[Monumenta Nipponica]] | volume =29 | year =Winter 1974 | issue =4 | pages =477–480 | jstor = }}</ref> *[[Cosme de Torres]] (1549, Spain) A Spanish Jesuit who successfully converted [[Ōmura Sumitada]] to Christianity – the first Christian ''[[daimyō]]''.<ref>Diego Pacheco, S. J., El hombre que forjó a Nagasaki. Vida del P. Cosme de Torres, S. J. Madrid, 1973.</ref> *[[Luís Fróis]] (1563, [[Portugal]]) A [[Jesuit]] who befriended [[Oda Nobunaga]] and published the account later.<ref>The First European Description of Japan, 1585: A Critical English-Language Edition of Striking Contrasts in the... by Luis Frois SJ, Daniel T. Reff and Richard Danford (Mar 7, 2014)</ref><ref>Biography of Luis Frois http://kotobank.jp/word/ルイス・フロイス</ref> His record still serves as an important resource for Japanese historians.<ref>大濱徹也 (2009年7月). "ルイス・フロイスが見た日本". 日本文教出版.</ref> *[[João Rodrigues (missionary)|João Rodrigues]] (1577, [[Portugal]]) A Portuguese [[Jesuit]] priest who carried out missionary work in Japan and served as an interpreter for both [[Toyotomi Hideyoshi]] and [[Tokugawa Ieyasu]]. Rodrigues is also known for authoring notable works on Japanese culture and language.<ref>Cooper, Michael. ''Rodrigues the Interpreter: An Early Jesuit in Japan and China.'' New York: Weatherhill, 1973</ref>
== 17th century == *[[William Adams (sailor)|William Adams]] (1600, England) - The first Englishman to reach Japan. The first Westerner to become a [[samurai]], under ''[[Shōgun]]'' [[Tokugawa Ieyasu]].<ref name="milton">''Samurai William: The Englishman Who Opened Japan.'' By Giles Milton</ref><ref name="lange">''Pars Japonica: The First Dutch Expedition to Reach the Shores of Japan. Brought by the English Pilot Will Adams, Hero of Shogun,'' (2006) by William de Lange.</ref> *[[Jan Joosten van Lodensteijn|Jan Joosten van Lodensteyn]] (1600, Dutch Republic) – Adams' shipmate who also became a Samurai and an advisor for the ''shōgun''. He is remembered in Japan (based on their variation of his name) in the [[Yaesu]] area of Tokyo and as Yaesu on one exit of the Tokyo Station.<ref name="milton"/><ref name="lange"/> *[[Cristóvão Ferreira]] (1609, Portugal) - A Jesuit missionary who committed [[apostasy]] after being tortured in the anti-Christian purges of Japan. His apostasy is the main theme of the novel ''[[Silence (novel)|Silence]]'' by [[Shūsaku Endō]].<ref>''The making of an enterprise: the Society of Jesus in Portugal, its empire, and beyond, 1540–1750'', Dauril Alden, Stanford University Press, 1996</ref> *[[Luis Sotelo]] (1609, Spain) – A [[Franciscan]] friar who proselytized in the [[Tōhoku region]] of Japan with the help of Daimyo [[Date Masamune]]. He was executed after re-entering Japan illegally in 1624. *[[John Saris]] (1613, England) – Captain of the English ship ''Clove'', who met with ''shōgun'' Tokugawa Ieyasu to establish a trading post in Japan. *[[Nicolaes Couckebacker]] (1633, Dutch Republic) - [[VOC Opperhoofden in Japan|VOC Opperhoofd]] (chief Dutch trader/agent) in [[Hirado]], who assisted the government in 1638 to suppress Japanese Christian rebels led by [[Amakusa Shirō]].<ref>Yasuko Suzuki, ''Japan-Netherlands Trade 1600–1800: The Dutch East India Company and Beyond''</ref> *[[Giuseppe Chiara]] (1643, Italian) - He entered Japan at a time when Christianity was strictly forbidden in an attempt to locate fellow priest Cristóvão Ferreira who had apostatized his Christian faith at the hands of torture by the Japanese authorities in 1633. Di Chiara was also tortured and eventually became an apostate as well. *[[Engelbert Kaempfer]] (1690, Dutch Republic) – A German naturalist and physician. His descriptions in ''History of Japan'' (posthumously published in English in 1727) became the chief source of Western knowledge about the country for nearly two centuries.<ref>''Kaempfer's Japan: Tokugawa Culture Observed by Engelbert Kaempfer'', Beatrice Bodart-Bailey and Beatrice M. Bodart-Bailey (1998)</ref> (Note: In 1639, the Japanese government promulgated the [[Sakoku]] policy, which prohibited foreigners from entering Japanese territory. The only exceptions were Dutch traders and associated workers permitted to live on [[Dejima]] Island. This policy lasted until 1854.)
== 18th century == *[[Giovanni Battista Sidotti]] (1700, Italy) An Italian Jesuit priest who entered Japan illegally and was arrested. His communication with the scholar [[Arai Hakuseki]] resulted in the book Seiyō Kibun.<ref>Mikkou Saigo no Bateren Sidotti. By Furui Tomoko. 2010. {{ISBN|978-4404038562}}.</ref> *[[Martin Spangberg]] visited the island of [[Honshu]] in 1738, being in command of the first Russian naval squadron specifically sent to seek for a diplomatic encounter with the Japanese. The Russians landed in a scenic area which is now part of the [[Rikuchu Kaigan National Park]]. Despite the prevalent policy of [[sakoku]], the sailors were treated with politeness if not friendliness.<ref name="Barratt">Glynn Barratt. ''Russia in Pacific Waters, 1715-1825''. UBC Press, 1981. {{ISBN|9780774801171}}. Pages 35-37.</ref> *[[Isaac Titsingh]] (1779-1784) A Dutch East India Company ("VOC") [[Opperhoofd]] at Dejima in Nagasaki Bay.<ref>Boxer, C.R. (1950) ''Jan Compagnie in Japan, 1600-1850''. Martinus Nijhoff: The Hague, p. 135.</ref> *[[Adam Laxman]] (1792, Russia) A Russian navigator who stayed in Hokkaido briefly. He was sent by [[Catherine the Great]] to return [[Daikokuya Kōdayū]] to Japan.<ref>Kodayu to Rakusuman: Bakumatsu Nichi-Ro koshoshi no ichi sokumen (Tosui rekishi zensho) (Japanese Edition) by Ryohei Kisaki (1992)</ref> *[[Carl Peter Thunberg]] (1775, Sweden) A Swedish naturalist who came as a surgeon on a Dutch East India Company ("VOC") ship. He was a follower of [[Carl Linnaeus]] whose scientific activities resulted in the first detailed description of the flora and fauna of Japan.<ref>Flora Japonica (1784)</ref> *[[Hendrik Doeff]] (1799, Dutch Republic) former Dutch East India Company ("VOC") Opperhoofd (Chief Officer) who maintained the Dutch nationality of Dejima even after [[Napoleon]] conquered the Netherlands. He presided over the Dutch East India Company ("VOC") during the Phaeton incident.<ref>"Phaeton Incident and Saga-han." by Saga Castle History Museum {{cite web |url=http://sagajou.jp/tenji/ishin.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2014-07-06 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140715010457/http://sagajou.jp/tenji/ishin.html |archivedate=2014-07-15 |df= }}</ref>
== 19th century == *[[Nikolai Rezanov]] (1804, Russia) A Russian diplomat who stayed in Nagasaki for 6 months. He was commissioned by [[Alexander I of Russia|Alexander I]] as Russian ambassador to Japan to conclude a commercial treaty, but his efforts were thwarted by the Japanese government. *[[Vasily Golovnin]], Fedor Mur, [[Andrey Khlebnikov]] with the crew (1811, Russia) - Russian navigators who were held captive for two years on the island of [[Hokkaido]]. Golovnin's book, ''Captivity in Japan During the Years 1811, 1812, 1813'',<ref>Narrative of my Captivity in Japan, etc. To which is added, an account of voyages to the coasts of Japan, and for the release of the author. by Capt. Rikord by Vasily Mikhailovich Golovnin</ref> was widely read by Europeans. Khlebnikov's mémoires left unpublished. *[[Philipp Franz von Siebold]] (1823, Netherlands/Germany) A German physician, botanist in Dutch service at [[Dejima]] who brought Western medicine to Japan. He was expelled from Japan after being accused as a spy (Siebold Incident).<ref>''Siebold and Japan. His Life and Work''. by Arlette Kouwenhoven, Matthi Forrer, M. Forrer and A. Kouwenhoven (2000)</ref> *[[Heinrich Bürger]] (1825..1835, Netherlands/Germany), A German scientist in Dutch service who became a pharmacist and botanist on Dejima. *[[Ranald MacDonald]] (1848, United States), The first native English-speaker to teach English in Japan, who taught [[Einosuke Moriyama]], one of the chief interpreters to handle the negotiations between [[Commodore Matthew Perry|Commodore Perry]] and the [[Tokugawa shogunate]]. *[[Matthew C. Perry]] (1853, United States) A [[Commodore (rank)|Commodore]] of the U.S. Navy who opened Japan to the West in 1854.<ref>''The Perry mission to Japan, 1853–1854'' by William Gerald Beasley, Aaron Haight Palmer, Henry F. Graff, Yashi Shōzan, Ernest Mason Satow, Shuziro Watanabe</ref> *[[Townsend Harris]] (1855, United States) The first United States Consul-General to Japan.<ref>''Townsend Harris, First American Envoy in Japan'' by William Elliot Griffis.</ref> *[[Henry Heusken]] (1855, United States) A Dutch-American interpreter for the American consulate in Japan who was assassinated by anti-foreigner [[rōnin]]. His diary was published as ''Japan journal, 1855–1861''.<ref>''Japan journal, 1855–1861'' by Henry Heusken</ref> *[[Rutherford Alcock]] (1859, United Kingdom) The first British diplomatic representative to live in Japan. His book, ''The Capital of the Tycoon'',<ref>The Capital of the Tycoon: A Narrative of a Three Years' Residence in Japan. By Rutherford Alcock.</ref> became one of the first books to describe Edo-period Japan systematically. *[[James Curtis Hepburn]] (1859, United States) An American physician, educator and Christian missionary who is known for the Hepburn romanization system, enabling westerners to read and write Japanese in Roman script.<ref>''A Japanese and English Dictionary with an English and Japanese Index'' by James Curtis Hepburn</ref> * [[Thomas Blake Glover]] (1859, Scotland) A [[Scotland|Scottish]] merchant who supported the anti-Edo government militant [[Satchō Alliance]]. His residence in [[Nagasaki]] still remains as a museum ([[Glover Garden]]).<ref>トーマス・グラバー伝 アレキサンダー マッケイ (著), Alexander McKay (原著), 平岡 緑 (翻訳) {{ISBN|978-4120026522}}</ref> *Margaret Tate Kinnear Ballagh (1861, United States) An American missionary who lived in Yokohama. Her account ''Glimpses Of Old Japan, 1861–1866''<ref>''Glimpses Of Old Japan'', 1861–1866. By Margaret Tate Kinnear Ballagh</ref> is the only book written by a Western woman staying in Edo period Japan. *[[Nicholas of Japan]] (1861, Russia) A [[Russian Orthodox]] priest, monk, archbishop and saint who introduced the Eastern Orthodox Church to Japan.<ref>宣教師ニコライと明治日本 中村 健之介 (Senkyōshi Nikorai to Meiji Nihon, by Nakamura Kennosuke) </ref> *[[Charles Wirgman]] (1861, United Kingdom) An English artist and cartoonist, the creator of ''Japan Punch'' which was the first magazine in Japan.<ref>Wirgman Drawings collection under (2002) {{ISBN|4000257528}} by Haga Toru</ref> *[[Charles Lennox Richardson]] (1862, United Kingdom) A British merchant who was murdered by samurai in the [[Namamugi Incident]] which later led to the [[Bombardment of Kagoshima]].<ref>"The Anglo-Japanese War". November 15, 1863, ''New York Times''.</ref> *[[Ernest Mason Satow]] (1862, United Kingdom) A British diplomat who assisted the negotiations during the [[Bombardment of Kagoshima]], and kept a diary of his career in Japan.<ref>''A Diplomat in Japan'' by Ernest Mason Satow</ref> *[[Aimé Humbert]] (1863, Switzerland) A Swiss politician who established a treaty with Japan and later published ''Japan and the Japanese Illustrates'', which captured many detailed scenes of Edo-period Japan.<ref>''Japan and the Japanese Illustrated'' (Google eBook) by Aimé Humbert, [[Frances Cashel Hoey]]. R. Bentley & son, 1874 – Japan</ref> *[[Felice Beato]] (1865, United Kingdom) A photographer who recorded many rare views of Edo Period Japan.<ref>''Felice Beato: A Photographer on the Eastern Road''. By Anne Lacoste.</ref> *[[Heinrich Schliemann]] (1865, Germany) An archaeologist who stayed in Japan for two months.<ref>''La Chine et le Japon au temps présent'' (1867)</ref> *[[Frederik Blekman]] (1839, Amsterdam / Holland) reached Nagasaki on 16 April 1859 via Jakarta. Translator and empresario
==See also== *[[Sakoku]] *[[Dejima]] *[[Dutch missions to Edo]] *[[Dutch East India Company]] *[[VOC Opperhoofden in Japan]] *[[Convention of Kanagawa]] *[[Christianity in Japan]] *[[History of Roman Catholicism in Japan]] *[[Empire of Japan–Russian Empire relations]] * [[Japan–United Kingdom relations]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=January 2018}} {{Use British English|date=January 2018}} ''' Luke Frost''' is an abstract painter living in [[Cornwall]], and is the son of the [[England|English]] painter [[Anthony Frost]] and the grandson of [[Sir Terry Frost]].
His work featured in the "Art Now Cornwall" exhibition, at [[Tate St Ives]], 2007, and he was Artist in Residence at Tate St Ives in 2008 following with a solo show from 24 January to 4 May 2009 .

{{BLP sources|date=September 2015}} {{Infobox model | name = Martha Hunt | image = [[File:Carolina Herrera AW14 03.jpg|300x300px]] | image_size = | alt = | caption = | birth_name = Martha Seifert HuntNorth Carolina Birth Index, 1800–2000 | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1989|4|27}} | birth_place = [[Wilson, North Carolina]], U.S. | death_date = | death_place = | nationality = American | occupation = Model | years_active = 2007–present | known_for = [[Free People]] spokesmodel

Mendel, Wayne, and [[Rebecca Taylor]]. ==Fashion career== She has walked more than 180 [[fashion show]]s, including [[Acne Studios|Acne]], [[Balmain (fashion house)|Balmain]], [[Carolina Herrera (fashion designer)|Carolina Herrera]], [[Castelbajac]], [[Chanel]], [[Christopher Kane]], [[Diane Von Furstenberg]], [[Dolce & Gabbana]], [[Fátima Lopes]], [[Giorgio Armani]], [[Givenchy]], [[Hervé Léger]], [[Issey Miyake]], [[Jason Wu]], Jefen, [[Louis Vuitton]], [[Marchesa]], [[Miu Miu]], [[Oscar de la Renta]], [[Prada]], [[rag & bone]], [[Ralph Lauren]], [[Stella McCartney]], [[Tory Burch]], [[Ramy Brook]], and [[Versace]].{{cite web|url=http://models.com/people/martha-hunt|title=Martha Hunt|website=models.com|accessdate=March 17, 2014}} In 2010 and 2011, she was featured in ''Velour'', ''[[Marie Claire]] Italia'', ''Vogue Russia'', ''Harper's Bazaar'', and ''[[Allure (magazine)|Allure]]'', as well as advertisements for [[BCBG Max Azria]], [[Y-3 (fashion brand)|Y-3]], [[Hugo Boss]], and [[Caleres|Via Spiga]].{{Cite news|url=http://fashioncow.com/2014/11/martha-hunt-david-bellemere-marie-claire-italia-december-2014/|title=Martha Hunt by David Bellemere for Marie Claire Italia, December 2014|date=2014-11-21|work=fashionCOW|access-date=2017-10-03|language=en-US}}{{Cite news|url=http://www.lingeriepedia.com/models/992-martha-hunt.html|title=Martha Hunt|last=lingeriepedia|work=Lingeriepedia|access-date=2017-10-03|language=en-gb}} She signed with [[IMG Models]] in 2012, during which she also posed for Pennyblack, [[Jason Wu]], and Victoria's Secret, was featured on the cover of ''[[Elle (magazine)|Elle]]'', and was selected for [[LOVE (magazine)|''LOVE'']] magazine's 2012 video advent calendar.{{citation needed|date=September 2015}} In 2013, she was featured in commercials for Miu Miu, Santa Lolla, Max&Co (with [[Frida Gustavsson]]), [[Express, Inc.|Express]], [[Ralph Lauren Corporation|Ralph Lauren]], [[Prada]], rag & bone, and [[Juicy Couture]].
